content:
I didn’t have STEM background. 
I didn’t know what pip install was. 
Heck, I didn’t speak a word of English.
I grew up with my grandma in the rural part of Kyrgyzstan. 
My first job was selling potatoes and onions on a sidewalk at a local bazar in Bishkek. 

Now, I live in San Francisco. 
Every day, I meet the smartest and the most Influential people in Tech. 
My self-doubt and imposter syndrome have never been this high. 
99% of the time, I am the dumbest person in the room. 

This slowly was getting under my skin. 
It was making me feel small and insignificant. 
I wouldn’t ask questions because I didn’t want to sound foolish. This made me stuck in one place. 


Until I realized, if I keep being quiet, I won’t ever grow and learn. 
So now, the first thing I do when I wake up is leetcode problems. 
I go to deeply technical meetups. 
I make friends with excellent engineers and scientists. 

And I am finally okay with looking like a fool and learning as much as I can. As fearlessly as I can.

This is a reminder, to never let your environment dictate how you should feel about yourself.

Instead use it as a source of inspiration to propel you forward. 
 
#datascience #adhd #mentalhealth #leetcode #impostersyndrome
name: Meri Nova

content:
Once you’ve worked with Machine Learning long enough, you realize tools do not matter as much.  

- whether it's PyTorch or TensorFlow At its core, it's all matrix multiplication and activation functions.

- whether it's LangChain or LlamaIndex At its core, it's all prompt engineering and retrieval generation.

- whether it's scikit-learn or XGBoost At its core, it's all statistical modeling and mathematical optimization. 

- whether it's Pinecone or ChromaDB At its core, it's all storage and retrieval of unstructured data as high-dimensional vectors.

- whether it's Claude or GPT or Llama At its core, it's all next token probability prediction services.

Tools come and go. Fundamentals stay forever.

name: Meri Nova

content:
Yesterday, the creator of Pandas, Wes McKinney, was asked to give advice for Data Scientists, so he answered with a shocking response: " Learn SQL. " 🤯

I didn't believe what I heard. The creator of one of the largest Python libraries with 60 million downloads every month, tells everyone to learn SQL!
 
I chuckled but was intrigued to hear his explanation. 

Here is what he said: 

" Well, some people on the Discord are going to laugh because I'm going to say that learning SQL is actually a really good skill. It's not just learning SQL the language, but learning the concepts of relational algebra and how to think about data sets, designing schemas, and  organizing data."

...

"It is about learning the file formatting and the basics of data storage, data partitioning, and the relationship between the execution engines. All of these things will yield you to be a better DBT user, a better Snowflake user or a Databricks user.

...

"Ultimately, it might seem like the wizard behind the curtain, but I think a lot of these systems have very similar architectures and properties. This will help you understand how these systems work and how to use them effectively."

...

I loved the advice and we have a lot to learn from him. 
Why? Because of his impressive contributions and his background: 👇


- Wes McKinney is a notable figure in the open-source community. 

- He dropped out of college to develop the Pandas library.

- He co-founded the Apache Arrow project, a cross-language development platform for in-memory data.

- He developed the Ibis project, which provides a more efficient way to bridge SQL and Python for data analysis. (Which is pretty cool)

- He published O'Reily book - "Python for Data Analysis," a widely-used reference book for learning Pandas. 

...

If you haven't heard about him or his work yet (which I doubt),  I highly encourage you to check out Chip Huyen's YouTube for the recording. 

Link in the comments.

content:
The FAANG Dream is dying.


A glorified 60-hour week is not fun anymore. Using AI to automate your work and reclaim your freedom is.

A 15% stock refresh on your $180,000 base salary is not fun anymore. A 100x return on your bootstrapped SaaS company is.

A 30-year mortgage for a $2 million shack in Mountain View, CA is not fun anymore. Building a beachfront villa in Bali after your startup exit is.

The world has become increasingly remote-first. 

A tech startup or personal brand can lead to generational wealth while maintaining a work-life balance. 


As we enter 2025, the illusion of stability at FAANG is finally dissipating. 

It is time to join or build a startup of your own.

name: Meri Nova

content:
At 17, I was rejected by the US embassy for a student visa. 
At 18, I was rejected for a financial aid from my college.
At 21, I was rejected for internships by Big Tech companies. 
At 22, I was rejected by Y Combinator. 
At 24, I got into $45k of debt, because of a failed business. 

I was scared, lonely, and depressed. 
But I refused to give up. 

So at 25, I taught myself Python and Data Science fundamentals. 
I built my portfolio, got my first tech job and paid off my debt!

How did I do it? 

- I developed a thick skin and started building technical skills. 
- I surrounded myself with smart people and learned from them daily. 
- And most importantly, I stopped taking failures personally. 

Because failures don't define you, they teach you the most valuable lessons so you can level up!

That is why, I am building an exclusive community for the most passionate and knowledge-hungry individuals to upskill in AI and Data. ( If you want to be among the first 50 people, sign up here -https://lnkd.in/gU5nmYmw) 


Keep growing, keep pushing, and fill your life with people who lift you up even higher!

You deserve every dream you ever had.

Software engineers are not scared of AI replacing them.

They are scared:


• Of managers pushing AI tools without understanding their limitations or risks.

• Of having more projects with tighter deadlines because of “AI-enhanced productivity”

• That unrealistic AI hype will lead to rushed, half-baked implementations.

• Of being forced to maintain AI systems they don't fully understand or trust.

• Of constantly adopting new tools instead of writing code and making progress. 

… 


In all seriousness, AI engineering will eventually become the new software engineering 2.0


Let’s make the transition smooth.

name: Meri Nova

content:
You don't have to lock yourself into one technical role.

In 2020, I was convinced I wanted to be a data analyst. By the end of it, I got tired of making visualizations and reports.

In 2021, I was convinced I was going to be a Research Data scientist. By the end of it, I got tired of endless experimentation and Jupyter notebooks. 

In 2023, I was convinced I wanted to be an NLP engineer. By the end of it, I got tired of processing text and building chatbots. 


Earlier in my career, I felt ashamed of having too many interests.
Until, I've realized, exploring different options is not only okay, but necessary for growth.

Don't be afraid to experiment early in your career. 
It will ultimately make you a better tech leader!
name: Meri Nova

content:
6 books that shaped me as a Machine Learning engineer. 

If I had to start from scratch, I would read these first: 


1."Designing Machine Learning Systems" by Chip Huyen
Easy to read and yet covers everything from Data Engineering for ML to deploying production-grade machine learning systems. 

2."Python Machine Learning" by Sebastian Raschka, PhD
An amazing resource for learning Python for ml applications. Works great for both beginners and experienced folks. 

3. "How Not to Be Wrong: The Power of Mathematical Thinking" by Jordan Ellenberg. 
A brilliant book that teaches you to think mathematically, helping you avoid common logical pitfalls in data analysis and machine learning. 

4. "A First Course in Probability" by Sheldon Ross
Understanding probability is fundamental to machine learning. This book is a great introduction to probabilistic thinking and statistical inference. 

5. "The Hundred-Page Machine Learning Book" by Andriy Burkov
A concise yet comprehensive overview of machine learning concepts, perfect for quick reference and as a primer for understanding the field. It’s a great starting point for anyone new to the field.

6. "Designing Data-Intensive Applications" by Martin Kleppmann
A well-known book among software engineers, however also necessary for ml engineers to grasp the fundamentals of scalable system design.  


These books will provide 80% of the foundation to become an excellent ML engineer. 

....

Do you have any additions?

name: Meri Nova

content:
If you want to get a job as an AI engineer, don’t start with the hottest tools and frameworks like Langchain, Llamaindex or Pytorch.

Sure, you’ve probably heard everyone talking about the latest AI tools and frameworks like they're the secret sauce to success… but here’s the truth nobody tells you. 

Technologies come and go—what’s cutting-edge AI or LLM tool today might be outdated tomorrow. But! Fundamentals underneath these tools stay forever. You need to learn to walk before you can run!

Focus on these first: 

🔑 Understand Neural Networks
LLMs are built on neural networks, so getting a handle on the basics like layers, activation functions, and backpropagation will take you further than focusing on the latest AI fad.
Start here: Neural Networks and Deep Learning - https://lnkd.in/gsPi-nSj

🔑 Prompt Engineering Basics
LLMs are only as good as the prompts they receive. Learning the fundamentals of crafting effective prompts can help you get better results from any AI coding assistant or LLM tool.
Start here: Prompt Engineering Guide - https://lnkd.in/gtVtw5nU

🔑 Data Curation & Preparation
LLMs need vast amounts of data to perform well. Understanding how to clean, preprocess, and organize data will always be a high-demand skill in this space.
Start here: Training & Fine-Tuning:  Data -https://lnkd.in/gmMApezn

🔑 NLP & LLM Fundamentals
Natural Language Processing (NLP) is the heart of LLMs. Get familiar with concepts like tokenization, embeddings, and attention mechanisms to understand what drives LLM performance.
Start here: Andrej Karpathy’s Zero to Hero playlist - https://lnkd.in/gQuHDJup

🔑 Model Deployment & Scaling
Knowing how to deploy, fine-tune, and monitor LLMs in production is just as important as building them. Cloud infrastructure and APIs will be your best friends here.
Start here: Large Language Models: Application through Production - https://lnkd.in/gn8fBrrJ

Tools and technologies will continue to change, but these foundational skills and understanding of the fundamental deep learning concepts will stay forever and will help you adapt to any additional layers of GenAI or  LLM-related tools. 

I am hosting a live session with IBM and Clicked to share more on the current AI and LLM landscape, as well as career trajectories, so you can learn how to position yourself well in this rapidly growing field.


📅 Date: September 24th. 

🔗 Hurry and sign up, while the registration is still open! 

https://lnkd.in/gKc5vqS8

name: Meri Nova

content:
If I wanted to break into Machine Learning in 2025, these are 3 types of projects I would have in my portfolio:

Forget the cookie-cutter approach of "1 LLM-powered chatbot, 1 Pytorch project, and 1 scikit-learn tutorial".

Trust me, no one's scanning portfolios for general implementations of popular libraries. 

Instead of following the crowd, focus on demonstrating depth and breadth in key ML competencies:

1. An End-to-End ML Pipeline
Skills to demonstrate: Data preprocessing, feature engineering, model selection, hyperparameter tuning, deployment, and monitoring.
Trust me you will learn a LOT by doing this. 

2. A State-of-the-Art Model Implementation 
Skills to demonstrate: Deep understanding of cutting-edge algorithms, ability to read and implement research papers,by translating math equations into working Python code. 

3. Find A Real-World Problem you care about. 
Skills to demonstrate: Problem framing, business impact assessment, data acquisition, approach and tech stack selection, ethical considerations, and project documentation. 

You could integrate all 3 aspects into one comprehensive project or showcase them separately. The key is demonstrating your ability to tackle real-world ML challenges and make a tangible impact. 

Stop endlessly consuming courses and start building!

If you want to learn more about how to build a portfolio join our event, where we will share 20+ project ideas and guidelines in Data, AI & ML: 

https://lu.ma/yxn73k6q


🎁 Once you register, we will email you a PDF and a recording!

Happy coding!

name: Meri Nova

content:
If I were to transition from Data Science to AI/ML engineering all over again in 2025, here is what I'd learn first: 


learn Software Engineering fundamentals
– master git for tracking code and model changes
– learn CI/CD pipelines for automated deployment
- master Python, async/await, and OOP
– practice writing clean, maintainable Python code, follow PEP8

learn API development
– try out building with FastAPI or Flask frameworks
– understand http/https
– learn rest APIs for model endpoints
– grasp API authentication and rate limiting

learn data infrastructure
– understand vector databases (Pinecone, Weaviate)
– practice storing, indexing, and querying unstructured data.
– build data pipelines and ETL processes
– learn about data streaming for real-time AI

learn cloud platforms
– master aws/gcp/azure ML/AI services
– understand docker, kubernetes 
– learn serverless deployment options
– implement cloud-based monitoring

study MLops fundamentals
– implement model monitoring and logging
– master model versioning and registry
– understand A/B testing in production
– understand system monitoring and alerting

learn production best practices
– implement proper error handling
- understand time/space complexity (Big O notation)
– master debugging in production environments
– master common AI system design patterns (prompt chaining, routing, parallelization, orchestration, and evaluation) 



Once you master both Data Science and Software Engineering skills, you will become unstoppable in 2025. 


#AIengineering
name: Meri Nova

content:
Stop using static datasets to build your ML project!
Instead, use public APIs and impress hiring managers with your skills.
Here are 5 project ideas with API links to get you started: 👇 


1. Music Recommender

𝗣𝗿𝗼𝗷𝗲𝗰𝘁: Build a personalized music recommender system using Spotify's API. Use user listening history, song features, and artist popularity to recommend tracks that match user preferences.
𝗔𝗣𝗜: Spotify - https://lnkd.in/gJY8VsCj

What you'll learn: Recommender Systems, Collaborative Filtering, Python, API Integration


2. Stock Market Trend Prediction

𝗣𝗿𝗼𝗷𝗲𝗰𝘁: Build a model to predict stock price movements based on live financial data. Use the Alpha Vantage API to pull historical and real-time market data and combine it with sentiment analysis from news articles.
𝗔𝗣𝗜: Alpha Vantage - (https://lnkd.in/gdU2raHM)

What you'll learn: Time Series Forecasting, Sentiment Analysis, Feature Engineering, Python, API Integration


3. Social Media Sentiment Tracking

𝗣𝗿𝗼𝗷𝗲𝗰𝘁: Build a sentiment analysis dashboard that monitors public sentiment towards companies or products in real-time using Twitter's API. This project can track how sentiment correlates with stock price or product sales.
𝗔𝗣𝗜: Twitter API - (https://lnkd.in/gv8E9jdt)

What you'll learn: Natural Language Processing, Sentiment Analysis, Data Visualization, Python, API Integration


4. Housing Market Price Prediction

𝗣𝗿𝗼𝗷𝗲𝗰𝘁: Create a model that predicts housing prices in your neighborhoods by pulling real estate data from Zillow's API. Combine it with demographic data from government APIs to find trends in housing affordability.
𝗔𝗣𝗜𝘀: Zillow API - (https://lnkd.in/gqAypm7U), US Census API - (https://lnkd.in/gR7RkVvi)

What you'll learn: Regression, Feature Engineering, Data Merging, Python, API Integration


5. Health Trend Prediction

𝗣𝗿𝗼𝗷𝗲𝗰𝘁: Analyze global health trends using WHO's public health data API. Build a time series model to forecast future trends in diseases and predict which regions may need more healthcare resources in the future.
𝗔𝗣𝗜: WHO Global Health Observatory API - (https://lnkd.in/gAuCcC8e)

What you'll learn: Time Series Analysis, Data Visualization, Forecasting, Python, API Integration



If this is not enough, you can also choose from 100s more public APIs from this repo - https://lnkd.in/gn7m3me7 !

name: Meri Nova

content:
Yesterday I had a mentorship call with a recent graduate who wanted to break into ML. The first thing I heard was: "I want to learn LLMs and Neural Networks to land my first job. "

This is something I hear every day and truthfully I get it. I did the same thing when I was just starting out. I thought if I could show them I could build the "hard things" I would stand out from the competition. 

I was very wrong. 

If your goal is to get a job in ML, you need to NAIL the fundamentals, which usually involves Statistics, Python, and ML algorithms, and building a relevant portfolio! 

And if later on, you want to transition to Deep Learning, these skills will provide you with a solid foundation and you will do it with much ease. 
But first, align your skills to the actual job requirements!

content:
Stop using static datasets to build your ML project!
Instead, use public APIs and impress hiring managers with your skills.
Here are 5 project ideas with API links to get you started: 👇 


1. Stock Market Trend Prediction

𝗣𝗿𝗼𝗷𝗲𝗰𝘁: Build a model to predict stock price movements based on live financial data. Use the Alpha Vantage API to pull historical and real-time market data and combine it with sentiment analysis from news articles.
𝗔𝗣𝗜: Alpha Vantage - (https://lnkd.in/gdU2raHM)

What you'll learn: Time Series Forecasting, Sentiment Analysis, Feature Engineering, Python, API Integration


2. Music Recommender

𝗣𝗿𝗼𝗷𝗲𝗰𝘁: Build a personalized music recommender system using Spotify's API. Use user listening history, song features, and artist popularity to recommend tracks that match user preferences.
𝗔𝗣𝗜: Spotify - https://lnkd.in/gJY8VsCj

What you'll learn: Recommender Systems, Collaborative Filtering, Python, API Integration


3. Social Media Sentiment Tracking

𝗣𝗿𝗼𝗷𝗲𝗰𝘁: Build a sentiment analysis dashboard that monitors public sentiment towards companies or products in real-time using Twitter's API. This project can track how sentiment correlates with stock price or product sales.
𝗔𝗣𝗜: Twitter API - (https://lnkd.in/gv8E9jdt)

What you'll learn: Natural Language Processing, Sentiment Analysis, Data Visualization, Python, API Integration


4. Housing Market Price Prediction

𝗣𝗿𝗼𝗷𝗲𝗰𝘁: Create a model that predicts housing prices in your neighborhoods by pulling real estate data from Zillow's API. Combine it with demographic data from government APIs to find trends in housing affordability.
𝗔𝗣𝗜𝘀: Zillow API - (https://lnkd.in/gqAypm7U), US Census API - (https://lnkd.in/gR7RkVvi)

What you'll learn: Regression, Feature Engineering, Data Merging, Python, API Integration


5. Health Trend Prediction

𝗣𝗿𝗼𝗷𝗲𝗰𝘁: Analyze global health trends using WHO's public health data API. Build a time series model to forecast future trends in diseases and predict which regions may need more healthcare resources in the future.

What you'll learn: Time Series Analysis, Data Visualization, Forecasting, Python, API Integration

name: Meri Nova

content:
Machine Learning interviews have 4-5 components to it. 

Get ready for the hottest hiring season in Jan and Feb with this guide:👇


- the coding interview
Prepare for: 
𝐓𝐡𝐞 𝐝𝐚𝐭𝐚 𝐬𝐭𝐫𝐮𝐜𝐭𝐮𝐫𝐞𝐬: Arrays, linked lists, stacks, queues, trees, heaps, hash tables, and graphs.
𝐓𝐡𝐞 𝐚𝐥𝐠𝐨𝐫𝐢𝐭𝐡𝐦𝐬: Breadth-first search (BFS), depth-first search (DFS), recursion, and sorting algorithms.
𝐁𝐢𝐠 𝐎 𝐧𝐨𝐭𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧: trade-offs for time and space complexity


- ML fundamentals
Prepare for: 
𝐂𝐨𝐫𝐞 𝐌𝐋 𝐜𝐨𝐧𝐜𝐞𝐩𝐭𝐬: supervised vs unsupervised, overfitting vs underfitting, bias-variance tradeoff, and regularization techniques(L1, L2) and evaluation metrics. 
𝐀𝐥𝐠𝐨𝐫𝐢𝐭𝐡𝐦𝐬:  random forests, gradient boosting (e.g., XGBoost, LightGBM), SVMs, k-means, PCA, etc. 
𝐃𝐞𝐞𝐩 𝐋𝐞𝐚𝐫𝐧𝐢𝐧𝐠: NN, activation functions, backpropagation, CNNs, RNNs, LSTM, and transformers.


- system design (ML)
Prepare for: 
𝐃𝐞𝐬𝐢𝐠𝐧𝐢𝐧𝐠 an end-to-end ML pipeline, from data ingestion to model deployment.
𝐒𝐜𝐚𝐥𝐚𝐛𝐢𝐥𝐢𝐭𝐲 & 𝐓𝐫𝐚𝐝𝐞-𝐨𝐟𝐟𝐬: latency vs throughput,  how to handle large datasets, distributed training, and serving models at scale.


- behavioral interview
Prepare for: 
𝐒𝐡𝐚𝐫𝐢𝐧𝐠 your impact story with the STAR (Situation, Task, Action, and Result) method. 


- research/math interview (for research roles)
Prepare for: 
𝐋𝐢𝐧𝐞𝐚𝐫 𝐀𝐥𝐠𝐞𝐛𝐫𝐚: Matrix operations, eigenvalues, eigenvectors, and singular value decomposition (SVD).
𝐏𝐫𝐨𝐛𝐚𝐛𝐢𝐥𝐢𝐭𝐲 𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐒𝐭𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐬𝐭𝐢𝐜𝐬: Bayes’ theorem, probability distributions, hypothesis testing, and confidence intervals.
𝐎𝐩𝐭𝐢𝐦𝐢𝐳𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧: Gradient descent, stochastic gradient descent, and convex optimization.
𝐀𝐝𝐯𝐚𝐧𝐜𝐞𝐝 𝐓𝐨𝐩𝐢𝐜𝐬: If applying for research-heavy roles, be familiar with topics like reinforcement learning, generative models (GANs, VAEs), and advanced neural architectures.


....


Get the full 30-page Interview Prep Guide for every role in Data & ML
from the best  Break Into Data mentors 👇

https://lnkd.in/gKv7VQ5C
name: Meri Nova

content:
If you want to get a job as a machine learning engineer, don’t start by diving into the hottest libraries like PyTorch,TensorFlow, Langchain, etc. 

Yes, you might hear a lot about them or some other trending technology of the year...but guess what!

Technologies evolve rapidly, especially in the age of AI, but core concepts are always seen as more valuable than expertise in any particular tool. Stop trying to perform a brain surgery without knowing anything about human anatomy. 

Instead, here are basic skills that will get you further than mastering any framework: 


𝐌𝐚𝐭𝐡𝐞𝐦𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐜𝐬 𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐒𝐭𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐬𝐭𝐢𝐜𝐬 - My first exposure to probability and statistics was in college, and it felt abstract at the time, but these concepts are the backbone of ML. 

You can start here: Khan Academy Statistics and Probability - https://lnkd.in/gtjzFrZP

𝐋𝐢𝐧𝐞𝐚𝐫 𝐀𝐥𝐠𝐞𝐛𝐫𝐚 𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐂𝐚𝐥𝐜𝐮𝐥𝐮𝐬 - Concepts like matrices, vectors, eigenvalues, and derivatives are fundamental to understanding how ml algorithms work. These are used in everything from simple regression to deep learning.

You can start here: 3Blue1Brown’s Channel https://lnkd.in/gSfpKWBQ

𝐏𝐫𝐨𝐠𝐫𝐚𝐦𝐦𝐢𝐧𝐠 - Should you learn Python, Rust, R, Julia, JavaScript, etc.? The best advice is to pick the language that is most frequently used for the type of work you want to do. I started with Python due to its simplicity and extensive library support, and it remains my go-to language for machine learning tasks.

You can start here: Automate the Boring Stuff with Python - https://lnkd.in/gmqdwrPD

𝐀𝐥𝐠𝐨𝐫𝐢𝐭𝐡𝐦 𝐔𝐧𝐝𝐞𝐫𝐬𝐭𝐚𝐧𝐝𝐢𝐧𝐠 - Understand the fundamental algorithms before jumping to deep learning. This includes linear regression, decision trees, SVMs, and clustering algorithms. 

You can start here: Andrew Ng’s ML Course - https://lnkd.in/ggusYiX8

𝐃𝐞𝐩𝐥𝐨𝐲𝐦𝐞𝐧𝐭 𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐏𝐫𝐨𝐝𝐮𝐜𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧:
Knowing how to take a model from development to production is invaluable. This includes understanding APIs, model optimization, and monitoring. Tools like Docker and Flask are often used in this process.

You can start here: Full Stack Deep Learning - https://lnkd.in/g6dYBZss

𝐂𝐥𝐨𝐮𝐝 𝐂𝐨𝐦𝐩𝐮𝐭𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐁𝐢𝐠 𝐃𝐚𝐭𝐚:
Familiarity with cloud platforms (AWS, Google Cloud, Azure) and big data tools (Spark) is increasingly important as datasets grow larger. These skills help you manage and process large-scale data efficiently.

You can start here: Google Cloud Machine Learning - https://lnkd.in/gVZ7JZTh

I love frameworks and libraries, and they can make anyone's job easier. 

But the more solid your foundation, the easier it will be to pick up any new technologies and actually validate whether they solve your problems. 



Sign up for my newsletter for more guidance merinova.substack.com

What people don’t see:

The math is simple:

More failures = More lessons
More lessons = Faster growth
Faster growth = 10x Better results

The people who succeed aren't the ones who avoid failure. 
They're the ones who run straight at it, learn from it, and keep going.

So don't ever stop trying. Your breakthroughs are closer than you think.

content:
If I wanted to break into Machine Learning in 2024, these are 3 types of projects I would have in my portfolio:

Forget the cookie-cutter approach of "1 LLM-powered chatbot, 1 Pytorch project, and 1 scikit-learn implementation".
Trust me, no one's scanning portfolios for general implementations of popular libraries. 

Instead of following the crowd, focus on demonstrating depth and breadth in key ML competencies:

1. An End-to-End ML Pipeline
Skills to demonstrate: Data preprocessing, feature engineering, model selection, hyperparameter tuning, deployment, and monitoring.
Trust me you will learn a LOT by doing this. 

2. A State-of-the-Art Model Implementation 
Skills to demonstrate: Deep understanding of cutting-edge algorithms, ability to read and implement research papers,by translating math equations into working Python code. 

3. Find A Real-World Problem you care about. 
Skills to demonstrate: Problem framing, business impact assessment, data acquisition, approach and tech stack selection, ethical considerations, and project documentation. 

You could integrate all 3 aspects into one comprehensive project or showcase them separately. The key is demonstrating your ability to tackle real-world ML challenges and make a tangible impact. 

Stop endlessly consuming courses and start building!
Your future in ML starts with hands-on experience.

If you want to learn more about how to build a portfolio read this article:
https://lnkd.in/g7sTg8Re 

Happy coding!

content:
The devil works hard but ML engineers work harder. 
I learned something surprising yesterday that should probably be illegal. 

While browsing through LLM projects on YouTube, I came across a tutorial that promised to scrape websites 10 times faster using LLMs. 

I was intrigued but skeptical. 

And oh boy, what did I learn! The days of HTML tag parsing using Beautiful Soup and long hours of cleaning are officially gone. 

Now, you can use an LLM-powered tool called 𝐉𝐢𝐧𝐚 𝐀𝐈 that:

1.  Instead of returning raw HTML, Jina AI understands and extracts only the relevant data from the web page using advanced embedding models.

2.  Then it automatically removes unnecessary HTML tags, normalizes the text, and organizes it into JSON or a more human-readable format, like plain text. 

3.  It is less detected and is less likely to be blocked by websites because it doesn't have repetitive patterns and high request rates. 

And the best part is - it is free!

I don’t know what the deal is with them. 

But I am grateful I found it. 

I will use this to feed my RAG libraries. 

...

What will you do with it? 


Legal Disclaimer:
The information provided here is for educational purposes only. Web scraping may be subject to legal restrictions. Before using any web scraping tools or techniques, ensure you have the right to access and use the data from the targeted websites. Unauthorized scraping or use of data may result in legal consequences. I do not endorse or take responsibility for any misuse of the information provided.

content:
If tomorrow I were hit by a bus, got a concussion, and lost all of my memory. 
I would be SAD, but I'd still want to learn ML engineering from scratch. And here is how I would do it in 2024, mostly in order:

Learn math:
 - linear algebra: Matrices, vectors, linear equations and transformations, 
 - probability and statistics: Distributions, hypothesis testing, Bias-Variance Tradeoff, and conditional probability.
 - calculus: Derivatives, integrals, gradient descent.

Learn Python:
 - data structures: Lists, arrays, and dictionaries.
 - libraries: NumPy, Pandas for data manipulations, scikit-learn for ml and Matplotlib for data viz. 
 - code organization and control flow: Functions, loops, and conditionals. 

Data Preprocessing:
 -  learn how to handle missing values, duplicates, and outliers
 -  read on feature engineering 
 -  try out data normalization and scaling

Core ML Algorithms:
 - Supervised Learning: Linear and Logistic Regression, and Classification algorithms(K-NN, Decision Trees, SVM)
 - Unsupervised Learning: Clustering (K-means) and dimensionality reduction techniques (PCA)
 - Reinforcement Learning: Basics of agents, environments, and reward systems

Model Evaluation and Validation:
 - learn metrics like accuracy, precision, recall, and F1 score
 - cross-validation techniques
 - learn about overfitting and underfitting, and how to address them

Get Hands-On Experience with Deployment:
 - use datasets from Kaggle and/or models from Huggingface. 
-  learn to deploy with Flask, FastAPI, and on Cloud (AWS or Azure or GCP)
 - participate in ml competitions or workshops. 

Digest everything before diving into advanced topics like:
 - ml frameworks like PyTorch, and TensorFlow 
 - neural networks, convolutional networks, and recurrent networks
 - understand (NLP) and computer vision (CV) applications and ensemble techniques 

Stay Updated:
 - I'd also follow Meri Nova, Chip Huyen, Bojan Tunguz, Ph.D., Andrew Ng, and Aurimas Griciūnas to stay updated on ml. 
 - And join online communities for networking like Break Into Data and Marvelous MLOps

But hopefully, I won't get hit by a bus and you will learn something new. 😁

Give yourself at least 5-6 months to nail these fundamentals and to build a unique portfolio...

And hopefully, you will land your first gig or better yet a full-time job! 

...

So more people can learn!

name: Meri Nova

content:
I should probably NOT say this, but there is a hidden hierarchy in LLM engineering that nobody talks about. 

The truth is, there are 4 levels of LLM implementations that impact your compensation. Companies are well aware of this and allocate their budgets according to each level. 
To truly succeed, focus on one and position yourself as an expert. 

Here are 4 main LLM expertise levels: 

1. AI Enthusiasts:
Basic understanding of how LLMs work. 
Passionate about AI, but limited practical engineering experience. 
Compensation: Entry-level salaries or internships. $60,000 - $90,000

2. AI Engineers
Don’t work with underlying architecture of the models but know how to integrate and deploy LLMs with external databases and architectures like RAG through API calls. 
Compensation: High-end salaries. $100,000 - $200,000+

3. ML Engineers
Deep expertise in machine learning algorithms and optimization.
Develop custom LLMs with advanced fine-tuning methods. 
Compensation: Competitive industry salaries, often with equity. $200,000 - $300,000+

4. ML Researcher Engineers
Contribute to cutting-edge LLM research and publications
Develop novel architectures, training techniques, or applications.
Bridge the gap between academic breakthroughs and industry implementation. Build models from scratch.
Compensation: Top-tier salaries, significant equity, and research grants. $300,000 - $500,000+

...

Tomorrow, I will release an article with more details on each level. 
So you will understand the LLM industry better and build your portfolio accordingly.   

Sign up here to get access -  merinova.substack.com. 

...

What level are you excited about the most? 


#machinelearning #llm

P.S. Keep in mind that compensation numbers are a ballpark estimate. The final numbers depend on your location.
name: Meri Nova

content:
In 2021, I hit rock bottom and found myself $45,000 in debt after filing for business bankruptcy.

I felt ashamed for not knowing better. I didn’t know how to pay off the debt or what to do with my career...

But I knew one thing: I wanted to get smarter. 
Smarter with numbers and with data, so I’d never find myself in such a financial pit again.

That’s when I learned about Data Analytics. I was excited to build hard skills that would always be in demand. But as I started researching, I became more and more overwhelmed.

With no one to guide me, I would purchase random courses and give up halfway through. My undiagnosed ADHD would make it worse. This cycle repeated until I was almost ready to give up.

At that pivotal moment, I met my ex-partner, a Data Scientist. I was blown away by his depth of knowledge and his natural enthusiasm for Data Science. He would share interesting AI concepts with so much passion—it was admirable.

He suggested I follow the Data Science field instead, because of its abundant opportunities and higher ceiling for growth. So I followed his advice. 

Very soon, I realized that I didn’t have any support system.

While my peers had entire university faculties focused on helping them learn and get a job, I was by myself in a different country, far away from family, trying to break into data.

So I decided to put my pride aside and ask him for guidance.
To my surprise, for our next coffee date, he prepared introductory presentation slides to teach me Data Science fundamentals.

I still remember that day as if it was yesterday. He presented on Supervised and Unsupervised Machine Learning techniques and gave me few articles to read. 

After our first few lectures and discussions, it suddenly seemed less scary and complex.

I cried because that new perspective changed everything for me.

The best part was he never looked down on me and always treated me as an equal.
This way, I was able to learn fast, and in less than a year, I landed my first job in tech, where I worked with Computer Vision and Robotics. 

I paid off my debt and opened a savings account for the first time in my life.

---

Sometimes all you need is kindness and encouragement from one person at the right time. 

Thank you for being that person when I needed it the most. 

---

Fast forward to now, as I lead a Data Science Community, I strive to pay it forward by guiding others on their transition journey.

Remember, the right support can change everything.

Don't be afraid to reach out and connect with those who inspire you. 

Your breakthrough might just be a few conversations away.

#datascience #careertransition #impostersyndrome

name: Meri Nova

content:
Here are 25 most common Deep Learning interview questions for ML research positions:

Fundamentals:
- What is deep learning, and how does it differ from traditional machine learning?
- What is an activation function, and why is it important? Explain three types of activation functions.
- You are using a deep neural network for prediction, but it overfits the training data. What can you do to reduce overfitting?
- What is the vanishing gradient problem in neural networks, and how can it be fixed?
- Explain the process of backpropagation.

Neural Network Architectures:
- Describe the architecture of a typical Convolutional Neural Network (CNN).
- What are Autoencoders, and what are three practical uses of them?
- What is a transformer architecture, and how is it used in NLP tasks?
- What is the role of pooling layers in CNNs?
- What are Recurrent Neural Networks (RNNs), and where are they used?

Training and Optimization:
- How does L1/L2 regularization affect a neural network?
- Why should we use Batch Normalization?
- How do you know if your model is suffering from exploding gradients?
- What is the purpose of dropout in neural networks, and how does it affect training?
- What are some hyperparameters used in training neural networks?

Advanced Topics:
- What are the main gates in LSTM networks, and what are their tasks?
- Explain how self-attention works in transformers.
- Can CNNs be used to classify 1D signals?
- What is transfer learning, and when is it recommended or not?
- How do depthwise separable convolutions improve CNNs?

Practical Implementation:
- Describe the process of pre-training and fine-tuning in transformers.
- What are the main challenges when training a deep learning model with limited data?
- How do you handle class imbalance in deep learning?
- What are the challenges of deploying deep learning models in production?
- How would you modify a pre-trained model from classification to regression?

...

name: Meri Nova

content:
Here are 25 most common ML interview screening questions for each category: 


1. Machine Learning fundamentals:
- Explain the difference between supervised, unsupervised, and reinforcement learning. Provide an example for each.
- What is the bias-variance tradeoff? How does it affect model performance?
- Describe the process of cross-validation. Why is it important in model evaluation?
- What is overfitting, and how can you prevent it in your models?
- Explain the concept of ensemble learning. What are bagging and boosting?

2. Statistics and Probability:
- Explain the difference between frequentist and Bayesian approaches in statistics.
- What is the Central Limit Theorem, and why is it important in machine learning?
- Describe the concept of hypothesis testing and its application in A/B testing.
- What is maximum likelihood estimation? Provide an example of its use in machine learning.
- Explain the difference between correlation and causation. How does this impact model interpretation?

3. Model Evaluation and Deployment:
- What metrics would you use to evaluate a classification model? How do they differ for balanced vs. imbalanced datasets?
- Describe the process of deploying a machine learning model in a production environment.
- What is A/B testing in the context of machine learning models? How would you design an A/B test?
- Explain the concept of model drift. How can it be detected and mitigated?
- What are the key considerations when scaling a machine learning system to handle large amounts of data or traffic?

4. Python for Machine Learning:
- How would you handle missing data in a pandas DataFrame?
- Explain the difference between a list and a numpy array in Python. When would you use one over the other?
- What are lambda functions in Python? Provide an example of how they can be used in data processing.
- Describe the purpose of the scikit-learn library. How would you use it to implement a simple classification model?
- What is the difference between *args and **kwargs in Python? How might they be useful in creating flexible ML functions?

5. Data Preprocessing:
- What is feature scaling, and why is it important? Describe different methods of feature scaling.
- How do you handle categorical variables in machine learning models? Explain one-hot encoding and label encoding.
- What is dimensionality reduction? Describe PCA (Principal Component Analysis) and its applications.
- How do you deal with imbalanced datasets? Discuss various techniques to address this issue.
- What is feature selection? Describe a few methods for selecting the most important features for a model.

....

name: Meri Nova

content:
Your entire career can change in 1 year. 

10 simple ways to transform your ML skills in 2024: 

1. Set quarterly goals
Every 3 months, set a new learning goal. Whether it’s mastering a specific branch of ML-like CV or NLP, or practicing a new programming language, like Python, focus and learn only 1-3 at a time. 

2. Embrace code sprints
Dedicate at least 2-4 hours every weekend to building small ML projects. From implementing ML algorithms to integrating new libraries like Hugging Face Transformers, you need to learn by doing! 

3. Implement the "Paper-a-Week" habit
Read one ML research paper every week and summarize it in your own words. This helps you stay updated with cutting-edge tech and sharpens your ability to think critically about new methods. (Check out BuildML) 

4. Use Leetcode-like challenges 
Build problem-solving skills by working on Leetcode-style coding challenges related to DSA. Practice these every day if you want to stay interview-ready. 

5. Participate in Kaggle Competitions or Hackathons at least once a month
I built awesome ML & AI apps and made life-long connections through hackathons. Truly a great opportunity to accelerate learning.

6. Join Accountability Groups
Find or create a small group of ML learners and share your weekly progress. Regular check-ins will keep you motivated to show up and improve your tech communication skills. 

7. Document Everything
Start a blog, LinkedIn series, or GitHub repository where you explain concepts or share projects. Teaching others solidifies your own knowledge, and builds a network of like-minded people!

8. Master One Tool Per Month
Whether it’s a new framework (like PyTorch Lightning), a cloud service (like AWS Sagemaker), or an automation tool (like MLflow), diving into one tool each month builds familiarity with industry-wide accepted tools, which will make you job-ready!

9. Enroll in a Bootcamp or Take Online Courses
If you have a hard time learning by yourself, then invest in a structured learning environment like bootcamps or courses on Coursera, Datacamp, or Udemy that have a solid roadmap. 

10. Contribute to open-source 
There are so many amazing repos that need tweaking and fixing. This is a great opportunity for you to get a taste of engineering workflows. Not to mention the networking opportunities you can get! 


...

name: Meri Nova

content:
Top 1% of ML engineers have mastered these 22 math concepts. 👇

If you truly want to stand out in machine learning, don't shy away from math. 
Instead, gain an intuitive understanding of these concepts, mostly in this order. 

I promise you, everything else will fall into its place.  

Linear Algebra:
1. Matrix Multiplication for transforming data as functions
2. Eigenvectors and Eigenvalues for identifying key patterns in a high-dimensional space
3. Singular Value Decomposition (SVD) for breaking data into simpler components 
4. Dot Product for finding how closely two feature sets relate 
5. Vector Spaces and Norms for measuring distances and magnitudes 

Calculus
6. Derivatives for measuring how much variable affect an output
7. Partial Derivatives for analyzing how multiple variables change 
8. Chain Rule for linking changes between variables 
9. Gradient Descent for minimizing errors step-by-step 
10. Integrals for calculating areas under curves 

Probability & Statistics
11. Conditional Probability for estimating likelihood based on prior events 
12. Bayes' Theorem for updating predictions with new data 
13. Probability Distributions for describing possible outcomes 
14. Mean, Median, and Mode for summarizing data trends
15. Standard Deviation and Variance for measuring data spread 
16. Covariance and Correlation for finding variable relationships 
17. Hypothesis Testing for checking if results are significant 
18. Central Limit Theorem for understanding sampling distributions 

Optimization
19. Stochastic Gradient Descent for efficient optimization of large datasets 
20. Cost Functions for measuring prediction errors 
21. Lagrange Multipliers for optimizing with constraints 
22. Convex Optimization for finding global solutions 


You can learn them for FREE with this popular book on math for ML: 
https://lnkd.in/gf-zy8US

....

name: Meri Nova

content:
Don't try to learn  Machine Learning all at once! 
You will get overwhelmed and paralyzed. 
Instead, follow these rules👇 

(This is a beginner-friendly guide.)


Rule #1 - No theory without application

If you want to gain the breadth of ML topics, don't just consume content!
If you do not immediately try to implement what you've learned, you will likely forget it in a few months or weeks. Theory and application should go hand in hand!
Action: For every new ML concept you learn, set aside time to implement a simple version or experiment with it using a small dataset.


Rule #2 - Learn the math from the source code

When importing popular ML libraries, don't just use them as black boxes. Dive into the source code to understand the math that's running the show under the hood. 
Action: Choose a simple ML model from a popular library (like scikit-learn) and reverse engineer its source code with underlying logic and math.  (This is like watching a fitness coach squat and trying to learn his form)


Rule #3 - Build from scratch

Before jumping to the next model, give yourself at least 30 minutes to try building that model from scratch using only NumPy and Python. 
Action: After learning about the fundamental logic behind this new ML algorithm, try to recreate own implementation. (This is like actually squatting)

A small gift for you. 🎁 

This free ML from Scratch Course (https://lnkd.in/g6fcGD8N) takes you through writing 10 algorithms from scratch with nothing but Python and NumPy! 

- K-Nearest Neighbors
- Linear Regression

- Decision Trees
- Random Forest
- Naive Bayes
- PCA

- SVM
- K-Means


...

name: Meri Nova

content:
There are only 5  Machine Learning paradigms that dominate the industry today: 


1.  prediction: it looks at past data, adjusts for trends, and smooths out random changes to make predictions.
(eg, Arima, LSTM)

2.  classification: it finds patterns that separate one thing from another. 
(XGBoost, logistical regression, SVM)

3.  generation: it creates new things only from the things it saw before.  
(GANs, Transformers)

4.  clustering: it groups similar things together without knowing what they are. 
(K-means, hierarchical clustering)

5.  recommendation: it suggests things based on your past behavior around similar things you liked. 
(Two-Tower models, collaborative or content-based filtering)


...

Which one do you want to master the most?

name: Meri Nova

content:
This is Gus. 

We last saw each other 4 years ago. 

When he was wrapping up business school, stressed about not finding a job and possibly having to leave USA.

Fast forward to our walk yesterday. 

Gus told me, in that year, he self-taught Python and JavaScript on top of graduating with 4.0 GPA. 

In hopes of increasing the chances of securing an internship.

He applied to 400 positions and even gave a YCombinator a shot. 

Nobody responded.

After series of failed interviews and his savings nearly gone, he faced a tipping point:
pay rent, or leave the country. 

Finally, after months of hard work.
On that critical day, both BlackRock and YC emailed to say he was accepted! 

YC was an obvious choice for him. 

With his new business credit card he was able to cover the rent the same day and stay. 

Within that year his company raised $4.2 million in their first round after YC. He then proceeded to learn Portuguese and land large contracts in Latin America. 


Stories like Gus’s really inspire me.

Don’t underestimate what you can achieve in less than 5 years. 

Put in the work now. 


—


Be like Gus. 

Be relentless. 

Learn continuously. 

Take massive actions.
name: Meri Nova

content:
ML engineer from academia: "I've improved our model's accuracy by 0.01% after only three months of work!"

ML engineer from the industry: "Great, but can it handle real-world data without catching fire?"

ML engineer from academia: "Uhm... no, but we created the perfect model using this standard, static dataset everyone uses."

ML engineer from the industry: "Uhm.. our data changed twice while we were talking."
name: Meri Nova

content:
I used to think that machine learning was all about tuning model parameters. 

Fast forward a few years, and I’ve realized that real value lies in:

- building a solid data pipeline
- deeply understanding the business problem 
- crafting features that truly represent the data
- ensuring data quality to avoid "garbage in, garbage out"
- knowing when to simplify instead of overcomplicating with advanced models

Tuning models is important, but it’s only the tip of the iceberg. 
The real impact comes from how you frame the problem and prepare the data!

Being a true machine learning engineer doesn’t mean:

- making $500k at FAANG 
- working in isolation and mastering every complex model
- sacrificing sleep to be available 24/7
- using only the latest tools and frameworks
- convincing yourself that you're the world's best engineer

Being a true machine learning engineer means:

- simplifying complexity
- being a team player
- striving for domain expertise and empathy for users
- embracing and growing from uncomfortable feedback 
- never looking down on junior engineers

name: Meri Nova

content:
Python is a #1 skill for ML engineering. 

You can see how important it is on Luke Barousse's job analytics board that has over 45k ML positions.

Even though these days we have AI coding helpers, you still need to understand many fundamental Python concepts to pass ML and Data Science interviews. 

Here are 7 main concepts you need to know for Python interview rounds: 

1. Data Structures: Explain and utilize Python's built-in data structures like lists, dictionaries, sets, and tuples. Be prepared to talk about when to use each type and their performance differences. 

2. Control Flow: Be familiar with conditional statements (if, elif, else) and loops (for, while). You should also know how to use list comprehensions for more concise code.

3. Functions and Scope: Know how to define functions, the concept of scope (local vs. global variables), and how to use *args and **kwargs for flexible function arguments.

4. Error Handling: Understand how to handle exceptions using try, except, finally, and how to raise exceptions. 

5. Object-Oriented Programming (OOP): Be able to explain the principles of OOP—classes, objects, inheritance, encapsulation, and polymorphism. You may be asked to implement a simple class structure.

6. Libraries and Frameworks: Learn key functions from popular libraries like NumPy, pandas, scikit-learn, and TensorFlow. Be prepared to discuss their use cases and how to implement them. 

7. Data Manipulation: Know how to manipulate data using pandas, including cleaning, filtering, grouping, merging, and reshaping data. 

8. Algorithms: Be ready to implement common machine learning algorithms from scratch, such as logistic regression or random forest. Understand the underlying mathematics and logic behind these algorithms so you can build them on your own with Python. 

...

I personally found Jay Feng's Interview Query platform to be the best resource to practice ML questions. 

Check it out with the link below. 

I hope it makes your prep a little easier!

name: Meri Nova

content:
It breaks my heart when I see people who are in their 20s and 30s feel like they are behind in their careers. 

Don't be so hard on yourself. You can pivot and start from scratch at any age and still succeed, just like these folks:

- Vera Wang, who was a figure skater and journalist, before owning the fashion industry at age 40.

- Ray Kroc, who used to sell paper cups before he launched McDonald's expansion at age 52. 

- Stewart Butterfield, who worked as a freelance web designer, before building Slack in his 40s. 

At the end of the day, it doesn't matter what other people think. 

What matters is, if you truly know yourself. 
What makes you tick? What are you naturally good at? 

The only way to discover this is by trying different things and not being afraid to fail.

Keep experimenting until you find what works best for you. 
After that, it's all about staying consistent.

Keep going!

#mentalhealth
name: Meri Nova

content:
Lately, I’ve been struggling with depression, even though I have everything I ever dreamed of. 

- I can travel anywhere I want. 
- I have supportive friends and family. 
- I have an amazing platform, which I am extremely grateful for. 

But, I've been feeling completely numb and disconnected for months. 
And it’s not the first time I’ve felt this way. 

I have been battling with depression and anxiety for as long as I remember.

I always thought that if I achieved success, reached milestones, or moved to the “right” place it would make it go away. But it hasn’t.

I’ve realized that mental health isn’t something you can “fix” once and be happy for the rest of your life. It's an ongoing process of facing yourself at your worst and extending genuine compassion. 

I know I’m not alone in this. So many of us carry mental health burdens from childhood into adulthood, and it can feel extremely shameful and isolating.

That is why talking about it is so important! 
It makes us more human.
It makes us be okay with not being okay. 

Today, I want to help lighten your burden and share some tools that truly pulled me through dark times. 
Use them whenever you feel off: 

- Emotional Freedom Technique (EFT) - helps me tremendously in processing my emotions. 
Resource: Brad Yates' Youtube, always makes me feel better.
https://lnkd.in/g9tiQvuA 

- Understanding C-PTSD 
Resource: Heidi Priebe, a brilliant guide to understanding yourself better.
 https://lnkd.in/gzDTCDHz

- Understanding your emotions 
Resource: Therapy in a nutshell, amazing short lectures on EI. 
https://lnkd.in/gzFCs6Qp

- Qi Gong to balance your energy 
Resource: Always brings me back to balance and back on my feet. 
https://lnkd.in/gdWx_QFh

...

Remember your emotional health matters as much as your physical health.
Take care of yourself this week!

...

These are the things that worked for me. 

I am curious to know, what helps you process your emotions? 
Share in the comments, so we can all learn from each other.
name: Meri Nova

content:
I didn’t have a STEM degree. My most advanced degree is BA in business.
I never wrote a single line of code. 
Heck, I didn’t even speak a word of English.   

I grew up in the rural part of Kyrgyzstan with my grandma.
My first job was selling potatoes and onions on a sidewalk at a local bazaar in Bishkek. 

Now, I  help 43k people transition to ML and Data Science daily and run an active data community (Break Into Data). 
Every week, I collaborate with the smartest and the most Influential people in the Data and AI world. 

But it wasn't always like this. 

Only a couple of years ago I was constantly paralyzed by toxic shame and imposter syndrome, unable to make progress in my studies. 

Talking to engineers and scientists from Big Tech made me feel inferior. 
I didn't think I was worthy of their time, let alone asking them any questions. 

This made me feel stuck. 

Until I realized the reason I felt inferior was because I compared my day 1 with their day 1,000! 
So now, the first thing I do when I meet brilliant people, I invite them to collaborate with me. 
And guess what?

80% of the time I hear a Yes! 

This gave me incredible leverage to improve my own skills and my own career!

I no longer second-guess myself.
I might be foolish, but I am always hungry for growth. 
And I let everyone know that. 

This is a reminder, to never let toxic shame and imposter syndrome impact your future. 
You deserve every goal you set to achieve. 
Show up daily and learn rigorously!

And if you need help along the way, follow my page and/or join the Break Into Data community of motivated and like-minded learners!

name: Meri Nova

content:
I never got Master’s degree in Data Science. 
I never worked at Big Tech. 
I never got a 200k salary.

When all of my friends and ex partners were building their tech careers, I was ridiculed for having too many passions and not mastering any. I was told I will never succeed if I won’t follow the same path as they did. 

I believed them. 
So I stayed in toxic relationships. 
I allowed disrespect and abuse. 
I undervalued my own effort in my unique pursuits. 

I endured the suffering thinking I deserved this.
Until I reached an emotional burnout.  

When my mental health hit rock bottom,
I decided to look inward. 
And finally take courage to choose myself. 

To write my own story. 
To follow my own curiosities. 
To chase my own dreams. 

Despite the loud judgmental voices around. 

And here is where I am now: 

- I built an audience of 20k engineers and scientists across all platforms in 3 months. 
- I lead a community of 1000 active learners who are helping each other grow. 
- I deploy and build multiple AI-driven applications, projects daily. 

Don’t let opinions of others get in your head. 
Don’t make yourself small to please the fragile egos around you. 
Don’t underestimate your own achievements, just because you don’t have a random paper that dictates your worth. 

Remember if you don’t choose yourself, no one else will. 

Now, go and make yourself happy and proud. 


P.S. I cried writing this. Hope it will remind you of what is really important. ❤️

You 🫵🏼!

name: Meri Nova

content:
Breaking into ML Engineering can be very confusing in 2024!

Should I learn TensorFlow or PyTorch? Python or R? Scikit-learn or XGBoost? GCP or AWS? FastAPI or Streamlit?

Fundamental principles are more important than tools:

- understanding statistics and deep learning is more important than TensorFlow vs PyTorch.
- understanding functional and object-oriented programming is more important than Python or R.
- understanding feature engineering is more important than Scikit-learn vs XGBoost.
- understanding scalable and resilient architectures is more important than GCP or AWS.
- understanding models serving is more important than FastAPI or Streamlit.


Knowing these will allow you to pick up new emerging tools easily. 

Stick to fundamentals first.

name: Meri Nova

content:
6 signs you are becoming a better Machine Learning engineer: 


1. Math is becoming your friend. 
You are no longer scared of complicated notations and equations. Instead, you screenshot them and use AI to break them down for you. After all, you are an insatiably curious monkey. 

2. You are focusing more on the data. 
Before mastering ML models, you are learning to deal with messy data. 
60-80% of your time goes into data preprocessing and applying new cleaning techniques specific to the data type and algorithms.  

3. You are no longer distracted by shiny new AI models and tools. 
You can distinguish between value and noise. FOMO can't catch you. Instead, you focus on filling your knowledge gaps in fundamentals like statistics, math, and programming. 

4. You know what you don't know. 
You frequently hear many repeating ML terms that you don't yet understand.  Instead of disregarding it, you make notes and get back to them in your free time. 

5. You are working on your soft skills. 
You finally understand that building hard skills is not enough. That is why you make an effort to explain complex things in a simple way to non-technical stakeholders. You know that's where you make the biggest impact in your career. 

6. You are being patient with yourself.
You are no longer rushing to learn everything in 3 months or threatening to quit it altogether. You found your comfortable pace and made learning your daily habit. Just like going to the gym, but instead of strengthening muscles, you're strengthening your brain.


I hope you are proud of your journey! 
Because I, sure am. 

Keep going!

name: Meri Nova

content:
You can’t call yourself a Machine Learning Engineer if you don’t know how to deploy your models. 

And no it is not just about wrapping functions in API endpoints using Flask or BentoML and calling it a day. 

When I ran the ML Coding Challenge Break Into Data, I advised participants to work on smaller problems which meant working on one model. 

However, in reality,  big tech companies have hundreds and thousands of models running in production at any given moment. 

And every single model has its own complex deployment architecture that corresponds to their software and product requirements. 


So here are 4 main deployment strategies you should know: 


1. Batch prediction (Figure 1) - The predictions are generated at defined frequencies and stored in a SQL or in-memory database and retrieved as needed. For example, Amazon might generate top recommended products every 4 hours and they are shown to users when they log in. You can read more about the architecture here - https://lnkd.in/gAbRCvdX 


2. Online prediction (Figure 2) - Rather than wait hours or days for predictions, we can generate predictions as soon as they are needed and serve these to users right away. Online inferencing also allows us to make predictions with recent streaming features, like product or user activity updates made in the last 10 minutes.  You can read more on the differences between online and batch prediction here - https://lnkd.in/ggV7xGaS 


3. Real-time deployment (Figure 3) - It is one of the hardest deployment architectures. It requires that the reaction to requests must be fulfilled within a matter of milliseconds. Consider, stock market predictions, air traffic control use cases, where latency is one of the highest priorities. To handle additional parallel requests from other users, you need to count on multi-threaded processes and vertical scaling by adding additional servers. Learn more here - https://lnkd.in/gQHKyqS6


4. Edge deployment (Figure 4)- It is when the model is directly deployed on the client such as the local machine, a mobile phone or IoT products. This allows offline predictions that result in the fastest inferences. Models need to be lightweight to fit on the smaller hardware pieces. Check out a CV use case here - https://lnkd.in/g8KSxXTG


…

If you want to learn more about Practical ML Engineering, sign up here - merinova.substack.com

name: Meri Nova

content:
When I was 18, I had no idea what degree to pursue. 
When I was 22, I had no idea what job to chase. 
When I was 24, I had no idea what to do with my life.  

But I knew one thing and one thing only. 
I needed to learn, to fail, and find out. 

That is why,

At 18, I left my family and crossed the Atlantic ocean to study. 
At 22, I started a few businesses that miserably failed. 
At 25, I started taking online classes for data science despite 0 tech skills.  

I didn't know what to expect, but I kept learning, building my portfolio and networking. And in that same year, I got my first technical job at a startup, where I worked with robotics and computer vision. 

At that point, I realized machine learning would become my lifelong passion.

Now I am 28. 
And my mission is to pay it forward for those who are unsure about their future, just like I was not long ago.  

You may not see it now, but...
Every hour you spend building technical skills will add up and result in a compounding effect.
And you will see the surprising results with your new superpowers in one year, if not sooner. 

Trust in yourself, even before the world sees it. 
You're exactly where you need to be and keep going!

name: Meri Nova

content:
15 timeless concepts every ML engineer should know:

- data formats (JSON, row-major vs column-major)
- data models (relational, NoSQL, structured vs unstructured)
- class imbalance
- log transformation
- discrete and continuous embeddings 
- L1 and L2 regularization
- precision, recall, F1-score, and ROC-AUC
- grid search and random search
- data drift vs model drift 
- model and data versioning
- dataflow (REST API, pubsub, message queue)
- batch prediction vs online prediction 
- distributed training 
- pruning, quantization, low-rank factorization
- containerization and orchestration

name: Meri Nova

content:
Nothing reveals the current state of ML landscape better than machine learning competitions do. 

I came across the most comprehensive report on "The State of Competitive Machine Learning in 2023" with countless insights into the best architectures for each domain, including NLP, CV, Computer Vision, and more.


Here are 6 of them that stood out the most for me: 


1. Python remains the most popular programming language among winners, with 63 out of 65 winning solutions primarily or exclusively using Python.

2. PyTorch remains by far the most popular deep learning library, in a two-horse race — out of 53 solutions using deep learning, 47 primarily used PyTorch, 4 used TensorFlow, and 2 used both PyTorch and TensorFlow.

3. The most popular models for computer vision remain both CNNs (convolutional neural networks) and Transformers. With the most popular being  ConvNeXt and U-Net (CNN) architectures. 

4. Winners of the most notable LLM competition at Kaggle used an ensemble of five 7B-parameter LLMs and one 13B-parameter LLM, which they fine-tuned, alongside Retrieval-Augmented Generation on a chunked local version of Wikipedia. 

5. Over 70% of winners used a GPU to train their model, and many of these used powerful data-center GPUs rather than cheaper consumer-oriented ones.

6. Polars, the dataframe library written in Rust, is starting to see adoption among competition winners, with its improved performance compared to Pandas.


P.S. Check out the comment section to find the link to the report.

Read 12 pages from AI research paper. 

Go for a quick 3-mile run and listen to Lex Fridman’s podcast. Shower. 

Plan my upcoming week in 20 min. 

- Write content for Linkedin

Every afternoon I call my mom at 4.30 pm. 

Then gym.
Shower again. 

I make a super healthy dinner. 
Read another technical article for 60 min before sleep. 
Meditate and dose off at 8.45 pm. 

Excellent day. 


…


Which is completely made up. 

Every time you read something like this, you feel behind. 

And it makes sense. The rate of technological advancement has never been this high. 

Just look at the news, every week we have:

🧨 New open-source models released.
🧨 New research papers published.
🧨 New AI tools changing the world. 

I get it . It is overwhelming. 

ESPECIALLY, when you are trying to break into the field. 

But guess what. 

The only thing you can control is your own 𝐚𝐭𝐭𝐞𝐧𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧. 
 
You need to shut the AI noise.
And start making consistent incremental progress towards your own goals.

Remember, learning is a life-long marathon. 
Don’t let the FOMO anxiety paralyze you.

The faster you figure this out. 
The bigger, better, and stronger your foundation will become. 

So…

- Sleep 8 hours. 
- Get enough sunshine. 
- Focus on fundamentals. 
- Enjoy the process. 
- And apply your skills consistently. 


With this in mind, I hope you have less stress and more kindness towards yourself this week. 

Love you.

This is how I would learn AI engineering in 2024. (AI agents edition): 



- Start with a goal. Let's say its a health goal, like keeping your mom updated on your daily wellness.

- Use a fitness tracker (e.g., Whoop, Fitbit) to collect data on steps, sleep, and heart rate. Get the data in a CSV.

- Connect OpenAI API to analyze your data and turn it into a short, meaningful message that sounds like you. 

- Add APIs like Whatsapp to send automated messages.

- Deploy on Hugging Face or set up a FastAPI server on GCP as an extra challenge.

- Schedule your script with a daily CRON job to send updates every morning.

- Improve the messages based on feedback to make them more personal and insightful over time.


...


Your imagination is your only limitation.

content:
My 5 biggest takeaways from yesterday's hottest AI  Conference in SF in under 5 minutes. 


⏩ RAG is the future. 80% Of yesterday's talks were focused on building the best-performing retrieval architecture for private databases. Chip Huyen proposes to start with simple retrieval techniques like BM25 and leaving fine-tuning as a last resort, due to its high maintenance requirements and dependence on foundational models. (Picture 2)

⏩ Data Quality is everything. Chad Sanderson introduces the importance of Data Contracts at SLA level and urges us to leverage them to ensure Data Quality across teams. LLamaIndex CEO, Jerry Liu shared the same sentiment and reminded us to avoid Garbage in Garbage out situation as much as possible. (Picture 3)

⏩ Graphs + RAGs = A promising marriage. Graphs capture semantic and hierarchical relationships across your datasets, significantly lowering the hallucinations for complex queries. In particular, Daniel Svonava's talk on controlling RAG results and his recent Knowledge Graph and RAG architecture caught my eye. Check it out here  - https://lnkd.in/ggpj9Qex
 
⏩ Everyone wants Data Scientists to be friends with DEs and MLEs. Catherine Nelson wrote an entire book on equipping Data Scientists with the engineering fundamental skills for that specific reason. (See last slide) We all want Data scientists to move away from notebooks. 

⏩ Overall, 2024 is a year of LLMs in production. As Eugene Yan says in his famous article 𝐖𝐡𝐚𝐭 𝐰𝐞 𝐡𝐚𝐯𝐞 𝐥𝐞𝐚𝐫𝐧𝐞𝐝 𝐟𝐫𝐨𝐦 𝐚 𝐲𝐞𝐚𝐫 𝐨𝐟 𝐛𝐮𝐢𝐥𝐝𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐰𝐢𝐭𝐡 𝐋𝐋𝐌𝐬: "It is time to move away from 0 to 1 and get to N from 1". And I couldn't agree more. We had enough time to play around with prototyping. Whatever makes the foundational models hallucinate less will become extremely valuable. Enforcing AI Guardrails, Schema prompting, and Introducing new Evaluation frameworks will accelerate LLM adoption in 2024. 


It is time to make the VC firms happy and focus on the ROI and PMF, so we won't end up with mass layoffs all over again. 




Other honorable mentions: 

Kirk Marple - Great talk on Graphs and RAGs .
Rick Lamers - Amazing technical slides on tool use and function calling with LLMs 
Joe Reis 🤓 - Data Engineering expert. 
Demetrios Brinkmann - Founder of MLOps community.  
Sonam G. - Podcast Host and Community builder


Had an amazing time and met many interesting speakers who will talk at Break Into Data very soon!

name: Meri Nova

content:
AI Engineering has fundamentally transformed from traditional ML Engineering, and here's what matters now:

- foundation model adaptation 
Understanding prompt engineering, fine-tuning, RAG, and Agents is critical now, rather than building models from scratch. 

- infrastructure optimization 
Whether you're working with cloud AI solutions like AWS Sagemaker, and Vertex AI, or inference optimization tools like vLLM, understanding how to efficiently deploy and scale large language models is crucial.

- evaluation frameworks 
With open-ended outputs from LLMs, traditional ML metrics aren't enough. Knowledge of evaluation techniques for generative AI, including human feedback systems and automated evaluation frameworks, is becoming increasingly important.

- cost optimization 
Managing inference and fine-tuning costs for large models with exponentially increasing API calls, while maintaining performance is the next big in-demand skill. 


The future of AI engineering isn't about building models from scratch anymore, it's about:
 
- getting first to market 
- solving real problems and finding PMF asap
- improving and innovating on the UX 
- effectively adapting, deploying,  
- and evaluating AI systems at scale!


The game has changed for 2025. 

It's time to build like a maniac.

name: Meri Nova

content:
Why do most startups prefer GraphRAG over RAG? 

Although RAG architectures are powerful on their own, they have painful limitations that need to be addressed: 

- they lack structure: Document embedding captures semantic meaning but struggles to capture themes and relationships across the entire document corpus, which lowers retrieval quality. 
- challenges with scalability: As the database volume grows, the retrieval process becomes less efficient, as the computational load increases with the search space.
- data challenges: Traditional RAG systems don't easily accommodate diverse data, which are harder to embed. (think PDFs, Flat files, HTML, CSVs, Web content, etc)

We can address those issues with GraphRAG. 

Graphs are the best at representing and storing diverse and interconnected information in a structured manner. 

The most exciting part is that these days you don't even have to populate the graph yourself!  An LLM can parse and categorize entities and their relationships, inferring all from the database itself.

If you want to learn more about how I built a GraphRAG with Wikipedia articles, check out my “RAG with Langchain” course on DataCamp. 

You can take the first chapter for free or sign up during their Black Friday 50% off promo. 

Here is the link: https://lnkd.in/gnGXMkTe
name: Meri Nova

content:
It is surprising how many data scientists fail to verify if linear regression is suitable for their use case. Before applying this simple and common model, you must validate the following assumptions... 


1. Linearity. 🛣 

𝐀𝐧𝐚𝐥𝐨𝐠𝐲: Think of a car driving at a constant speed. If the speed is steady, the distance traveled increases proportionally with time.

𝐄𝐱𝐩𝐥𝐚𝐧𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧: The relationship between predictors (independent variables) and the response (dependent variable) is like that of speed and distance traveled. It is proportional. 


2. Independence. ⚡ 

𝐀𝐧𝐚𝐥𝐨𝐠𝐲: Think of students taking an exam in separate rooms without any communication. Each student's score is independent of the others.

𝐄𝐱𝐩𝐥𝐚𝐧𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧: Residuals (errors) should be like those students – one residual shouldn’t affect another. 


3. Homoscedasticity vs Heteroscedasticity. 👩‍🏫 

𝐀𝐧𝐚𝐥𝐨𝐠𝐲: Imagine you are trying to measure how well a group of students perform on different levels of difficulty of questions in a test. 

𝐇𝐨𝐦𝐨𝐬𝐜𝐞𝐝𝐚𝐬𝐭𝐢𝐜𝐢𝐭𝐲: If the spread of scores (how much the scores vary) is about the same for easy, medium, and hard questions, it means you have homoscedasticity. 

𝐇𝐞𝐭𝐞𝐫𝐨𝐬𝐜𝐞𝐝𝐚𝐬𝐭𝐢𝐜𝐢𝐭𝐲: If the spread of scores is different for different question difficulties (e.g., for easy questions, scores vary from 70 to 90, but for hard questions, scores vary from 50 to 90), it means you have heteroscedasticity. And you do not want that. 


4. Normality of Residuals (Multivariate Normality):  🔔 

𝐀𝐧𝐚𝐥𝐨𝐠𝐲: Think of rolling a fair dice many times. The distribution of outcomes (residuals) should look like a bell curve (normal distribution) over a large number of rolls.

𝐄𝐱𝐩𝐥𝐚𝐧𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧: The residuals in your model should follow a normal distribution. 


5. No Multicollinearity: ‼ 

𝐀𝐧𝐚𝐥𝐨𝐠𝐲: Imagine trying to understand the effect of both age and experience on salary. It’s hard to tell which one really impacts salary because they move together.

𝐄𝐱𝐩𝐥𝐚𝐧𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧: Independent variables should not be highly correlated with each other.


6. Measurement Error. 👻 

𝐀𝐧𝐚𝐥𝐨𝐠𝐲: Imagine trying to weigh fruits on a scale that occasionally gives wrong readings. 

𝐄𝐱𝐩𝐥𝐚𝐧𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧: Measurement errors can lead to unreliable predictions in your model.

If you find these helpful...

So more people can learn.

name: Meri Nova

content:
When the creator of Pandas, Wes McKinney, was asked to give advice for Data Scientists, he had a shocking response: " Learn SQL 🤯

I didn't believe what I heard. The creator of one of the largest Python libraries with 60 million downloads every month, tells everyone to learn SQL!
 
I chuckled but was intrigued to hear his explanation. 

Here is what he said: 

" Well, some people on the Discord are going to laugh because I'm going to say that learning SQL is actually a really good skill. It's not just learning SQL the language, but learning the concepts of relational algebra and how to think about data sets, designing schemas, and organizing data."

...

"It is about learning the file formatting and the basics of data storage, data partitioning, and the relationship between the execution engines. All of these things will yield you to be a better DBT user, a better Snowflake user or a Databricks user.

...

"Ultimately, it might seem like the wizard behind the curtain, but I think a lot of these systems have very similar architectures and properties. This will help you understand how these systems work and how to use them effectively."

...

I loved the advice and we have a lot to learn from him. 
Why? Because of his impressive contributions and his background: 👇


Wes McKinney is a notable figure in the open-source community!

- He dropped out of college to develop the Pandas library.

- He co-founded the Apache Arrow project, a cross-language development platform for in-memory data.

- He developed the Ibis project, which provides a more efficient way to bridge SQL and Python for data analysis. 

- He published O'Reily book - "Python for Data Analysis," a widely-used reference book for learning Pandas. 

...

If you haven't heard about him or his work yet, I highly encourage you to register for tomorrow’s Live session!
Where you can ask questions and learn from his journey. 


Register here 👇

https://lu.ma/i80kh30z

content:
This year has been the most transformational year of my life. 

January: I hit rock bottom - a toxic partnership left me shattered.
February: I channeled my pain into purpose. I stopped chasing validation and found clarity.
March: Started taking LinkedIn more seriously and got to 20k followers. 
April: I realized I always wanted to work for myself. 
May: Launched the 30-day ML challenge and inspired 120+ members to take action.
June: My community grew to 3k members, and they started landing real jobs - proof we were onto something.
July: Landed my instructor contract with DataCamp. 
July: Celebrated my first wins: rapid audience growth(15k a month), and brand deals. 
August: Recorded my first-ever AI engineering course with James Chapman.
September: Visited home in Kyrgyzstan to see family. Reconnected with 100s of relatives who gave me so much strength to move boldly through life. 
October: Traveled to Bali and met wonderful people; Daliana Liu, Grace Ling 🐰 and Anton Cherkasov. 
November: Launched Break Into Data PRO community on Circle and getting first paying users!


This year, I let go of many people, but I also found those who truly understand and support me.

Life gets better when you start appreciating your own journey more than anyone else's.
