content:
This is Aizada and Assel. 
They raised 6-figures in the last 4 months for their AI Legal Startup. 
Here is what it’s like to be First-Time Female Founders…


Both came from developing countries: Kyrgyzstan and Kazakhstan.
Where median salary of a Data Analyst is $400 a month. 
Both are self-starters, who got into Ivy League schools with their perseverance and grit. 


However, their background gets even more impressive. 


Aizada Marat was the first person to ever start a crowdfunding campaign back in Kyrgyzstan. 
She made a video that reached millions of viewers. 
Where she tells the public that she gets admitted to Harvard Law School. 

And…

That she needs $80,000 for tuition. 

Otherwise.. 

She would miss out on this - once in a life-time opportunity!

People had varying reactions...

Many said that she was selfish and should build a family instead. 

But thankfully, multiple entrepreneurs and people from government, gladly supported and pitched in. 

So she was able to attend and graduate! 


I was impressed to say the least, by her perseverance, confidence and courage. 
I looked up to her, just like many other young girls did. 
Even-though, she became extremely well-known in the intellectual circle of Bishkek,
She still agreed to meet me at a coffee shop and helped me guide my journey.


This was 9 years ago. 


Fast forward to our talk yesterday. 

After graduating Harvard and working 80 hours a week both for McKinsey & Company  and Cooley LLP. 
She decided to take a bet on herself once again and dream big. 
So she launched her first AI Legaltech Startup with her co-founder. 

Assel Tuleubayeva, who is equally impressive. 

A Harvard Business School alumna, who has been carving her path in the male-dominated business world for years as well. 


Listening to their story gave me permission to be bold and continue making big strides in my own career. 


You must know this..


Women like them, stand out in cultures, where females are condemned for choosing their careers over family. 

Aizada and Assel are redefining this narrative.

Ambition and success in the tech world are not confined by traditional roles!

Neither should you. 

Be yourself. 

Write your own story. 



♻️Share this with anyone who isn't afraid to dream big. 

 

P.S. They are hiring their first ML engineer! Make sure to reach out. 


#startup #femalefounders #dataanalytics #ai
name: Meri Nova

content:
What is a Data Pipeline and how to build one?

𝐅𝐢𝐫𝐬𝐭 𝐔𝐧𝐝𝐞𝐫𝐬𝐭𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐄𝐓𝐋 𝐁𝐚𝐬𝐢𝐜𝐬:
𝘌𝘹𝘵𝘳𝘢𝘤𝘵: Get data from sources like data lake or file storage.
𝘛𝘳𝘢𝘯𝘴𝘧𝘰𝘳𝘮: Apply changes or filters to clean and organize the data.
𝘓𝘰𝘢𝘥: Save the processed data to a place where it can be used, like a database.

𝐂𝐡𝐨𝐨𝐬𝐞 𝐁𝐚𝐭𝐜𝐡 𝐨𝐫 𝐑𝐞𝐚𝐥-𝐓𝐢𝐦𝐞 𝐏𝐫𝐨𝐜𝐞𝐬𝐬𝐢𝐧𝐠:
Decide if you need to process data in batches (at intervals) or in real-time (as it comes in).

𝐈𝐝𝐞𝐧𝐭𝐢𝐟𝐲 𝐃𝐚𝐭𝐚 𝐒𝐨𝐮𝐫𝐜𝐞𝐬:
Find out where your data is coming from. It could be databases, file storage systems like AWS S3 or HDFS, or other sources.

𝐊𝐧𝐨𝐰 𝐘𝐨𝐮𝐫 𝐃𝐚𝐭𝐚 𝐅𝐨𝐫𝐦𝐚𝐭:
Understand the format of your incoming data. Is it in JSON (flexible structure), CSV (rows and columns), or another format?

𝐄𝐱𝐩𝐥𝐨𝐫𝐞 𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐃𝐞𝐟𝐢𝐧𝐞 𝐃𝐚𝐭𝐚 𝐒𝐜𝐡𝐞𝐦𝐚:
Look at your data to understand its structure and types. This helps in reading and processing it correctly.

𝐒𝐞𝐥𝐞𝐜𝐭 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐑𝐢𝐠𝐡𝐭 𝐓𝐨𝐨𝐥𝐬 𝐟𝐨𝐫 𝐓𝐫𝐚𝐧𝐬𝐟𝐨𝐫𝐦𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧:
Choose a processing framework like Apache Spark for batch processing or Apache Flink for real-time processing.

𝐃𝐞𝐜𝐢𝐝𝐞 𝐖𝐡𝐞𝐫𝐞 𝐭𝐨 𝐋𝐨𝐚𝐝 𝐏𝐫𝐨𝐜𝐞𝐬𝐬𝐞𝐝 𝐃𝐚𝐭𝐚:
Choose a destination for your processed data. It could be a database, a data warehouse, or a file storage system.

𝐂𝐨𝐧𝐬𝐢𝐝𝐞𝐫 𝐔𝐬𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐚 𝐒𝐜𝐡𝐞𝐝𝐮𝐥𝐞𝐫 (𝐎𝐩𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧𝐚𝐥):
If you need to run your data pipeline at specific times, use a tool like Apache Airflow to schedule and automate this process.

𝐀𝐠𝐠𝐫𝐞𝐠𝐚𝐭𝐞 𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐀𝐧𝐚𝐥𝐲𝐳𝐞 𝐃𝐚𝐭𝐚:
After processing, save your data in an organized way, like in folders sorted by date. Use tools like Hive to create tables from this data for analysis.

𝐏𝐫𝐚𝐜𝐭𝐢𝐜𝐚𝐥 𝐈𝐦𝐩𝐥𝐞𝐦𝐞𝐧𝐭𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧:
For a hands-on example: set up a system to process daily data. Use Hadoop for storage, Spark for processing, and Airflow for scheduling.
Transform the data according to your business needs and load it into a system for further analysis or reporting.

𝐂𝐫𝐞𝐚𝐭𝐞 𝐀𝐜𝐜𝐞𝐬𝐬 𝐏𝐨𝐢𝐧𝐭𝐬 𝐟𝐨𝐫 𝐀𝐧𝐚𝐥𝐲𝐬𝐢𝐬:
Set up external tables (using Hive, for example) to easily access and analyze the processed data.


Remember, the key to building an effective data pipeline is understanding your data and selecting the right tools and processes to handle it efficiently. 


#dataanalytics #datapipelines
name: Meri Nova

content:
Everyone says you can transition to Data Science from any background. But nobody says how?

Tomorrow we will have Nirmal Budhathoki as a guest speaker at Break Into Data. 

He will share what worked for him during his unique Career Transition journey. 

- He was born and raised in a small town in Nepal
- Moved to the USA for graduate school in 2007.
- Graduated during the Great Recession, but couldn't find a job. 
- So he joined the US Army instead. 
- The military was tough and many times he felt like giving up and leaving back home. 

But this is my favorite part of his story: 

"In early 2014- I had to make a tough decision: whether to continue in military or transition out. I had no job lined up, and my wife was still unemployed. My mind said - renew the military contract, but my heart said- take a risk to find a job that fits your goal. I asked my wife for advice, and she suggested me: Go with your heart, we will manage it. She has always been my mentor." 

Following that pivotal moment, he was able to secure a job as a Data Analyst with the US Navy within a month of leaving the military. Later on, he landed his first job as a Data Scientist with Wells Fargo in 2019.

And the rest is history. 

If you are thinking of transitioning towards Data Science, but don't know where to begin, join us at Break Into Data's Discord Server with Nirmal Budhathoki and ask him how he did it!

The event will take place at 12 PM Pacific time tomorrow June 21st, 2024. 

Register here to get the invite link - https://lnkd.in/gAbw54E7
name: Meri Nova

content:
AI engineering is no different than software engineering, except for "a few" painful nuances:


- instead of unit tests with exact matches, you use evaluation sets with thresholds.

- instead of clear API contracts, you get "close enough" inputs/outputs.

- instead of only debugging through logs, you now navigate through prompt chains and model versions.

- instead of only focusing on latency & throughput, you now optimize for faithfulness, accuracy, and 100+ more metrics. 

- instead of explicit state management, you deal with implicit, emergent states.(across memory, context windows, and tools)


In 2024, we're no longer simply writing code, we're learning to work with compounding uncertainty.


#AIengineering
name: Meri Nova

content:
The worst and most popular way to break into data:

1.  binge-watch 284 random online courses on ML, AI, and LLMs without a clear goal.
2. spiral into self-doubt after a few rejections and consider giving up and switching fields.
3.  ignore networking because you think your resume alone will get you hired
4.  continue to chase shiny new tools instead of learning engineering fundamentals
5.  Ignore your interests to follow the crowd, and end up with a portfolio that screams "template" rather than "talent."
6. blindly apply to every job that starts with "data"
7. overload your resume with buzzwords like Hadoop, Big Data, and Microsoft Paint, despite never using them.  
8. stress on landing a job in 6 months or never try again. 
9. blame everything else instead of reflecting on your strategy. 


The best way to break into data :

1.  identify the specific areas of data science that genuinely interest you, like Computer Vision, NLP,  RecSys, or Forecasting. 
2.  network like your career depends on it - because it does. (attend meetups, join communities, make more data friends)
3.  reach out to real professionals, not just instructors, and learn what skills truly matter on the job
4.  build projects that solve real-world problems that you are genuinely passionate about. 
5.  find a mentor whom you aspire to be, as soon as possible (it can be life-changing)
6.  document your learning journey and share them on Linkedin (it costs $0).
7.  stay consistent and disciplined with your learning schedule. (join an accountability group) 
8.  apply your skills through freelancing, internships, or by contributing to open-source early on. 
9.  be patient and persistent, breaking into data takes time and effort.


Remember, 
Consistency beats intensity. 

So take time to breathe and enjoy the learning process. 


#breakintodata #datascience #ml
name: Meri Nova

content:
Stop rewriting your resume to every single Data Science position. 
Here is the strategy you are going to want to implement instead. 

During the last event at Break Into Data, the guest speaker, Karun Thankachan, who is a Senior Data Scientist at Walmart, brought an unusual perspective that made me rethink my job search approach. 

Majority of us would spend countless hours customizing our resume to every open DS position, hoping for callbacks. 

It turns out it was a wrong strategy altogether! 

Instead, Karun suggests all aspiring Data Scientists to have 3 core resumes.

Here is how. 

Every DS position has its main focus area. You need to identify at least 2-3 areas from your technical expertise within Data Science. Either from your previous job or personal projects. 

It can be: 

⭐️ Forecasting 
⭐️ Recommended systems 
⭐️ Computer vision 
⭐️ Etc…

Based on those, build your main 3 resumes that focus on each methodology with in-depth bulletin points and metrics. 

So next time you will apply for a DS role you will pick one of the 3 instead of creating one from scratch. 

This will keep you focused and show potential employers that you are indeed knowledgeable in your focus area. 

If you want to watch the entire episode with Karun. 
Subscribe to our YouTube channel and turn on the notifications 👇 

https://lnkd.in/gNCY3SDi

Because true #leadership isn’t measured by titles  - it’s measured by the lives you've changed forever.
name: Meri Nova

content:
If you are a machine learning engineer who's feeling discouraged because you think that your technical skills aren't as good as your peers, remember that there is so much more to it than shipping models. 

This isn't some comforting advice to make you feel better. Truly, successfully deploying and maintaining ml systems requires all types of ml engineers and not just coding geniuses. 

- Those who can estimate project requirements accurately and plan the deliverables in the right order  
- Those who can break down complex technical limitations to non-technical stakeholders
- Those who can build great teams and keep everyone on the same page  
- Those who can mentor and guide other engineers
- Those who can find creative and effective solutions to problems 

The most successful machine learning projects are built by teams with a rich mix of talents, working together towards a common goal. 
So, take pride in your role and know that you’re an essential part of the bigger picture. 

#machinelearning #breakintodata
name: Meri Nova

content:
I am noticing a pattern among tech/data content creators that is terribly misleading and demotivating to many. 

Here is how it goes: 

- Get a job in Big Tech.
- Hit 100k followers.
- Publish a book with O’Reily.
- Start a Youtube channel and have each other as guests.
- Quit a 6-figure job and write a viral post about it.
- Create a Bootcamp or Course and call it a day.

For many of you, this might create an illusion that it is the only way to start building a massive LinkedIn presence. 

But!

You do not have to follow that beaten path and I am the proof of that. 
I grew my account to 32k followers in 6 months on my own terms. 

Don't let the majority's voice overpower your own. 

- You do not have to work in FAANG to be a creator.  
- You do not have to make 6 figures to share valuable content online.
- You do not even have to share photos if you do not want to. 

All you need is - BE YOURSELF!

Share what you find interesting, 
Share what helped you overcome any personal or professional challenge...

People want to hear your story. 

Everyone! And I repeat everyone has an inspiring story to tell. 

It is time to write your own.


....


P.S.  Tag me and #breakintodata on your post this week and I will engage to help you get started! 

Love you, now let's go! 



#contentcreator
name: Meri Nova

content:
The next big wave of AI innovation won't come from better models. 
It will come from better UX. 

You do not need to be a Deep Learning Expert to build unique AI applications. 
You need to experiment, build prototypes, fail fast, and fail forward. 

Think about it...

The last AI headlines were made by: 

- Claude's artifacts. 
- Google's NotebookLM. 
- ChatGPT's newest Canvas feature. (check it out if you haven't already)

All of them are variations of better user experience with pre-existing models. 

The fact of the matter is that we are still searching for better ways to integrate LLMs into our everyday lives. 

And guess what?

There is still a LOT of unchartered territory.
name: Meri Nova

content:
I did 30 days of SQL leetcode every day. 
Here is what I learned: 


- Leetcode doesn’t resemble real life

- It provides the problem and solution for your queries 

- It helps you understand the basic rules and syntax of SQL 

- It requires identically formatted output and instructions are not always clear 



What is it good for? 

- Practicing and learning various use cases of CTEs and Joins. 


What should you focus on, if you want to get a job? 

- Besides nailing SQL basics, working on a personal Data project will give a more in-depth perspective of real life problems. 

I will be focusing more on that in the coming weeks myself. 


—- 


What is your learning strategy?

name: Meri Nova

content:
Top 5 reasons why Machine Learning is the best profession in data:

1. Job security.
While companies like Microsoft, Amazon, and Google laid off over 240,000 tech workers in 2023, the demand for ML professionals remained robust. This is largely due to the ongoing innovation in AI and ML.

2. Higher demand = Higher pay:
ML engineers make 15-20% higher salaries than other data roles, with staff MLe's at Google earning $600,000+. Deep learning specialists make even more.

3. Diverse opportunities.
Over 80% of the entire industry including healthcare, finance, entertainment, and supply chain desperately need ML talent to leverage their data and cloud resources and build revenue-driving algorithms.

4. New engineering frontiers.
The rise of LLMs and GenAI created a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity. But it comes with new non-deterministic challenges. Those who can make models more reliable and deterministic will become invaluable.

5. Higher Ceiling for Growth.
It is impossible to hit the learning plateau in ML. Weekly breakthroughs in research, models, and startups keep the field exciting. It is one of the most dynamic and rewarding fields in data.


Why do you choose machine learning?

#machinelearning #ai
name: Meri Nova

content:
How Akanksha Paliwal got interview callbacks from Amazon, Square, Walmart & more, and landed a dream Data Science job in 6 months? 

Yesterday, we invited her to speak at Break Into Data to share her job search strategy and learn from her mistakes. 

Here is what she’s changed to finally start landing interviews: 

1. CV: She stopped tailoring her resume for each job opening. Instead, she created only 2 for Data Science and Data Analytics. On top of that she reached out to at least 10 highly experienced professionals, for feedback on her resume. This paid off immensely and she finally started getting callbacks. 

2. Change of environment: Prior to the job search her circle was made of computer science graduates, but she didn’t know anyone who worked as a data scientist. This was not helping her job search. So she started making friends with data professionals through forums and data communities.  

3. Cold Outreach with Emails: Instead of random LinkedIn DMs, she focused on finding emails of hiring managers and sent out highly customized and relevant inquiries, explaining how she could be a great fit for the role. 

4. Selective Projects: Instead of putting small Kaggle projects on her resume, she became a lot more strategic with her time. And chose to work on a real-world project from a startup that challenged her and aligned with her career goals in data science. 

5. Applying: Her daily goal was to apply to 10-15 positions through Linkedin and Company websites and track it on Excel. She also automated her cold outreach with one email template that contained her background details. This way she focused more on finding relevant positions rather than crafting a unique message each time. 


If you want to learn more than watch the entire episode on Youtube, find the link in the comments. 

#datascience #jobsearch
name: Meri Nova

content:
AI didn’t get here by chance. Historically, each key research paper fixed what the last one couldn’t. 

These were the 6 papers that shaped the history of LLMs and Transformers. Read the summary to understand key problems they solved : 


2003 – Bengio et al., 𝘈 𝘕𝘦𝘶𝘳𝘢𝘭 𝘗𝘳𝘰𝘣𝘢𝘣𝘪𝘭𝘪𝘴𝘵𝘪𝘤 𝘓𝘢𝘯𝘨𝘶𝘢𝘨𝘦 𝘔𝘰𝘥𝘦𝘭 (12,600 citations)
Summary: "Laid the foundation for neural networks in language modeling, but could only predict a single word from a fixed input."
Link: https://lnkd.in/gi5bszmb

2014 – Sutskever et al., 𝘚𝘦𝘲𝘶𝘦𝘯𝘤𝘦 𝘵𝘰 𝘚𝘦𝘲𝘶𝘦𝘯𝘤𝘦 𝘓𝘦𝘢𝘳𝘯𝘪𝘯𝘨 𝘸𝘪𝘵𝘩 𝘕𝘦𝘶𝘳𝘢𝘭 𝘕𝘦𝘵𝘸𝘰𝘳𝘬𝘴 (35,350 citations)
Summary: "Enabled machine translation with encoder-decoder LSTMs. But still faced the 'encoder bottleneck,' fitting entire sentences into one vector."
Link: https://lnkd.in/gQ23JM2H

2014 – Bahdanau et al., 𝘕𝘦𝘶𝘳𝘢𝘭 𝘔𝘢𝘤𝘩𝘪𝘯𝘦 𝘛𝘳𝘢𝘯𝘴𝘭𝘢𝘵𝘪𝘰𝘯 (20,390 citations)
Summary: "Solved the encoder bottleneck by introducing the attention mechanism, allowing the model to focus on relevant parts of the input."
Link: https://lnkd.in/gMEZP6m6

2017 – Vaswani et al., 𝘈𝘵𝘵𝘦𝘯𝘵𝘪𝘰𝘯 𝘪𝘴 𝘈𝘭𝘭 𝘠𝘰𝘶 𝘕𝘦𝘦𝘥 (77,250 citations)
Summary: "Took it further by removing RNNs entirely, showing that self-attention alone could outperform all previous models."
Link: https://lnkd.in/gf7PjVPg

2020 – Brown et al., 𝘓𝘢𝘯𝘨𝘶𝘢𝘨𝘦 𝘔𝘰𝘥𝘦𝘭𝘴 𝘢𝘳𝘦 𝘍𝘦𝘸-𝘚𝘩𝘰𝘵 𝘓𝘦𝘢𝘳𝘯𝘦𝘳𝘴 (𝘎𝘗𝘛-3) (8,800 citations)
Summary: "Scaled transformers to billions of parameters, enabling few-shot learning, but faced challenges with generating human-like responses consistently."
Link: https://lnkd.in/g4cABNVD

2021 – Ramesh et al., 𝘋𝘈𝘓𝘓·𝘌: 𝘊𝘳𝘦𝘢𝘵𝘪𝘯𝘨 𝘐𝘮𝘢𝘨𝘦𝘴 𝘧𝘳𝘰𝘮 𝘛𝘦𝘹𝘵 𝘋𝘦𝘴𝘤𝘳𝘪𝘱𝘵𝘪𝘰𝘯𝘴 (1,590 citations)
Summary: "Pushed boundaries by using transformers to generate images from text, addressing multimodal applications but still constrained by limited context length."
Link: https://lnkd.in/gD4n886f

...

For now, transformers are stealing the show in AI. 

But who knows, maybe right now another Sutskever or Bahdanau is building a new algorithm that will bring us closer to AGI.

What do you think is next in AI?
name: Meri Nova

content:
Don’t know what role to pick in tech? 

Here is a guide for you with a touch of humor… 👇



Before starting a job search you need to understand your options thoroughly. 
The following will illustrate the functions and frustrations of each role with a touch of satire. 
Enjoy 🌶



➡️ If your idea of a fun weekend is arguing with a machine in a language only 2 % of the population understands, congratulations, you're ✨ 𝐚 𝐒𝐨𝐟𝐭𝐰𝐚𝐫𝐞 𝐄𝐧𝐠𝐢𝐧𝐞𝐞𝐫✨. You'll spend more time debugging code than sleeping, but hey, that's just more time to admire your beautiful error messages. 

➡️ Love telling engineers what to do without doing the coding yourself? Dream of making grand plans that change with every client meeting? You might like being ✨𝐚 𝐏𝐫𝐨𝐝𝐮𝐜𝐭 𝐌𝐚𝐧𝐚𝐠𝐞𝐫.✨ 

➡️If you find joy in turning a mountain of data into an insightful line graph that upper management will ignore, then ✨𝐚 𝐃𝐚𝐭𝐚 𝐀𝐧𝐚𝐥𝐲𝐬𝐭 ✨might be your calling. You're the corporate equivalent of a fortune teller, but with spreadsheets instead of a crystal ball.

➡️ Want to build the next algorithm that decides which ads haunt people on the internet? As ✨𝐚 𝐌𝐚𝐜𝐡𝐢𝐧𝐞 𝐋𝐞𝐚𝐫𝐧𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐄𝐧𝐠𝐢𝐧𝐞𝐞𝐫✨ , you’ll play with more data than you can imagine and occasionally worry about the ethical implications at 3 AM.

➡️ If you love the idea of spending hours refining models that might just end up predicting that people buy more umbrellas when it rains, ✨𝐚 𝐃𝐚𝐭𝐚 𝐒𝐜𝐢𝐞𝐧𝐭𝐢𝐬𝐭✨ role is for you. It's like being a detective, but instead of solving crimes, you’re figuring out why sales drop every Tuesday.

➡️If you like doing all of the above and more. Then this special position might be for you. A modern-day superhero, juggling finance, marketing, product development, and your sanity all at once? ✨𝐀𝐬 𝐚𝐧 𝐄𝐧𝐭𝐫𝐞𝐩𝐫𝐞𝐧𝐞𝐮𝐫✨, you’ll have the unique opportunity to work 100-hour weeks for yourself instead of 40 hours for someone else, all while reading more self-help books than you ever thought possible. 


Pick your role wisely. 

Happy hunting!

name: Meri Nova

content:
Stop rewriting your resume for every single ML or AI position. 
Instead, pick 1 or 2 areas of expertise and build a solid portfolio. 

Unfortunately, most people waste countless hours customizing their resumes to fit every ML opening, hoping for callbacks. 

When in fact, it is a completely wrong strategy! 

Every ML position has its main focus area. You need to identify your 1 - 3 areas of technical expertise. 

It can be: 

⭐️ NLP and LLMs 
⭐️ Recommended systems 
⭐️ Computer vision 
⭐️ Reinforcement Learning
⭐️ Etc…

Based on those, build your main 2-3 resumes with portfolio projects that focus on each methodology. 

So next time you will apply for a job you will pick one of the 3 instead of creating one from scratch. 

This will keep you focused and show potential employers that you are indeed knowledgeable in your focus area. 

...

If you want to learn more, 

I just published an entire article on how to build a Machine Learning portfolio in 2024. 

You can read it here - https://lnkd.in/gxqgqPZY

I used to think I am not cut out for math. Until I realized it wasn’t about me, but more about the lack of intuitive learning materials.

And remember, just like Andrej Karpathy suggests, focus on building intuition instead of memorization. 


And don’t give up on math just yet!

name: Meri Nova

content:
It is surprising how many people don't understand the differences between ML engineering levels in Big Tech. It is a lot simpler than you think. 

Imagine the task is to build a house.

- The junior engineer gets a detailed blueprint with every instruction. They follow the steps carefully and successfully build the house, brick by brick.

- The mid-level engineer receives only half of the blueprint. They can still fill in the gaps with their past experience and problem-solving skills, and complete the house on time. 

- The senior engineer doesn't get a blueprint, because the last engineer burned it. Instead, they research zoning laws, survey the land, to create the blueprint from scratch, and lead the team until the house is built.

- The staff engineer questions why we’re even building the house in the first place. After speaking with stakeholders, they realized an apartment building is needed instead. They convince the team to pivot and complete a better project, making more money instead.

- The principal engineer is in panic. They don't think we should use bricks at all. They design a modular system that allows us to build anything we want faster and cheaper, setting the foundation for future projects.

- The distinguished engineer is done with physical buildings. They create virtual homes in the metaverse, so we can be anywhere and everywhere all at once. 


Every time you level up, you change your mindset and your behaviors, from pure execution to strategic and critical thinking. 

If you're aiming for the next level, focus on mindset shifts with an unprecedented innovative approach that challenges the status quo. 


P.S. this is relevant to all engineering roles, and not just ML. 

#machinelearning #career

There is one company in San Francisco that does hiring differently than 80% of the market. 
Their work culture is superb and here is why.

I can’t say the name to respect the privacy of my friend who works there and who shared his experience with me.

He is an ML engineer and, for the first time, he truly enjoys the environment and his team. Even though he had worked at MAANG companies in the past. 

What stood out the most is that this AI company strives to achieve “psycoholofical safety” so people can truly be creative and collaborative. 

And this is how their interview process looks like: 

1️⃣ Initial informal chat 

2️⃣ 60 Min Zoom Coding Interview
   ▪️ No Online Coding Environment 
   ▪️ Allowed to look up ANYTHING

3️⃣ Pair code with their existing engineer for 90 min.

4️⃣ Come to the office and work with the team for 2 days. 


So what does this tell me? 

🙏 Collaboration and problem-solving skills are prioritized. 
👎🏼 No memorization of Leetcode necessary 
👻 No stress over live technical interviews. 


If all companies had this hiring process, the world would be a better place. 

—-

Why? 

Because he's been helping countless people upskill and land their first jobs in Data for over 10 years!

So I had to ask him:

"How can someone with a non-tech background break into data in 2024 ?"

Some of his answers were surprising, while others confirmed my long-standing assumptions.

Most people can do it!

It's about believing in yourself and getting it done."

name: Meri Nova

content:
A friend recently shared how he learned to develop and deploy ML algorithms, and it completely changed my approach to learning.
I now wish this method was prioritized over using common ML libraries.

For example, we dive headfirst into scikit-learn, calling model. fit() completely bypassing the crucial step of understanding the model's inner workings.

This robs us of independent thinking and creativity as we try to become a better engineer. 

However, after applying this first-principle thinking to my learning process, I became more confident, and able to learn much faster.

Here is how: 

1. Start with the Problem:

Identify the core problem you want to solve with an algorithm. Instead of focusing on how others have solved it, ask questions like:

- what is the nature of the data? 
- what classes and relationships are we trying to uncover?
- what parameters should we take into account? 

2. Understand the Underlying Principles:

Dive into the mathematical and statistical foundations of the algorithm you are building. 

For instance:
- is it an optimization problem? finding the best parameters to minimize or maximize a function
- is it a probability question? modeling uncertainty and make predictions
- is it a causal inferencing? defining cause-and-effect relationships between variables

3. Rebuild from Scratch:

Implement algorithms from the ground up with Python only, focusing on the core logic.

By doing this, you’re forced to confront the complexities that are often abstracted away.

4. Compare it: 

 with the source code of any corresponding popular ML library and you will gain a much deeper appreciation and understanding of that technology!

...

I am curious to know what is your favorite way of learning ML?

name: Meri Nova

content:
Every ML engineer nails coding interview rounds, but many fail on Data Literacy.  
Don’t be that person, prepare for these questions! 

Data literacy is a crucial but often overlooked skill in ML engineering, that goes beyond statistics and writing SQL queries. 

Before building an ML model, have you ever stopped and asked yourself these questions?

- When collecting data, are we aware of the potential biases that could skew our results?

- When predicting trends over time, do we account for seasonality or other external factors that could influence our metrics?

- When visualizing a dataset, do we use appropriate scales and axes to accurately represent information and derive meaning?

If you haven’t , then is time to build data literacy skills first. 

To further assess for it, hiring managers may ask questions like: 

- How do you determine whether a significant outlier needs to be included or excluded? 

- Can you share an example when your assumptions contradicted the analysis and what did you about it?

- What was a key insight you derived from your data analysis that surprised you? How did it impact your decision-making?

Having a solid data intuition can help you build a better foundation for more robust ML systems. 


#dataliteracy #ml

content:
Do these 5 things before applying for Data Analyst positions.
I am still working on the 4th one. 

1️⃣ 𝐃𝐞𝐯𝐞𝐥𝐨𝐩 𝐂𝐨𝐫𝐞 𝐒𝐤𝐢𝐥𝐥𝐬:
Ensure you know at least 2 of the four core skills at a basic or intermediate level: SQL, Python, Tableau ( Power BI or Looker), and Excel. Most jobs require proficiency in just a couple of these areas, not all. 
Excel is still a relevant skill in the industry. Something I learned watching Alex Freberg' youtube videos. 

2️⃣ 𝐁𝐮𝐢𝐥𝐝 𝐚 𝐩𝐨𝐫𝐭𝐟𝐨𝐥𝐢𝐨 𝐩𝐫𝐨𝐣𝐞𝐜𝐭:
If you haven't yet built your first dashboard in Tableau with clear documentation, then consider joining Chris French's community to get your first project out the door for free. I love Chris's approach to project-based learning, where you can receive feedback and gain confidence through experience. This cohort ends in March.

3️⃣ 𝐂𝐫𝐚𝐟𝐭 𝐚 𝐃𝐚𝐭𝐚 𝐀𝐧𝐚𝐥𝐲𝐬𝐭-𝐅𝐨𝐜𝐮𝐬𝐞𝐝 𝐑𝐞𝐬𝐮𝐦𝐞:
Your resume should highlight your data analyst skills.
Include all portfolio projects to demonstrate your experience with tools and frameworks. List any relevant certifications you've obtained.

4️⃣ 𝐏𝐫𝐞𝐩𝐚𝐫𝐞 𝐟𝐨𝐫 𝐈𝐧𝐭𝐞𝐫𝐯𝐢𝐞𝐰𝐬:
Start preparing for interviews as soon as you consider applying for jobs, covering both technical and general questions.
Use platforms like DataLemur 🐒 (Ace the SQL & Data Interview) for technical questions in SQL and Python.

5️⃣ 𝐀𝐝𝐨𝐩𝐭 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐑𝐢𝐠𝐡𝐭 𝐌𝐢𝐧𝐝𝐬𝐞𝐭:
Recognize that you may never feel 100% ready or confident to apply. It's important to start the application process even if you feel slightly unprepared.
Understand that the learning continues on the job. Employers often seek candidates who are proficient in key skills like SQL, have a good attitude, and show eagerness to learn.

Don't delay applying due to fear of not meeting every requirement.

Happy hunting!

name: Meri Nova

content:
I don’t want to sound harsh. But I hate it when good people shy away from embracing their new identity because of a missing “title”.  

- You are an engineer NOT when you receive a job title. You are an engineer the moment you get your hands dirty to solve a real problem. 

- You are a teacher NOT when you get a board accreditation. You are a teacher, the moment someone finally understands a complex topic because of you. 

- You are a content creator, NOT when you reach 100k followers. You are a content creator the moment you become consistent with sharing high value posts! 

- You are a leader, NOT when you make Forbes’s silly 30 under 30 list. You are a leader the moment you have inspired someone to chase their own dreams. 


Don’t let arbitrary labels stop you from embracing your new identity. 

You are what you do, not what you are called!

name: Meri Nova

content:
Yesterday, I saw someone post 'New Year, New Me - 30 Days to Total Body Transformation!' 
I had to laugh. 

Not because it's impossible to change, but because we've completely lost touch with how real change happens.

Let me tell you something that took me years to accept:

Meaningful progress takes 𝘺𝘦𝘢𝘳𝘴, not 𝘥𝘢𝘺𝘴. 

No matter how many productivity tools or AI assistants we have, real long-lasting change requires making mistakes with patience. 

I get frustrated watching 'experts' promise quick fixes, knowing they're setting others up for disappointment. 

I have seen it first-hand multiple times, when someone can't match these unrealistic timelines, they're made to feel like they're not working hard enough or they don't deserve to reach their dreams. 

And it pains me. 

Because here's the truth: 

It took me 9 months to get my first Data job. 
It took me 18 months of creating content, day after day before I could call myself self-employed. 
And it took me 28 years to become my own best friend. 

This New Year, I hope you'll be gentle with yourself!

You are not too slow. 
You are not dumb. 
You just have unrealistic expectations. 

If you want the transformation to last, take your damn time and enjoy the daily progress. 

Happy New Year's Eve! ❤️ 

....

If you want to read about Data & AI leadership in 2025, join my newsletter: merinova.substack.com

When I was a teenager, whenever I got too caught up in my studies, my mom would step in, close my laptop, and tell me to get outside for fresh air. 

I would get irritated back then. But now I would very much appreciate it. 

So let me be your mom today. 😁 
Get your face out of the screen and go on a long walk!

Appreciate all you’ve done this year, this month, this week. 

And do something nice for yourself. 

You deserve it!

..

P.S. Kindness towards yourself goes a long way.

content:
Relational databases are not dead. 
Data engineering is not dead. 
SQL is 100% not dead. 

Many people mistakenly think that AI will kill the need for traditional data engineering skills. 

When in reality, it couldn’t be further from the truth

Due to increasing data volumes in AI systems, we will have: 

- 100x more transactional data to work with due to endless API calls
- more need for scalable and efficient real-time data processing for AI Agents
- more external tools and environments to move data through 
- more multimodal data to work with 

In fact, data engineering will take a crucial role in integrating AI into the modern software stack. 

If you want to know more about the future of Data Engineers in the Age of AI, join our conversation with Andreas Kretz this Thursday, 10 AM pacific. 

Andreas has taught more than 2k aspiring Data Engineers and has more than 300k followers combined. 

Prepare your questions for the Q&A session :)


Register here: https://lu.ma/0jfa54q3

name: Meri Nova

content:
Whatever you do, don't be rude to servers! 

I worked as a waitress on one of my first jobs.
And I already felt extremely bad when things didn't go the way a customer wanted. 

Lately, though, I've been noticing a surprising number of situations, where full-grown adults were throwing tantrums with explosive emotions and with a huge sense of entitlement.

Yesterday, for instance, I saw a lady who was screaming at a waitress to change her order immediately, when the order had been already placed. 

Or the other week, when an elderly man was literally shouting "You need to serve me first, and nobody else!" because a waiter didn't bring his check on time. 

I don't know what to do during these situations, but to feel sorry. 

Please be nice to the service workers, especially when the holiday season is coming up!

They are humans who deserve respect, just like every one of us.
name: Meri Nova

content:
When I was 22 I was lost and depressed. 

I had just graduated from business school. And wanted to prove to myself I was worthy of success. 

- I tried building an online travel agency - ended up quitting because it didn’t feel right.
- I tried front-end engineering - but ended up quitting because I found CSS too boring.
- I tried data analytics - but ended up quitting because I quickly got tired of it. 
- I tried machine learning and fell in love with it!

I kept learning every single day. And after a year, got my first job at an amazing agrotech startup, which allowed me to open a savings account for the first time in my life!

Nowadays, I enjoy what I do and run a thriving and rapidly growing data community. 

It is absolutely normal to feel lost early on in your career.
Keep learning every single day.
And you will find your thing eventually!

name: Meri Nova

content:
First 1-3 months of learning Data Science: 

- Opens Jupyter Notebook 
- Imports Pandas, Numpy, FastAI 
- Feels proud 🤓


Next 3-6 months into Data Science: 

- Downloads VSCode
- Imports PyTorch/Tensorflow or scikit-learn
- Learns to feature engineer data and fine-tune the models. 
- Tries to deploy on the AWS, GCP and gives up midway. 🙃 


Next 6-12 months of learning: 

- Trains the models on Nvidia GPU’s 
- Deploys with Terraform, Kubernetes, Docker and CI/CD
- Creates its own API 
- Implements evaluation metrics and calls it a day ✅


Next 1-3 years: 

- Focuses on solving a business problem 
- Makes bank 💰
name: Meri Nova

content:
Don’t make a jump from Software Engineering to ML Engineering, until you have done these 5 things. 

Here’s what Kartik Singhal, Senior ML Engineer at 𝐌𝐞𝐭𝐚, shared with me on what he wished he knew before transitioning to ML Engineering. 


1. 𝐔𝐧𝐝𝐞𝐫𝐬𝐭𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐲𝐨𝐮𝐫 𝐦𝐨𝐭𝐢𝐯𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧. 
For Kartik, it was Google's PageRank that got him hooked on ML. It made him want to learn more about the tech behind it. 
𝐋𝐞𝐬𝐬𝐨𝐧: 
Reflect on why you want to get into Machine Learning and identify specific areas of interest. 


2. 𝐒𝐭𝐢𝐜𝐤 𝐭𝐨 𝐲𝐨𝐮𝐫 𝐧𝐢𝐜𝐡𝐞 𝐝𝐮𝐫𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐭𝐫𝐚𝐧𝐬𝐢𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧. 
Kartik started working as an SWE in the Amazon Dynamic Pricing team. Even though Pricing was not his preferred choice, his experience helped him transition to MLE much faster.
𝐋𝐞𝐬𝐬𝐨𝐧: 
Leverage your existing domain knowledge to make the transition fast. 


3. 𝐔𝐧𝐝𝐞𝐫𝐬𝐭𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐩𝐞𝐫𝐟𝐨𝐫𝐦𝐚𝐧𝐜𝐞 𝐞𝐯𝐚𝐥𝐮𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧 𝐦𝐞𝐭𝐫𝐢𝐜𝐬:
With Software Engineers, the emphasis is more on scalable system design, and code quality. With MLE, the emphasis is more on the business impact and technical expertise.
𝐋𝐞𝐬𝐬𝐨𝐧:
Identify and optimize towards the MLE criteria, as they differ from SWEs


4. 𝐖𝐨𝐫𝐤 𝐨𝐧 𝐌𝐋 𝐩𝐫𝐨𝐣𝐞𝐜𝐭𝐬.  
Kartik worked on a project to improve the AWS SageMaker training pipeline, even though it was not in his primary role. 
𝐋𝐞𝐬𝐬𝐨𝐧:
Collaborate with experienced ML engineers on small projects to gain hands-on experience on the job. 


5. 𝐅𝐢𝐧𝐝 𝐚 𝐬𝐮𝐩𝐩𝐨𝐫𝐭𝐢𝐯𝐞 𝐦𝐚𝐧𝐚𝐠𝐞𝐫: 
A manager familiar with ML roles and who is supportive of your learning and career growth is crucial. 
𝐋𝐞𝐬𝐬𝐨𝐧: 
They should not only support you verbally but also take ACTUAL steps to facilitate your transition.


...

Sign up for our upcoming event this Friday with Kartik Singhal! 

Here: https://lu.ma/ydnncgmk

This event will be PACKED with actionable advice. 

So come prepared with your questions for Q&A!

I don't know who needs to hear this, but your worth != your productivity.

It's easy to get caught in the "productive == important" trap. But you are so much more than your to-do list or your job title.

Your kindness matters. 
Your creativity matters. 
Your presence matters.

On days when you feel like you haven't "done enough," remind yourself that existing, caring, and simply being you is more than enough. 

You're worthy, not because of what you do, but because of who you are. Don't ever forget that.

name: Meri Nova

content:
How to Design a Database Schema for Ride-Sharing Apps during a 30 min Interviews.

If you're prepping for a tech interview, understanding how to design database schemas, especially for dynamic apps like Uber or Lyft, is crucial. 


Here's a short guide based on a Jay Feng's interview prep video:


𝐔𝐧𝐝𝐞𝐫𝐬𝐭𝐚𝐧𝐝𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐑𝐞𝐪𝐮𝐢𝐫𝐞𝐦𝐞𝐧𝐭: First, clarify if the schema is for analytics, backend, or app service. Optimization for latency is key, especially for backend services.

𝐓𝐚𝐛𝐥𝐞𝐬 𝐟𝐨𝐫 𝐃𝐢𝐟𝐟𝐞𝐫𝐞𝐧𝐭 𝐏𝐮𝐫𝐩𝐨𝐬𝐞𝐬: Design separate tables for different functionalities - one optimized for latency (real-time app interactions) and another for analytics and machine learning.

𝐈𝐦𝐦𝐮𝐭𝐚𝐛𝐥𝐞 𝐍𝐚𝐭𝐮𝐫𝐞 𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐊𝐞𝐲 𝐀𝐭𝐭𝐫𝐢𝐛𝐮𝐭𝐞𝐬: Start with immutable attributes like 'trip ID' and 'event timestamp'. In NoSQL databases (like DynamoDB), these form the unique keys.

𝐀𝐭𝐭𝐫𝐢𝐛𝐮𝐭𝐞𝐬 𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐑𝐞𝐥𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧𝐬: Include critical attributes like rider ID, driver ID, location coordinates, and ratings. Avoid unnecessary joins in NoSQL; include essential paired attributes in the same table.

𝐇𝐚𝐧𝐝𝐥𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐋𝐚𝐭𝐞𝐧𝐜𝐲 𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐀𝐧𝐚𝐥𝐲𝐭𝐢𝐜𝐬: For low-latency systems, use NoSQL databases. For analytics and machine learning, consider data lakes or lakehouse systems.

𝐑𝐞𝐠𝐢𝐨𝐧𝐚𝐥𝐢𝐳𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧 𝐟𝐨𝐫 𝐄𝐟𝐟𝐢𝐜𝐢𝐞𝐧𝐜𝐲 𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐂𝐨𝐦𝐩𝐥𝐢𝐚𝐧𝐜𝐞: Create regionalized tables (e.g., by country) to reduce network latency and comply with data regulations.

𝐏𝐚𝐫𝐭𝐢𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐒𝐜𝐚𝐥𝐢𝐧𝐠: Partition tables naturally (e.g., by date or region) to manage data efficiently and scale effectively.

𝐃𝐚𝐭𝐚 𝐒𝐭𝐫𝐮𝐜𝐭𝐮𝐫𝐞 𝐟𝐨𝐫 𝐌𝐚𝐜𝐡𝐢𝐧𝐞 𝐋𝐞𝐚𝐫𝐧𝐢𝐧𝐠: For ML use cases, join denormalized data with dimension tables to create a comprehensive dataset.

𝐎𝐩𝐭𝐢𝐦𝐢𝐳𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐐𝐮𝐞𝐫𝐢𝐞𝐬: Design your schema to minimize the need for joins and facilitate efficient querying.

𝐂𝐚𝐜𝐡𝐞 𝐈𝐦𝐩𝐥𝐞𝐦𝐞𝐧𝐭𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧: Use caching mechanisms (like Redis or Memcache) for quicker access to frequently used data.



This approach to schema design balances immediate transactional needs with long-term analytical requirements, crucial for efficient ride-sharing app functionalities. 

Remember, understanding these nuances can be a game-changer in tech interviews!

name: Meri Nova

content:
Yesterday, my 87 yo grandpa and 78 yo grandma were introduced to ChatGPT for the first time! 

By the end, one was visibly shaken, and the other couldn't stop firing off questions about the lives of Muslim prophets and scientists.

Since I landed in Kyrgyzstan last week, I was surprised to learn how few people knew about AI. (only 20% of everyone I talked with)

Having spent most of my adult life in the Bay Area, I've grown accustomed to new AI inventions seamlessly becoming part of my daily routine.

It just shows how naturally people in San Francisco adapt to innovation.

But back home in Kyrgyzstan, I was surprised to see very little enthusiasm for AI in the general public. 

When I saw my grandparents, I didn't even think to bring up ChatGPT...

Until they asked me to write a song in Kyrgyz for their upcoming 60th anniversary.

That’s when it hit me: “Have you heard of a 'genius computer' that knows everything?” I asked.

They thought I was joking. 

So, I quickly opened my laptop, gave ChatGPT family details, and asked it to create a song in Kyrgyz. (To my relief, it didn't hallucinate much 😅 )

The result? 

Grandpa was completely shocked and couldn't get away from the computer for another hour. 

and Grandma got deeply confused and even a little scared. 

Now, it seems they might just need a subscription of their own.

In general,  I believe it's important to bring all generations on board and show them how AI can make a real difference in their everyday lives!

content:
How Data Science roles are different from ML engineering roles?
Here are some nuanced differences that most people get wrong. 👇

- DS focuses more on extracting insights, while MLE focuses more on model implementation.
- DS works with historical data, MLE works with dynamic data. 
- DS is more statistics and business-oriented, while MLE is more software engineering and systems-oriented.
- DS uses SQL and sometimes Python. MLE uses Python and sometimes Rust, C++, and Java. 

Some similarities:

- Both, DS and MLE need to follow version control, documentation, and reproducibility standards. 
- Both, DS and MLE need a strong understanding of statistics, machine learning algorithms, and their applications.
- Both work closely with data engineers to ensure data quality and availability.
- Both hate unnecessary meetings.
- Both need to balance model complexity with constraints like computational resources and interoperability.

Remember, in many organizations, the lines between these roles can blur. 

The key is to find where your personal skills and interests align best. 

...

name: Meri Nova

content:
After researching the most common questions for Machine Learning interviews, I compiled a list of top 30: 👇

1. How is machine learning different from general programming?
2. What is Overfitting in Machine Learning and how can it be avoided?
3. Why do we perform normalization?
4. What is the difference between precision and recall?
5. What is the bias-variance tradeoff?
6. What is Principal Component Analysis?
7. What is one-shot learning?
8. What is the difference between stochastic gradient descent (SGD) and gradient descent (GD)?
9. What is the Central Limit theorem?
10. Explain the working principle of SVM.
11. What is the difference between L1 and L2 regularization? What is their significance?
12. What is the purpose of splitting a given dataset into training and validation data?
13. Why removing highly correlated features are considered a good practice?
14. Reverse a linked list in place. 
15. What is the reason behind the curse of dimensionality?
16. What is Linear Discriminant Analysis?
17. Can you explain the differences between supervised, unsupervised, and reinforcement learning?
18. What are convolutional networks? Where can we use them?
19. What is cost function?
20. List different activation neurons or functions.
21. Explain Epoch vs. Batch vs. Iteration.
22. What is regularization, why do we use it, and give some examples of common methods?
23. Explain why the performance of XGBoost is better than that of SVM?
25. What is the difference between correlation and causality?
26. What is stemming?
27. What is Lemmatization?
28. What is Static Memory Allocation?
29. What are some tools used to discover outliers?
30. What are some methods to improve inference time?

Quick tip: 

Copy and paste these questions to Google Sheets. 
Every time you go through them, create a separate column and write down your answers. This way you can track and improve your learning process.

name: Meri Nova

content:
Don't make the mistake 80% of AI engineers do when building RAG evaluations.
 
Many forget to measure the individual components of RAG and instead only focus on the output accuracy or relevance. 
 
To truly get consistent results with RAG, you need to evaluate these systems at multiple stages:

𝐑𝐞𝐭𝐫𝐢𝐞𝐯𝐚𝐥 𝐒𝐭𝐚𝐠𝐞:
- Context Precision: What percentage of the retrieved documents are actually relevant to the query?
- Context Recall: Out of all relevant documents, what percentage does the system successfully retrieve?

If document ranking is important, consider metrics like:
- NDCG (Normalized Discounted Cumulative Gain)
- MRR (Mean Reciprocal Rank).

𝐎𝐯𝐞𝐫𝐚𝐥𝐥 𝐏𝐞𝐫𝐟𝐨𝐫𝐦𝐚𝐧𝐜𝐞:
Evaluate the system end-to-end to ensure all components work harmoniously.

Think of these questions when evaluating your RAG system: 
- How scalable is it, both in terms of data storage and query traffic?
- How much data can you process in bulk at once when indexing? 
- What is query latency? 
and more...

For a comprehensive evaluation framework, consider using ragas, an open source LLM evaluation library. This tool is specifically designed to assess both the retrieval and generation components of any RAG application. 

...

If you're eager to learn more about optimizing RAG systems, check out my course "RAG with Langchain" on the DataCamp's platform. You can take the first chapter for free here - https://lnkd.in/gnGXMkTe

And if you want to gain full access to all of their courses, you can get 50% off within the next 36 hours! 

Use the link here: https://lnkd.in/guVFxeQq

And start building RAG projects!

name: Meri Nova

content:
Here is a #1 secret to acing any Data Science Interview. 

I talked with countless ML engineers and Data Scientists from Big Tech about their successful interview learnings and here is the common tip I hear the most: 

"You need to act like a consultant.
At the end of the day, you are providing a service to a company "  

Just like on a first discovery call, you need to see if you are a good fit for each other. You can do it only if you understand their current problem and their business well. 

Here is how you can do it:

1. Interviewer: Provides you with a context and a current business goal/problem. 
2. You: Instead of answering right away, pause and ask clarifying questions.
3. Interviewer: Provides more context.
4. You: Repeat what you understood, pause, and think, and then respond. (Feel free to ask  more clarifying questions if necessary)
5. Interviewer: Asks more follow-up questions.
6. You: Provide more value and ask them for feedback to adjust your answer further. 

♻️Wash. Rinse. Repeat. 

If you want to outcompete other applicants, act like a salesman, and show your genuine interest and true competence to win their trust. 

Good luck! 

#mlengineer #interview #bid

There’s a huge misconception that careers in Large Language Models (LLMs) are limited to a few niche roles like prompt engineering. But in reality, there are far more diverse roles that go often unnoticed.

Here’s what the future of work in LLMs really looks like:

1.  AI Engineer: building the infrastructure that powers cutting-edge LLM applications.
2. AI Product Manager: driving the development of LLM-based tools, from concept to launch.
3. Developer Relations Specialist: helping communities use and understand LLM tools.
4.  LLM/ML Research Engineer: pushing the boundaries of what LLMs can do in real-world applications.
5.  Machine Learning Ops Specialist (MLOps): ensuring smooth deployment and maintenance of LLM models in production.

It’s not just about one tool or one role. LLMs can transform industries and create opportunities for people with all types of backgrounds and skill levels.

That is why I’m partnering with Clicked and IBM to host a FREE workshop on LLMs and how you can level up your career in AI and machine learning!

You don’t need years of technical experience to break into these roles. It’s about how you apply your unique skills that counts.

content:
It is NOT too late to change careers. 
It is NOT too late to get the degree you always wanted. 
It is NOT too late to avoid settling into a relationship that makes you unhappy. 

For today’s very important international holiday, I want to remind you:  

You are not running out of time!

Do not fall victim to anyone’s expectations of how your life should look like at any age. 

I was there. 

And it was miserable. 

Growing up in Asia, I would see young women crumble under the weight of expectations from society. 

They would be ridiculed and publicly mocked for being single and not having kids by 25. 

And unfortunately would settle into terrible environments that would stomp their growth and vigor. 

On the other hand, women who dared to prioritize themselves and their careers were called “a waste”. 

Fortunately, I was surrounded by strong women in my teenage years. 

Entrepreneurs, scientists, and politicians, who were proudly single and successful way in their 30s and 40s. 

And this is the message they gave me:

You are a human who deserves to lead your life however you please. 

Study whatever you want. 

Change careers however many times you want. 

Wear whatever you want. 

Date whomever you want, however often you want. 

Every day remind yourself of your intrinsic power.

Listen to yourself. 

Appreciate yourself. 

Trust yourself. 

Give yourself ALL the time you need. 

And remember you can always choose to change paths all over again. 



Happy International Women’s Day, Champions! 💐 


#internationalwomensday 
#womenempowerment

name: Meri Nova

content:
When I first started Break Into Data, I pulled an all-nighter to launch our 30-day ml coding challenge. I thought I was cool and dedicated. 

But it was one of the stupidest things I have ever done.

I was brainwashed by the SF tech culture, that success meant constant grinding with no breaks, 

Otherwise.... you are a loser. 

I learned the hard way how toxic it was, because ultimately: 

- our brain needs rest to learn effectively. 
After a few of those late nights, my ability to absorb new information crashed. 
If you won't prioritize sleep, it will only get worse. 

- the tech world will always demand more. 
There's always another algorithm to master, another mountain to climb. If you don't set boundaries, the work will consume you.

- your health is your most valuable asset. 
The headaches, eye strain, and back pain from that night took a while to fully recover from. No KPI is worth that.

- balance makes you a better performer and a leader. 
When I'm well-rested and balanced, I can provide much better support and guidance.

Even if a project fails, or you get laid off, you can (and will) recover.
But your health and relationships are much harder to repair once damaged.

Now,  I remind myself:

- set realistic deadlines that don't require heroic efforts
- prioritize sleep and exercise—they're as important as coding practice
- take regular breaks to step away from the screen
- remember that consistency trumps intensity

Your dedication is admirable, but if you want a long-lasting career you need to prioritize work-life balance. 

Remember, the best leaders aren't those who work the longest hours, but those who sustain their energy and enthusiasm in the long run.

content:
Can Software Engineers Transition to Machine Learning Engineers?

The short answer is, yes!

The longer answer...

Working as a software engineer gives you an advantage if you know how to use it well.  You already have a solid foundation that is directly applicable to ml engineering. 

This includes:

- Strong programming skills that many data scientists lack
- Understanding the software development lifecycle 
- Familiarity with version control like Git 
- Fundamentals of System Design. 

Once you've got a baseline, then you just need to:

- Build a strong understanding of linear algebra and statistics behind machine learning models. You can follow this guide - https://lnkd.in/gSfpKWBQ

- Learn about core machine learning concepts and algorithms. You can start here  - https://lnkd.in/ggusYiX8

- Practice building, training, and deploying machine learning models. Check out this Krish Naik's ML Deployment playlist - https://lnkd.in/gTpSDEZa

- Read up on machine learning papers. I like to learn from Yannic Kilcher's simple explanations of popular research papers  - https://lnkd.in/gyUipbv7

- Seek out machine learning projects within your current company to gain hands-on experience. 

- Start interviewing for machine learning engineer roles!

name: Meri Nova

content:
80% of hiring managers and recruiters will NOT open your GitHub repo. 
But they will ALWAYS click the link to your website. 
Learn to deploy your projects on the cloud and land 3x more interviews. 👇 

Unfortunately, many Data Professionals make this mistake:

They spend hours building beautiful dynamic dashboards, and web applications on Flask or Django that never see the light of day. 

But here is the truth they don't realize. 

Projects that are accessible on the web 24/7 are more impressive and impactful than hundreds of lines of code that merely sit on GitHub.

However, if you have never deployed on the cloud, do not make a rookie mistake and jump straight into AWS, GCP or Azure. 

The learning curve for large cloud platforms is too STEEP. And you will waste time learning those tools instead of focusing on your portfolio. 
 
Here is what you should do instead: 


1. 𝐏𝐥𝐚𝐧 𝐘𝐨𝐮𝐫 𝐏𝐫𝐨𝐣𝐞𝐜𝐭 𝐑𝐞𝐪𝐮𝐢𝐫𝐞𝐦𝐞𝐧𝐭𝐬: Before setting up your server, outline what your project needs. Consider the required processing power, memory, storage, and security features. Knowing this will help you choose the right option.

2. 𝐂𝐨𝐧𝐬𝐢𝐝𝐞𝐫 𝐲𝐨𝐮𝐫 𝐨𝐩𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧𝐬: Shared hosting (When you share one server with others), Dedicated hosting (When you own the entire server), VPS hosting( Provides features of dedicated hosting but at a lower cost)

3. 𝐌𝐚𝐤𝐞 𝐚 𝐜𝐡𝐨𝐢𝐜𝐞. If this is your first time hosting on a cloud I would recommend VPS, as it has the best of two worlds. I personally moved from Heroku to VPS hosting on https://lnkd.in/d3qcNA6r for my projects, it was easier to set up, had a lower cost, high security, and automated data backup.

4. 𝐒𝐞𝐭 𝐮𝐩. Once you've chosen your provider and plan, set up your virtual server. This involves configuring the operating system, setting up the network, and securing your server.

5. 𝐓𝐢𝐦𝐞 𝐭𝐨 𝐝𝐞𝐩𝐥𝐨𝐲 𝐲𝐨𝐮𝐫 𝐚𝐩𝐩𝐥𝐢𝐜𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧. Transfer your data, set up databases, and configure any necessary software and credentials on the dashboard. 

6. 𝐌𝐨𝐧𝐢𝐭𝐨𝐫. With everything in place, continually monitor your application's performance. A good VPS provider will offer compliance indicators for service performance and uptime.

Launching your data project on a VPS ensures you have a scalable environment, which is more cost-effective for smaller applications and yet it provides high availability and performance.


Happy coding and deploying!


P.S. You can use my code to get a 15% discount on Is*hosting -> MERI15

content:
I gained 5000 followers in 10 days!
But nobody knows this ...
I was ready to GIVE UP one day prior...


The day before 800,000 people on LinkedIn and X read my story, 
I felt deeply unfulfilled and was ready to give up creating content. 

I believed I wasted a lot of time. 

The time that I could have spent upskilling in Data Science and Engineering. 😫

You don’t know this, but…  

I made content EVERY SINGLE DAY on 3 platforms for 70 days straight. 

With absolutely no result. 😭

Until one day, 
When I woke up and saw another failed content piece. That absolutely crushed me. 

I was devastated and bawled my eyes out. 
I wanted to quit and put my dreams back on the shelf.
“All this hard work! For nothing!” - I thought. 


But guess what… 


I wiped my tears. 
Went to a coffee shop. 
And decided to try another approach.


Instead of only making educational content.
I decided to be vulnerable and talk about my personal journey. 


I wrote my story in 15 min and hit “publish”. 
Moments later..
I start getting endless pings & notifications.🔔 


The post went absurdly viral. 
I still get messages from that post. 
And the rest is history. 


🔑 The key takeaway here is:


If you do not see immediate results it doesn’t mean you failed! 

Nothing is truly wasted. 

Skills you attain now will come handy when you least expect it. 

If I haven’t built the work ethic, this wouldn’t have happened.  


—


This is a reminder to you: 

Don’t delay your dreams.

If you need to pivot, pivot. 

But keep showing up every day, no matter what! 🫵🏼👁️
name: Meri Nova

content:
I once worked with an engineer who was well known for one thing above all else: relentless focus.

While others might get distracted by numerous side projects, new tools or the endless list of tasks, this engineer had an ability to zero in on the most critical issues.

I remember a project where the team was overwhelmed by competing priorities. It felt like everything was about to go on fire.

But instead of trying to do everything at once, he would always ask:

- What’s the one thing that, if solved, will take us to the next level?
- How can we deliver the most value with what we have right now?

By consistently focusing on what mattered the most, he drove the team to  deliver high-impact results and earned respect from peers. 

These days, in the age of rapid innovation, the ability to cut through the noise becomes a game changer for your career.

name: Meri Nova

content:
Top 5 industry-defining trends in AI & ML that you need to watch in the next 2-3 years:  

1. explainability: Companies are increasingly prioritizing transparency over sheer performance. Trust comes first. 

2. evaluation: Due to the non-deterministic nature of AI, robust and reliable evaluation methods are not only challenging to build but also absolutely critical. 

3.  agentic AI: The shift towards proactive AI systems will bring the next wave of GenAI applications that fully leverage its automation potential. 

4. multimodal: There's a growing trend towards integrating multiple data types -text, images, and audio - to build more human-like experiences with AI. 

5. data literacy: Despite the rapid advancement of AI, there is still a huge skill gap in the industry.  It is better to have 100s of educated data professionals (data science citizens) than to have a few AI/ML unicorns. 

...

What trends are you most excited about?
name: Meri Nova

content:
12 months ago, I stopped drinking alcohol. 

I didn’t know if I would lose friends and be forever lonely.

But I knew I had to make a change.

Things became obvious when I got diagnosed with ADHD. 

That’s when I started learning about the negative impacts of alcohol on human neurology.  

Each sip took a toll on my already struggling dopamine, norepinephrine, and serotonin levels, which ultimately led to depressive episodes and mood swings. 

How could I think about my future when all I could focus on was feeling better at the moment?

I realized I would rather do what’s best for my health than worry about losing friends. 

And that’s exactly what I did. 
Surprisingly and partly sadly, some people disappeared from my radar. 

But the moment I became clear on my priorities, new people entered my life and supported me and my goals. 

Fast forward to now, the summer of 2024:

- I have more energy, better discipline, and a work ethic
- I went all in on LinkedIn content creation
- I started a community with passionate lifelong learners
- I am surrounded by founders, creators, and leaders
- I had excellent coaches to guide me
- I am invited to speak on events and podcasts. 


Coincidence? I don't think so.

Do not be scared to lose people and old destructive habits. 

I promise you, life is better on the other side of fear.

It's time to trust yourself and take a leap.

content:
You don't have to spend $100k on a Masters or PhD to break into ML. 
Get inspired by these 5 career transitions to ML. 

After reading about their stories, it turns out all of them share these 5 common traits.  

Adopt them and you will win too: 

1. 𝐏𝐚𝐬𝐬𝐢𝐨𝐧 𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐒𝐞𝐥𝐟-𝐌𝐨𝐭𝐢𝐯𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧: These engineers pursued the field without formal credentials because of their underlying passion for AI/ML. They often spent nights and weekends on online courses, research papers, and side projects. This genuine enthusiasm helped them push through initial rejections and self-doubts, where many people fail. 

2. 𝐋𝐞𝐯𝐞𝐫𝐚𝐠𝐞 𝐄𝐱𝐢𝐬𝐭𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐒𝐤𝐢𝐥𝐥𝐬: They built upon their prior experience in domains like software engineering and data analysis to transition into AI/ML roles. They were strategic when it came to leveraging their past experiences. 

3. 𝐂𝐨𝐧𝐭𝐞𝐧𝐭 𝐂𝐫𝐞𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧 𝐟𝐨𝐫 𝐕𝐢𝐬𝐢𝐛𝐢𝐥𝐢𝐭𝐲: Blogging, open-source projects, and online discussions helped these engineers get noticed by AI/ML hiring managers and researchers. YouTube project videos, blog posts, and articles are prime examples of how sharing your AI/ML journey can create opportunities.

4. 𝐅𝐢𝐧𝐝 𝐔𝐧𝐜𝐨𝐧𝐯𝐞𝐧𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧𝐚𝐥 𝐄𝐧𝐭𝐫𝐲 𝐏𝐨𝐢𝐧𝐭𝐬: They seized opportunities like the OpenAI or Facebook AI research residencies and proactively reached out to researchers and hiring managers. Rai’s contact with John Schulman is a notable example of taking bold steps despite not feeling fully ready.

5. 𝐁𝐞 𝐛𝐨𝐥𝐝: Be ready to take unconventional career moves, and embrace being a beginner again.

name: Meri Nova

content:
10 harsh lessons I wish somebody had told me before I became an international student 10 years ago. 

I remember feeling lonely, clueless and freaked out as a foreigner in the US. 

If you are an international student now, don't make the same mistakes as I did. 

Learn from them and you will be ahead of the 80%: 

1. Making friends will take time, be patient.
2. Take leadership roles in your favorite clubs to gain experience outside of the classroom. 
3. Find a professional therapist and commit to it for at least 6 months. (can't stress this enough)
4. Get diagnosed with ADHD asap. Everything will start to make sense. 
5. Take advantage of Career Services at school. (use everything they give)
6. Start weight lifting and long-distance running. (it will boost your self-esteem)
7. Surround yourself with those who inspire you, and don't be afraid to leave the ones who don't.
8. Network with alumni and find a mentor early on. (life-changing)
9. Learn SQL and Python and build your portfolio. (trust me, you will get a job)
10. Quit trying to fit in and don’t be afraid to stand out. (you deserve it)


What would you tell your 18-year-old self? 


P.S. This is me on our first day of college in 2014.

What is NOT a growth mindset: 

- self-criticism 
- a comparison game
- sacrificing sleep and rest
- idolizing 'successful' people
- consuming edutaining content
- abandoning your health & social life entirely 

What IS a  growth mindset: 

- patience with yourself
- consistent effort that gets appreciated by you
- admitting when it gets hard
- and asking for help 
- giving yourself breaks
- only comparing yourself to your past
- allowing joy and delight into your daily work


Remember. Be kind to yourself. Everything else is secondary.

name: Meri Nova

content:
Want to know something crazy? 

When it comes to job searching, it's not a lack of skills holding you back - it’s a lack of strategy.

Before you hit 'apply' on the next job post, answer these questions first:

1. Industry vs Research. 
Do you want to build products or explore new ideas?
The industry offers higher pay but less freedom, focusing on products. Research prioritizes innovation over profits.

2. Startups vs Big Tech
Do you want speed and risk, or stability and structure?
Startups move fast, reward risk, and need generalists. Big Tech offers stability, specialized roles, and more resources.

3. Vertical vs Horizontal. 
Do you want to serve customers or engineers?
Vertical markets focus on specific industries (healthcare, finance), requiring domain expertise. Horizontal markets offer tools for engineers across industries.

4. Consumer vs Enterprise
Do you want to focus on users or enterprises?
B2C builds products for users. B2B creates solutions for businesses.

...

Once you answer these questions, you will have a better understanding of your long-term career preferences. 

Do this often, as preferences may change!

🔔 If you like this, sign up for Break Into Data's newsletter and get weekly career guidance, free resources, and more: https://lnkd.in/gmmWf7uE 

♻ Repost to help others find it.

content:
Interview Ready vs Job Ready. 
Not long ago I didn’t know the difference and wasted an entire month. 

90% of the time I was preparing to be Job Ready.

- I revised technical concepts to fill knowledge gaps.
- Built different projects to hone my analytical and engineering skills. 
- Completed SQL Leetcode challenges 

I thought if I could do everything above I will be able to pass the interviews with almost no preparation. 

I was wrong…

In reality, being Interview Ready is what gets you to the finish line. 

So now I shift my focus on: 

🎯 Building resumes that are aligned with the desired role. 
🎯 Practice common interview questions. I found this site helpful - https://lnkd.in/gEgwHsBP 
Great resource by Jay Feng. 
🎯 Learn to translate your past experience and make it relevant to the position.

—

✨Job Ready✨ means to perform and meet employer’s expectations at the job.

✨Interview Ready✨ means convincing them to give you a shot.  

—

What are your tips to be interview ready?

name: Meri Nova

content:
Explaining how deep learning models work can be difficult because: 

- most models have billions of parameters, making it impossible to track how each one contributes to the final output

- most models use ensemble techniques, making it untraceable to find which sub-model is responsible for specific outputs

- most models rely on high-dimensional feature / latent spaces that can't be easily mapped to the human mind 

- most models change their behavior during training in ways that aren't captured by traditional metrics


Are we really the first generation of engineers deploying systems that we can’t fully comprehend? 


#deeplearning

It is NOT about crunching as many leetcodes as possible. 
It IS about knowing when and how to apply your coding skills. 

It is NOT about hoarding more information in your bookmarks. 
It IS about building confidence through your daily progress. 

It is NOT about avoiding failure on your interview rounds. 
It IS about documenting and improving upon it with self compassion. 

It is NOT about sending cold LinkedIn messages to strangers.

You are not alone in this. 

Join our community Break Into Data to have more fun and joy in your learning process.

name: Meri Nova

content:
Today, ChatGPT lost $21 million in 6 hours. 
Here is what happened. 👇

Nobody will tell you exactly how much money OpenAI lost during those hours, but we took a stab at it anyway. 

Read until the end to find the formula. 

Earlier today, on June 4th, at 2:15p GMT, ChatGPT experienced one of the 𝐥𝐚𝐫𝐠𝐞𝐬𝐭 𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐥𝐨𝐧𝐠𝐞𝐬𝐭 𝐨𝐮𝐭𝐚𝐠𝐞𝐬 since its inception.

Everyone knows when a website is down, you are not only bleeding money but also: 

- Your users are switching to your competitors. 
- Your enterprise customers no longer see you as a reliant option. 
- The trust and reputation are damaged. 

Now let's feel this damage in numbers. Shall we? 

To calculate the loss you need to take into account the long-term impact of this incident. 
Here is how: 

(1)Direct cost + (2)Indirect long-term costs. 

1. 𝐃𝐢𝐫𝐞𝐜𝐭 𝐥𝐨𝐬𝐬. 

Chatgpt makes approximately $80 million per month. 
Estimated Revenue Loss = Hourly Revenue × Duration of Outage. 

$111,111/ hour × 6  hours =  $ 666,666

2. 𝐂𝐮𝐬𝐭𝐨𝐦𝐞𝐫 𝐂𝐡𝐮𝐫𝐧:

Estimation: A 0.5% increase in churn among 1 million paying users who pay $20 a month multiplied by 12 months(ChatGPT Plus and enterprise users).

Annual loss calculation:
1,000,000 × 0.005 × 20 x 12 = $1,200,000 / year

3. 𝐃𝐞𝐜𝐫𝐞𝐚𝐬𝐞𝐝 𝐆𝐫𝐨𝐰𝐭𝐡 𝐫𝐚𝐭𝐞 𝐨𝐧 𝐒𝐮𝐛𝐬𝐜𝐫𝐢𝐩𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧𝐬:

Estimation: A 1% decrease in expected new subscribers monthly due to negative publicity, based on a 5% monthly growth rate on 1 million users.

Annual loss calculation:
1,000,000 × 0.05 × 0.01 x 20 x 12 =1,200,000 dollars/year

4. 𝐀𝐏𝐈 𝐔𝐬𝐚𝐠𝐞 𝐑𝐞𝐝𝐮𝐜𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧:

Estimation: A 2% decrease in API monthly usage due to reliability concerns, given that API sales are a significant part of the $80 million monthly revenue.

Annual loss calculation:
80,000,000×0.02 x 12 =19,200,000/ year


𝐓𝐨𝐭𝐚𝐥 𝐋𝐨𝐬𝐬:

Summing these factors gives:
Total Annual Long-Term Loss = 1,200,000+1,200,000+19,200,000= 💫 21,600,000 𝐝𝐨𝐥𝐥𝐚𝐫𝐬 💫 




If you like what you read ...

👍 React
♻️ Share
💬 Discuss

Follow for more Data Content that is based on the real world.

content:
Most of my life, I focused on what I did wrong in my career. 

My heart felt heavy and filled with regrets:

- I wish I had studied for a STEM degree.
- I wish I had broken into tech few years earlier
- I wish I had focused on my personal growth instead of pleasing others

These "wishes" only pulled me backward and made me feel incredibly small. 

That is when I realized - it’s extremely important to actively challenge these distorted perspectives and remind yourself of the things you did right.  

You and I did lots of things right! 

- We persevered through limited resources and guidance 
- We handled daily uncertainties with grace and humility 
- We followed our curiosities and look where it got us
- We learned a lot about ourselves through health and relationship challenges
- We brought our best foot forward daily and built great work ethic 


Take a moment today to reflect on the good decisions you've made in the past and if you feel like it share them in the comments!

Show some gratitude for your past self for getting you this far. 💌 

We all deserve it.

content:
Lately, I've been feeling a lot of imposter syndrome. 

Searching for a job in a slow market is taking a toll on my self-esteem.

At the end of each day, I am confronted by my intense critical inner voice screaming at me for not doing enough.

It is not okay. 

Such moments signal the need to 𝘱𝘢𝘶𝘴𝘦 and 𝘳𝘦𝘧𝘭𝘦𝘤𝘵.

I have found a great practice to bring me back to center. 

Before I go to bed, I list at least 5 achievements of the day, small or big, that fill me with 𝐩𝐫𝐢𝐝𝐞. ❤️ 

I found it extremely beneficial and I want more people to try it. 

If you do it every day, you will: 

💙𝐑𝐞𝐬𝐭𝐨𝐫𝐞 𝐤𝐢𝐧𝐝𝐧𝐞𝐬𝐬.This will remind you that you are doing the best you can with what you have now. And you should probably be a lot more gentler with yourself. 🫶🏻

💙 𝐁𝐨𝐨𝐬𝐭 𝐜𝐨𝐧𝐟𝐢𝐝𝐞𝐧𝐜𝐞. Seeing a tangible list of accomplishments can clear the clouds of self-doubt and reignite your motivation and drive. 🏃‍♀️

💙𝐏𝐫𝐨𝐯𝐢𝐝𝐞 𝐜𝐥𝐚𝐫𝐢𝐭𝐲. Allow deeper reflection on what you have learned and how you have grown, ensuring continuous personal and professional development.🎯

💙 𝐁𝐮𝐢𝐥𝐝 𝐚 𝐫𝐞𝐜𝐨𝐫𝐝 𝐨𝐟 𝐬𝐮𝐜𝐜𝐞𝐬𝐬: It will be incredibly uplifting to look back on this accumulated list of projects, skillsets, and learnings from mistakes during challenging times and when you need a reminder of your journey and growth. 🏆 

💙 𝐈𝐧𝐯𝐢𝐭𝐞 𝐠𝐫𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐭𝐮𝐝𝐞: Choose to see your effort and generate gratitude for yourself and for the support you received along the way.  💌 


This practice serves as a reminder that you are indeed doing the best you can with what you have. 


Be gentle with yourself.

name: Meri Nova

content:
Large context windows will NOT replace RAG.
Here is why. 👇

So many people believe that, as foundation models expand their large context windows (LCW), RAG will become obsolete. This is a common misconception that overlooks the unique benefits of RAG such as: 

1. 𝐑𝐞𝐥𝐞𝐯𝐚𝐧𝐜𝐞 𝐅𝐢𝐥𝐭𝐞𝐫𝐢𝐧𝐠: A large context window might process a lot of data, but it doesn't inherently filter for relevance. RAG retrieves only the most relevant documents from a database, ensuring the query has the most useful context. 

2. 𝐒𝐜𝐚𝐥𝐚𝐛𝐢𝐥𝐢𝐭𝐲 𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐄𝐟𝐟𝐢𝐜𝐢𝐞𝐧𝐜𝐲: Loading entire datasets into a model's context window is impractical and expensive, especially when dealing with real-time, dynamic content. RAG's structure lets you store and retrieve vast knowledge bases on demand, using only what's necessary to answer a query. 

3. 𝐌𝐞𝐦𝐨𝐫𝐲 𝐋𝐢𝐦𝐢𝐭𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧𝐬: Even the largest context windows are finite and can quickly be overwhelmed by extensive data sources. RAG sidesteps this by retrieving just the right context at each step, ensuring that even smaller models with limited memory can access a nearly limitless knowledge base.

4. 𝐓𝐨𝐤𝐞𝐧 𝐄𝐟𝐟𝐢𝐜𝐢𝐞𝐧𝐜𝐲 𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐋𝐚𝐭𝐞𝐧𝐜𝐲: Extending context length comes at a cost. Each additional token in a model’s input requires more processing power, increases latency, and drives up expenses. RAG is more efficient by using fewer tokens overall, focusing only on the most pertinent data, and reducing computational costs without compromising performance.

...

While LCWs allow models to process more information in a single prompt, they don’t solve the challenges of efficiency, relevance, or scalability that RAG does so well!

Keep that in mind when developing AI-driven applications. 

...

If you want to learn more about building a RAG system, check out my new course on RAG with Langchain on the DataCamp's platform!


You can start the first chapter for free here, once you register.  - https://lnkd.in/gnGXMkTe

name: Meri Nova

content:
I used to be ashamed of how my ADHD brain worked. 
"You never finish what you start, Meri!" 
I was told so often it became part of my identity. 

Back then I did not even know what ADHD was. 

In my late teens, I started noticing how fast I would pick up a new skillset.

It would take only 3-4 months to learn a local language whenever I moved. Like Chinese and German. While some of my friends would take years. 


However, I would dissociate a lot during classes and get kicked out for being a class clown.
I knew I had "a little bit" more of chaotic energy in me than in others.


I also had a hard time focusing on "boring" things. Like Excel. 
I thought, my brain was just slow or weird. 


Finally, after numerous nudges from friends earlier this year, 
I made an appointment with a psychiatrist and got officially diagnosed with "extreme case of ADHD" at the age of 27. 


To say it changed my life is to say the least.
Now I understand my behaviors without underlying shame or judgement for being different. 


My self-esteem has improved significantly since then. 


I now prioritize understanding my brain's natural inclinations instead of forcing it to be "normal".


To give you an idea. 


Nowadays, I allow myself to engage in at least 3 of these activities at any given day: 

- Building Python Bots 
- Analyzing Personal Data
- Brainstorming content ideas
- Taking Data Science course
- Writing content
- Creating a video for IG or Tikok


The ADHD brain thrives on curiosity and novelty! 
Seeking variety in your work will make you feel more fulfilled and successful. Reducing the boredom friction is critical for job satisfaction.

----


What hobby projects are you working on to satisfy your brain itch?

#adhd #adhdbrain #mentalhealth

name: Meri Nova

content:
ChatGPT exploded to 100 million monthly active users within 60 days of its launch. That led to 5 unprecedented engineering challenges. 
Here is how they solved them to continue scaling. 


1.  Balance of Memory and Computing Power
Challenge: The "self-attention" mechanism in ChatGPT meant computational demands grew quadratically as conversations got longer.
Solution: The team implemented a sophisticated "Key Value cache" system to store previous computations in the limited GPU memory, reducing the need for recomputation.

2. Optimizing for Arithmetic Intensity 
Challenge: Ensuring the GPUs were being used as efficiently as possible, balancing compute power and memory bandwidth.
Solution: The team carefully tuned the "batch size" - the number of requests processed at once - to maximize the ratio of floating-point operations to data movement.

3. Finding the Right Metrics
Challenge: Traditional performance metrics didn't provide the necessary visibility into the system's bottlenecks.
Solution: The team developed new monitoring approaches, focusing on KV cache utilization and cache miss rates, to identify and address the unique challenges of large language models.

4. GPU Scarcity
Challenge: The powerful NVIDIA GPUs needed were in incredibly short supply.
Solution: The team sourced these critical hardware components from a global network of cloud providers, managing a distributed and heterogeneous GPU fleet.

5. Limits to Growth
Challenge: Ultimately, there was only so much hardware available to scale the system.
Solution: The team had to carefully manage capacity and, at times, restrict access to ensure the system remained available and responsive for users.

...

It is pretty cool to see the behind-the-scenes of this historical engineering moment. 


If you want to read more about it, check out Gergely Orosz's article on "Scaling ChatGPT: Five Real-World Engineering Challenges". 

.

What we thought Generative AI would do for us:

- Replace entire job sectors, leading to massive unemployment
- Make traditional machine learning obsolete
- Operate as standalone systems, handling all tasks autonomously with (AGI)
- Solve complex global issues like climate change and resource scarcity 
- Eliminate the need for human creativity in arts and literature

What it is currently doing for us:

- Working alongside humans to improve productivity and decision-making 
- Enhancing traditional ML with synthetic data and better feature engineering
- Complementing classical ML techniques, forming powerful hybrid ensemble systems 
- Accelerating scientific research and drug discovery 
- Augmenting human creativity through powerful brainstorming tools


Contrary to popular belief, AI is not stealing our jobs.
Instead, it is empowering us to address more pressing and complex problems.
