name: Meri Nova

content:
Yesterday, we talked about the positive effects of consistent learning. 🧠 
But do you know what has the most impact on our cognitive functions? 
It is our often forgotten - nervous system! 

Your efficiency as a learner  largely depends on your day-to-day neurological condition. 

What does this all mean? 


According to a Polyvagal Theory, our bodies operate in 1 of 3 nervous system states:


- Ventral Vagal State: This is a state of safety, marked by calmness, joy, and a sense of connection. It supports better digestion, immune response. 

For example. You are in this state, when writing code, analyzing data, reading or socializing with colleagues during lunch. 



- Sympathetic State: Known as the fight or flight response, it's associated with feelings of anxiety, agitation, or heightened energy. 
This state leads to increased blood pressure, heart rate, and adrenaline, but hampers digestion. 

For example, you experience this when working on urgent project deadlines or responding to emergencies during on-call duties.



- Dorsal Vagal State:This shutdown response is linked with feelings of dissociation, helplessness, or depression, conserving energy and increasing the pain threshold. It often occurs after burnout or as a response to trauma.

For example, you might feel this way after months of strenuous work that did not lead to any results. 
It can also be a common response to a childhood trauma or burnout in adulthood. 




Unfortunately, many people live in a dorsal vagal state mistaking it for laziness or general apathy. 

Or in the sympathetic state, constantly stressed out and on the edge, thinking it helps them move them forward. 


As adults, we often forget that neither of these states is necessary for leading ambitious careers and fulfilling lives.
In fact, the opposite is true. Being in the Ventral Vagal State allows us to:

- Process and retain information more effectively.
- Recover and restore efficiently from physical and mental strains.
- Be more present and engaged with the important people in our lives.


Simply put, the more time you spend in Ventral Vagal State the more sustainable progress you can make. 

I am writing this in hopes of encouraging self-awareness and self-regulation as a continuous form of self care. 

This approach will not only enhance your own life but also massively impact those around you. 

Remember your well-being is our well-being!



——


What do you do daily to regulate your own nervous system? 

#mentalhealth #neuroscience
name: Meri Nova

content:
You are NOT a Data Scientist if you never pushed to production. Master these MLops basics to get ahead in today's competitive job market. 👇


1. 𝐕𝐞𝐫𝐬𝐢𝐨𝐧 𝐂𝐨𝐧𝐭𝐫𝐨𝐥. 
If you are deploying models in production, you need a way to track changes, collaborate with others, and manage your codebase efficiently. 
🛠️ You can use GitHub, Azure DevOps, and GitLab, MLflow for this. 


2. 𝐂𝐈/𝐂𝐃.
Deployment should only happen through your automated integration and unit tests running on your CI/CD pipelines. 
🛠️ You can use Github Actions, GitLab CI/CD, and Jenkins to ensure that new code is tested and deployed efficiently with every new change. 


3. 𝐂𝐨𝐧𝐭𝐚𝐢𝐧𝐞𝐫𝐢𝐳𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧
Docker is an open-source containerization platform that allows you to build, package, and run applications inside lightweight, isolated containers so that your code can run in any environment. 


4. 𝐊𝐮𝐛𝐞𝐫𝐧𝐞𝐭𝐞𝐬
Kubernetes is a container orchestration system that automates the deployment, scaling, and management across multiple hosts. It builds upon Docker's containerization to provide advanced features at scale.

🛠️ You can use VPS for hosting your isolated software environments. 
I recommend starting with something straightforward like - https://lnkd.in/d3qcNA6r   


5. 𝐎𝐫𝐜𝐡𝐞𝐬𝐭𝐫𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧
Orchestration ensures that all components of the ML pipeline are executed in the correct order and that resources are efficiently utilized.
🛠️ You can use Kubeflow or Airflow. 


6. 𝐌𝐨𝐧𝐢𝐭𝐨𝐫𝐢𝐧𝐠 
Monitoring enables maintenance and helps detect issues such as model drift, performance degradation, and anomalies, allowing for timely interventions and retraining.
🛠️ You can use tools like SPLUNK, Sagemaker, Evidently etc. 


📚 If you want to learn more, sign up for the newsletter - https://lnkd.in/gEMeG9GV  
Tomorrow, I will release a complete guide on how to select an ML model for production.

name: Meri Nova

content:
It’s never too late to change your career.  I know someone who transitioned to tech in just 4 months and another person who did it in 2 years. 

Don't compare your timeline with others.

It may take a little longer for you and that is okay. 

It doesn't mean you are not smart enough. 

It means there are invisible circumstances that can slow us down.

For instance. 

Over the weekend, I found myself regretting not starting sooner.

I wished I had studied CS instead of Business. 

And had taken SQL and Python seriously in my early 20s.

When I shared these thoughts with a friend, he said something that changed my perspective:

“Meri, when you compare your timeline to others, you’re disrespecting your own journey.”

That struck a chord with me.

I remembered all the obstacles I faced since I left home when I was 15. 

And the wrong environments I frequently found myself. 

No matter how old you are. 

It is never too late to dedicate 6 months to learning a new skill. 

And to transition into a better-paying field. 

Instead of dwelling on past mistakes, we should be grateful for the opportunities we have today and stay consistent with our progress.

Keep learning and showing up every day.  

You are never alone. ❤️
name: Meri Nova

content:
Being a generalist is not something to be ashamed of!

Lots of people think that to be a successful engineer you need to specialize in one domain/ tech stack/ language/. 

When in reality, generalists make everyone else's life 10x easier, because: 

- they know everyone else's stack and can lead end-to-end projects 
- they pave the road by learning first and teaching others. 
- they find new opportunities by constantly experimenting and prototyping 
- they adapt to new tech faster than anyone else and establish new standards

This is not to say we shouldn't encourage mastery in a specific domain. 
In fact, all of us should strive to build niche expertise, but we shouldn't dismiss those who are willing to explore new territories for all of us. 

Let's encourage one another to stay open and curious about different engineering disciplines, especially in this rapidly evolving ML / AI landscape.
name: Meri Nova

content:
Implementing LLM into your applications does NOT have to be hard. 
It took us 1 week to finish the integration within our open source project. 
Here is how we did it. 

We have a Discord Community "𝐁𝐫𝐞𝐚𝐤 𝐈𝐧𝐭𝐨 𝐃𝐚𝐭𝐚" with an Accountability System that uses Discords' API. 

In that system, a user commits to a goal. 🎯 

Let's say: "Solve 3 Leetcode challenges a day and/or run 5km a day."

Our bot then tracks the submissions and creates a leaderboard. 🏆 

𝐓𝐡𝐞 𝐩𝐫𝐨𝐛𝐥𝐞𝐦 with our old system was - it didn't track granular metrics, like the number of problems solved, the amount of time spent exercising, etc. 

And we did not want to create a separate form for each type of submission. 🙄  

Then we had a eureka moment! 🌋 

Why don't we try using LLMs. 

After playing with ChatGPT and asking it to create CSV file from text.
It was clear that results can be sustainable. 👍 


So here is the breakdown of our approach: 

𝐖𝐡𝐚𝐭 𝐢𝐬 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐩𝐫𝐨𝐛𝐥𝐞𝐦❓
Parse user's text messages as individual submissions into our database, without asking them to follow any format, like a form. 

𝐖𝐡𝐲 𝐋𝐋𝐌❓
Is your problem worth the LLM integration?  Keep in mind that it will significantly increase your application maintenance costs. 
LLM made sense because it allowed us to keep natural flow of the conversation within Discord channels, which improves engagement. 

𝐇𝐨𝐰 𝐭𝐨 𝐢𝐧𝐭𝐞𝐠𝐫𝐚𝐭𝐞❓
First outline the user flow and identify 𝐈𝐍𝐏𝐔𝐓 and 𝐎𝐔𝐓𝐏𝐔𝐓 data for the LLM. 

In our case, we wanted the 𝐈𝐍𝐏𝐔𝐓 to be: 
User's text message and their data from relevant dimensional tables in our DB. 
The input data goes into the prompt with each API request. 

The 𝐎𝐔𝐓𝐏𝐔𝐓 would be: 
A CSV file to give us a more reliable structure for data entry. 


We just published a complete walkthrough of this project. Make sure to read and subscribe here - https://lnkd.in/gySriuXu

If you are interested in contributing or using this feature join the Discord Server here - https://lnkd.in/gP8Pyyv4

name: Meri Nova

content:
THIS interview question gets asked ALL the time. 
It's on ✨ 𝐁𝐚𝐲𝐞𝐬 𝐓𝐡𝐞𝐨𝐫𝐞𝐦✨. 
Let's tackle it with a funny scenario:

It's 5 pm on a Friday, and somebody from the office parked their brand-new Tesla truck in the wrong spot ❗ 

We need to figure out whether it's the Chief Data Officer(CDO) of the company or one of the Data Analysts.

We do not want to bother CDO and risk getting fired. 

So we decided to calculate the probability using the Bayes Theorem. 

Naturally, we might assume it's her, because she makes significantly more money to afford the Tesla truck. 

But Bayes Theorem is all about incorporating existing data into the circumstance.

In our case, there are 20 Data Analysts and only 1 CDO in the office.

Moreover, Elon was kind enough to share his data with us. And now we know that at least 10% of all Data Analysts and 40% of all CDOs in the USA have a Tesla Truck.

Using Bayes' theorem, we calculate,
P(H∣E), the probability of the hypothesis given the evidence:

𝑃(𝐻∣𝐸) = 𝑃(𝐻)𝑃(𝐸∣𝐻)  /  P(E∣H)×P(H)+P(E∣¬H)×P(¬H)

in short... 

𝑃(𝐻∣𝐸) = 𝑃(𝐻)𝑃(𝐸∣𝐻) / 𝑃(𝐸)

In this case:

▪ H represents the hypothesis that the person is the Chief Data Officer (CDO).

▪ E represents the total probability of the evidence that the person has a Tesla truck.

From the image, you can see that the answer is 16.67% which means: 

It is 16.67% likely that the truck belongs to CDO. 

Which means we should probably not bother her first.  😝 


P.S. I loved making these. 
Let me know if it helps in the comments ❤️ 


​ ♻ Share with your network. 
📲 Follow for more content like this.

name: Meri Nova

content:
Sparse and Dense retrieval methods are fundamentally different! 

*This is for you if you are building RAG systems.


Sparse retrieval (Term-Based):

- focuses on matching query keywords directly within documents.
- ideal for finding documents with exact phrases like "ML engineering."
- uses inverted indices for quick lookups; optimized for high-speed retrieval 
- uses TF-IDF and BM25
- typically cheaper since indexing is less compute-intensive.


Dense retrieval (Embedding-Based):

- embeds text in vector spaces to retrieve similar meanings, not just matching words.
- effective when meaning is more critical than keywords
- high-performance, but slower retrieval 
- requires vector storage (e.g., FAISS) for efficient nearest-neighbor search.
- higher cost due to embedding generation and vector storage, especially with frequently updated data

7. Knowledge Graphs: We've connected all the dots. Now, if only our LLM could follow them…

8. AI Ethics: The topic we all pretend to care about but secretly find it to be the least exciting.

content:
The more I say “NO” to others. 
The more I am disliked.

You see, I am a recovering people pleaser. 

“Yes” - was my default answer to almost every request. 

This led to mental, emotional, and physical exhaustion from constantly going the extra mile for others


The worst part? People often remained unsatisfied and expected more.
Each time, I ended up feeling miserable, unappreciated and hurt.


This holiday season is testing me again. 
However, this time around, after months of weekly therapy, I'm taking a different approach.


I'm learning to say 'NO'.

And you know what?
I'm hated more than ever...


But I choose to embrace it. 


I embrace it, because, I am discovering my own STRENGTH.
The strength to be OKAY with being DISLIKED. 
The strength to choose ME and my health over manipulative demands of others. 


I am building new neural pathways and habits that benefit my mental health. 
I am taking control of my time and energy, the way I see fit. 
I am now an adult, taking responsibility for my own life. 


—-

Choosing yourself means learning to say ‘NO’ to others.
Initially, you will feel like you're letting people down. 
And some may label you as selfish, mean, or narcissistic even. 

But hold your ground and keep going.
Make a daily commitment to choose yourself.
In time, you will see remarkable growth in confidence and self-esteem. 
That will light the path to your true potential.

content:
I changed 7 schools and 4 countries by the time I turned 18. 

This transformed my brain and mind forever. 

I grew up in an entrepreneurial household. 

My dad believed if I changed my environment every year, I would grow up resilient and strong.



Here is how my childhood went: 


Grades 1-6: Attended School #13 in Bishkek.
Grade 7: Transferred to School #70.
Grade 8: Expelled, moved to School #67.
Grade 9: Changed schools again to escape “ the comfort zone”. 
Grade 10: Enrolled at Montana Institute in Switzerland, without speaking a word of English. 
Grade 11: Studied at Utahloy International School, China, without speaking a word of mandarin. 
Grade 12: Planned for a California high school; but visa rejection led to Silk Road International School in Bishkek instead. 

College: Hult International Business School in San Francisco, California. 




My journey was not optimized for academic success. 

It was about: 

- Thriving amidst constant change 
- Embracing different cultures
- Learning new languages as I learn new subjects at the same time
- Becoming a true global citizen. 



My unpredictable past was different from anyone else I knew. 

It made me appreciate lifelong learning and develop open-mindedness. 

Which is crucial to navigate career changes. 

Some may see this volatile childhood as setback. 

I view it as a set of unique strengths that I contribute to any room I enter.

content:
3 years ago, when I was 25, I decided to get a driver’s license in California. 

I decided not to prepare because I was a pretty good driver back home. Or so I thought. 

To my surprise, I didn’t even last my first 5 minutes there. I confused the hand signals. I was frustrated at this silly mistake. But scheduled the next exam immediately after. 

But on the next try, I failed again, because the examiner didn’t like my clumsy turns. I got upset, went back, and practiced more on turns. 

I scheduled the test for the 3rd time now. AND FAILED AGAIN! 
For completely different reasons. 

I won’t lie to you, it took me 6 trials before finally getting a pass. 
This frustrating journey could have been much shorter if I prepared in advance. 

But…

Did I take failures personally and stop trying? No, I didn't. 
I had to get my license no matter what. 

So my question to you is, why don't we approach our career goals with the same mindset? 

Imagine that you will inevitably get that new high-paying more fulfilling job. 

What would you do differently now? 

Stress less, enjoy the process more and ideally prepare better.

content:
If you were the devil, who is trying to stop people from landing their dream jobs in AI or ML, what would you encourage? Here is my answer 👇


I’d encourage these 10 destructive habits: 

1. I would instill the idea that only "geniuses" have access to this field. 

2. I would tell them to endlessly study theory without applying knowledge practically.

3. I would encourage beginners to compare themselves to experts every day. 

4. I would exaggerate the complexity of the field and let the confusing math notations stop from learning.

5. I would discourage participating in communities and collaborative projects, depriving people of crucial support and opportunities.

6. I would create endless distractions, like shiny new AI tools and libraries, that make people forget about fundamentals.

7. I would downplay the importance of communication skills and teamwork. 

8. I would let them believe that failure is bad and should be avoided at all costs. 

9. I would let them believe skills are fixed and can never be developed. 

10. I would nurture self-doubt every time they make a minor mistake leading to imposter syndrome. 

...

Now, ask yourself—are any of these habits secretly holding you back? 

Recognizing these habits is the first step to building a healthier mindset that brings you closer to your best and most authentic life.

name: Meri Nova

content:
Have you ever wondered who is behind the largest open-source frameworks?
And why should you even care? 

Many tools that we use daily were once born out of the frustrations of ordinary engineers, like you and me, who eventually decided to build better solutions and later revolutionized the entire industry. 

Here are some origin stories: 

- Apache Spark: Matei Zaharia and his team at UC Berkeley didn’t like the limitations of a linear dataflow structure of MapReduce, so they built Spark in 2009. The framework introduced Resilient Distributed Datasets (RDDs) which for the first time allowed in-memory processing for large-scale analytics. Today, it is used by 80% of Fortune 500 companies. 

Fun Fact. The logo represents its speed. 

- Apache Kafka: LinkedIn engineers Jay Kreps, Neha Narkhede, and Jun Rao were struggling with real-time data integration across their growing ecosystem of applications. In 2011, Kafka solved this by creating a distributed streaming platform capable of handling high-throughput, fault-tolerant pub/sub messaging. Today it is used by 100,000 organizations worldwide. 

Fun fact: Kafka is named after the author Franz Kafka, and its partitioned log model was inspired by Kafka's writing style.

- Apache Airflow: Maxime Beauchemin at Airbnb needed a way to programmatically author, schedule, and monitor complex data workflows. Airflow solved this in 2014 by providing a platform to create directed acyclic graphs (DAGs) of tasks, with rich scheduling and dependency management features. Today it is a Top data orchestration tool.

Fun fact: Airflow's mascot is a blue squirrel named "Squeaky," chosen because squirrels are known for their ability to plan and execute complex tasks.

…

Many do not know this, but the majority of private companies make their profits by leveraging these giant open-source frameworks. 

If you work at a large company that doesn’t contribute to open source, it probably doesn't want to attract the best engineering talent.

Time to make them contribute.

name: Meri Nova

content:
How to Apply The Central Limit Theorem to your job search. 👇

The Central Limit Theorem is a fundamental statistical concept and is widely applied in the business world. 
The good news is that it's a pretty simple one to understand!

Imagine you’re tracking the top skills required for data science roles across all job postings. 
You’ve collected data from hundreds of listings, but the information seems overwhelming and varied. 
This is where the CLT comes in handy.

𝐓𝐡𝐞 𝐤𝐞𝐲 𝐢𝐝𝐞𝐚: 

It states that the distribution of the sample means (averages) will tend to be normal (bell-shaped) if you take a sufficiently large number of samples, even if the original population distribution is not normal.

This means you do not have to waste time looking at hundreds of job postings to understand the core requirements for a Data Science job. 

Instead, use CLT! 

Here is how: 

1. Gather data on skills listed in job postings. Skills might include Python, SQL, machine learning, etc.
2. Take random samples of 30 job postings at a time. For each sample, count the frequency of each skill.
3. Calculate the average number of times each skill appears in these samples.

For ex. if you find that Python appears an average of 25 times with a standard deviation of 3 in your samples, you can infer that Python is highly sought after. If the sample mean for SQL is 5, then maybe you should stop focusing on it. 

Of course, this is a general take on the CLT and there are many more techniques to measure the validity of your hypothesis, like: 

- 𝐭-𝐓𝐞𝐬𝐭: Used to compare the means of two groups and determine if they are significantly different from each other.
- 𝐀𝐍𝐎𝐕𝐀 (Analysis of Variance): Extends the t-test to more than two groups, testing for differences in means across multiple groups.


If you find this post helpful...

👍 React
♻️ Share
💬 Comment

So more people can learn with simple explanations 👇

#datascience #statistics #jobsearch

Here is how I would learn Data Analytics in 2024:


- Find a dataset you are curious about. 
	(I like to use my personal data, e.g., Fitbit/Whoop API for my health data)

- Clean and process the data into a SQLAlchemy schema 

- Build aggregations and an exploratory data analysis using SQL or Pandas

- Ask additional questions. Be curious about the potential insights this dataset can provide. 

- Use Tableau or Matplotlib to visualize your analysis

- Set up a simple web app on Heroku server using Flask or Django

- Use HTML templates and present your findings and visualizations on that web app


----

For additional resources check out this Github repo - "Breaking Into Data".

Link is in the comment section.

content:
Stop wasting time and start building your ML portfolio like a pro. 
If you're struggling to land interviews, you might be making these crucial mistakes.

I wish I heard these tips when I was just starting out. 

They would have saved me a lot of time and provided clarity on building a solid portfolio.

Follow them here: 

1. Focus on quality over quantity. Instead of having 16 random Github repos, reduce it to 2-3 projects that align with each domain of your choice. 

2. Avoid using CSV files as a data source. I taught you better than that. There are hundreds of open APIs you should use.

3. Maintain a learning document for each project. Write down the challenges you faced while building the project and how you overcame them. This will truly set you apart during the interviews.

4. Once you finish the first version of an ML project, don't rush to start a new one. Instead, think about how you would deploy it with real-world constraints and industry demands. 

5. Be creative when sharing your project on Linkedin. Pro tip: Try to grasp attention in the first 1-2 sentences. I spend 80% of my time writing hooks on my post. Don't believe me? Go to my account and check all of my posts. 

...

name: Meri Nova

content:
Did you know that Large Language Models (LLMs) can handle more than just text and code?
Here is how LLMs are changing the Robotics field. 

Yesterday, Jason Ma, presented his research paper, Eureka, where he leverages LLMs to improve Reinforcement Learning (RL) techniques in robotics. 

I was intrigued by the presentation because it was relevant to my previous work. I also struggled with training a robotic arm to perform with precision. 

However, I never got a chance to work with the Reinforcement Learning (RL) model, which is a widely popular approach in autonomous driving that became popular after AlphaGo defeated a professional human player. 

But, Jason decided to take one step further and introduce LLMs to RL to tackle this tedious problem. 

In his paper, he uses language models to write reward functions at scale which are fed back to the RL model to help robots perform complex tasks, such as balancing on top of a yoga ball. See the video. 

How did he achieve it? 

Imagine this...

The probability of a robot landing in the right target pose can be 20% in one possible scenario. But if we use LLMs to generate 16 more ways to arrive at that pose, we have a significantly better probability, increasing the success rate to over 90%. 

Typically, designing these reward functions is manually intensive and relies heavily on domain expertise and trial-and-error adjustments.

The cool thing about Eureka is that the system can generate reward functions for previously unseen tasks by leveraging LLMs, and do it at scale. 

Thank you Jay Yao, Peter Danenberg and Justin Woo for organizing these events and introducing great research!

If you are a tinkerer...

🕹️ You can run his code on a simulation here -> https://lnkd.in/gtJNtU2d 

🌎  And If you have a  robot use this repo -> https://lnkd.in/gn6AZPwc

name: Meri Nova

content:
San Francisco gives me anxiety. 
Everyone is trying to board a 1.3 trillion dollar AI rocket ship. 
Meanwhile, I was preoccupied with self-doubt and only now waking up to it. 

Yesterday, I had a hot debate with my talented friends about the current AI frenzy and how to be part of it. 
They are successful Research Engineers and Managers at rapidly scaling AI startups. 
So I wanted to ask them how to land an AI Research Engineering job that I'd love.

I was pleasantly surprised by the advice they gave to me:

🚀 𝐅𝐨𝐜𝐮𝐬 𝐨𝐧 𝐁𝐨𝐚𝐫𝐝𝐢𝐧𝐠: View the GenAI field as a rocket ship; your primary objective is to simply GET ON BOARD. Don't focus on the role, compensation, and other perks.  Focus on getting your foot through the door. 

🚀 𝐑𝐞𝐥𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧𝐬𝐡𝐢𝐩𝐬 𝐓𝐫𝐮𝐦𝐩 𝐓𝐢𝐭𝐥𝐞𝐬: Don't look at titles. Look at companies in general. Once you're in the door, build relationships with decision-makers and demonstrate your adaptability and eagerness to learn; you can always pivot to your desired position within the company. 

🚀 𝐄𝐦𝐛𝐫𝐚𝐜𝐞 𝐎𝐩𝐩𝐨𝐫𝐭𝐮𝐧𝐢𝐭𝐢𝐞𝐬: After our conversation, I  realized I was focusing on whether the rocket ship will like me or whether I am good enough for it. Which now sounds hilarious to me. 😆 Become conscious of these self-deprecating thoughts. They cloud your vision so much so that you will stop seeing endless opportunities around you. 


Regularly get out of your own head and change your perspective. 
See your dream job as an opportunity to seize and a goal to chase. 
Be ready to face various challenges to achieve it. 


---
Remember, 

It is not about you. 

It is about the prize. 

---

How do you get out of your own way?

name: Meri Nova

content:
Latency vs Throughput. 
What's the difference? 
If you know it, you probably have a job.

Every single engineering team optimizes for these metrics. 

And here is everything you need to know about them. 


- 𝐋𝐚𝐭𝐞𝐧𝐜𝐲 🏎️ 
Refers to the time it takes for a single request to be processed by a system or an ML model. 

𝘍𝘢𝘤𝘵𝘰𝘳𝘴 𝘢𝘧𝘧𝘦𝘤𝘵𝘪𝘯𝘨 𝘭𝘢𝘵𝘦𝘯𝘤𝘺: 

1. ML model and infrastructure complexity
2. Hardware: The computational power of the servers (CPU, GPU, etc.) 
3. Data Transfer: The time it takes to transfer data to and from the model, including network latency.
4. Software practices:  Efficient coding practices and optimizations (e.g., pruning, quantization) help reduce latency. 


- 𝐓𝐡𝐫𝐨𝐮𝐠𝐡𝐩𝐮𝐭 🤹🏻
Refers to how many queries/requests are processed in a specific time.

𝘍𝘢𝘤𝘵𝘰𝘳𝘴 𝘢𝘧𝘧𝘦𝘤𝘵𝘪𝘯𝘨 𝘵𝘩𝘳𝘰𝘶𝘨𝘩𝘱𝘶𝘵:

1. Concurrency: Handling multiple requests simultaneously with parallel processing and multi-threading.
2. Resource Allocation: Proper allocation of computational resources (CPU, GPU, memory) 
3. Scalability: The capability to scale horizontally by adding more machines or vertically by upgrading hardware.
4. Batch Processing: Processing in batches improves throughput by reducing the overhead.


In general...

If you work in research you care more about throughput. 
In production, however, you focus on latency. 

Every ms your program takes hurts your sales and conversion rates. 

If you know how to optimize for both you will always be desirable in the industry. 

---

If you find this helpful:

👍 React
♻️ Share
💬 Comment

So more people can learn.

---

name: Meri Nova

content:
Before writing a single line of code for your ML project, answer these questions first. 
This will help you understand which model you need: 


1. 𝗜𝗱𝗲𝗻𝘁𝗶𝗳𝘆 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗖𝗮𝘁𝗲𝗴𝗼𝗿𝘆 𝗼𝗳 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗣𝗿𝗼𝗯𝗹𝗲𝗺: Labeled vs unlabeled.

- Supervised Learning: Used when you have labeled data. Common tasks include classification (e.g., spam detection) and regression (e.g., predicting house prices).

- Unsupervised Learning: Used when you have unlabeled data. Common tasks include clustering (e.g., customer segmentation) and association (e.g., market basket analysis).


2. 𝐃𝐞𝐭𝐞𝐫𝐦𝐢𝐧𝐞 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐓𝐚𝐬𝐤 𝐚𝐭 𝐡𝐚𝐧𝐝:

To choose the right model you need to understand the task: 

- Classification: Assigning data to predefined categories (e.g., image recognition).
- Regression: Predicting continuous values (e.g., stock prices).
- Clustering: Grouping similar data points (e.g., segmenting users based on behavior).
- Dimensionality Reduction: Reducing the number of features (e.g., PCA for feature extraction).
- Recommender Systems: Suggesting items to users (e.g., movie recommendations)

3. 𝗗𝗲𝗳𝗶𝗻𝗲 𝗠𝗲𝘁𝗿𝗶𝗰𝘀 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗗𝗲𝗽𝗹𝗼𝘆𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁 𝗦𝘂𝗰𝗰𝗲𝘀𝘀

- How important is accuracy? 
- What about inferencing or training speed?
- Scalability and reproducibility?
- What about the cost of model training and inferencing?


If you want to learn more about Selecting the right ML model, read today's article - https://lnkd.in/gnRcmhTS

If you don't follow these ATS rules in your resume, you are missing lots of opportunities. 

5 must-haves for an ATS-optimized resume. 

☝️ A clear and powerful summary:
start with a 2–3 sentence statement highlighting your skills, experience, and goals. (Must be in bullet points!)

✌️ Quantifiable achievements:
always use numbers and results to show your impact (e.g., “Increased sales by 30% in 6 months after improving predictive analytics pipeline”).

🤟 Keywords tailored to the job:
align your resume with the job description to pass ATS scans and grab recruiter attention.

🖖 Every word counts:
eliminate common and unnecessary skills like leadership, problem-solving, and adaptability that every other candidate has. 

🖐️ A clean, professional design:
easy-to-read formatting with consistent fonts, bullet points, and no clutter.


Your resume is your first impression. 

Make it count.

name: Meri Nova

content:
How are you supposed to get any work done when people are getting fired left and right ? 

Most people in corporate America, especially in tech don’t have any psychological safety. 

And who can blame them? 

When one day you are sharing your weekend updates over lunch with a collegue and the next day you are told you will never see them again. 

Then they change your job, your manager or your team and call it restructuring. 

And each time it happens, you try to numb yourself and dissociate a little more. 

I think we made it waaaay too normal. 

But it doesn’t have to be. 

Did you know that in Netherlands you need to come to a mutual agreement before firing an employee? 

Or get approval from local court and employment agency, which usually takes months. 

This makes the hiring processes a lot more intentional from the get-go. 

Believe it or not, safety is a number 1 requirement for humans on a Maslow’s hierarchy.  

Without it; there is no creativity, no sense of comradery and no inspiration. ❗️

Which are all of the fundamental traits of high performing teams. 


Let’s do better, corporate America. 


—- 


How do you deal with lack of psychological safety in the workplace?

name: Meri Nova

content:
Consistent learning changes your brain through neuroplasticity. 

It’s an easy buzzword to throw around. But few actually know what happens when you leverage it.

This is how your brain transforms when you consistently learn something for 30 days : 

It will become sharper ⚡️

- Myelination: Consistent learning develops the fatty layer called myelin around your brain neurons. This in turn speeds up the transmission of electrical signals in the brain. Which helps you use your practiced skills more efficiently. 

It will become faster 💨

- Improved attention and concentration: with each repetition you lessen the initial friction to get into “the deep focus zone”. Which means over time you will become even a faster learner! 

You’ll become more confident 💪🏼

- Cognitive and behavioral changes: Doing hard things and solving complex tasks daily, tells your brain that you have a higher capacity to accomplish things.  It has a dramatic positive influence in your motivation, persistence and resilience! 


If there is a day with no learning, it is a a sad day.


What skills are you working on these days?

name: Meri Nova

content:
The secret to building successful AI systems isn’t about finding the best model - it’s about catching the 1,000 ways it could fail. 

Imagine this. 

You’ve deployed your AI app. 
It’s fine-tuned, performs well on benchmarks, and looks ready to scale.

But after a while, it suddenly starts failing 1 out of 100 times when interacting with users.

Users are losing trust and leaving your app!
At scale, this small failure rate can destroy your business.

Most often, in this case, the problem isn’t the model—it’s the lack of a robust evaluation system (evals).

And the best way to build effective evals today is by using LLMs-as-a-judge!

Here’s why:

- Domain-Specific: taylor to the metrics that matter most to you.
- Scalable: evaluate 1000s of outputs quickly without a large team.
- Consistent: eliminate variability and bias in scoring.
- Creative: test for nuanced qualities like ethics, tone, or even creativity.

Do you want to get real hands-on experience building evals? 

Then, we’ve got something special prepared for you:

This Saturday, Hai N., who is an experienced AI founder and LangChain Ambassador, will lead an exclusive coding workshop at Break Into Data.

If you’re serious about building AI systems that work in the real world, this is your chance to learn from an expert.

By the end of the workshop, you’ll have the tools and knowledge to:

- build robust evaluation systems 
- stand out in the competitive AI job market with real-world skills.
- create AI systems that scale without breaking trust.

📅 When: This Saturday at 12 PM Pacific Time
🎟️ Tickets: Only 38/50 seats left!

🎁 As a bonus: You will receive a free step-by-step guide to building LLM-as-a-judge systems. 

Grab your ticket now before it’s too late: https://lnkd.in/gGCh_Msm
name: Meri Nova

content:
How does interview process for a Data Science position look like? 🤔 

Here's an outline for a typical process.

It can vary significantly based on the company's size, industry, and specific needs.However, there are some common elements you can expect:


1️⃣ 𝐀𝐩𝐩𝐥𝐢𝐜𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧 𝐑𝐞𝐯𝐢𝐞𝐰: 1-2 𝘸𝘦𝘦𝘬𝘴
Resume and cover letter screening.

2️⃣ 𝐈𝐧𝐢𝐭𝐢𝐚𝐥 𝐂𝐨𝐧𝐭𝐚𝐜𝐭:1 𝘸𝘦𝘦𝘬
Brief HR or recruiter phone call/screening.
Discussion of the candidate's background and interest in the position.

3️⃣ 𝐓𝐞𝐜𝐡𝐧𝐢𝐜𝐚𝐥 𝐏𝐡𝐨𝐧𝐞 𝐒𝐜𝐫𝐞𝐞𝐧:1-2 𝘸𝘦𝘦𝘬𝘴 𝘢𝘧𝘵𝘦𝘳 𝘪𝘯𝘪𝘵𝘪𝘢𝘭 𝘤𝘰𝘯𝘵𝘢𝘤𝘵
Conducted by a data scientist or hiring manager.
Discussion of technical skills, previous projects, and problem-solving approach.
May include technical questions or a brief coding exercise.

4️⃣ 𝐓𝐚𝐤𝐞-𝐇𝐨𝐦𝐞 𝐀𝐬𝐬𝐢𝐠𝐧𝐦𝐞𝐧𝐭: 1-2 𝘸𝘦𝘦𝘬𝘴
Candidates are given a data set and asked to perform analysis, build a model, or generate insights.Aimed at assessing technical proficiency, creativity, and ability to derive meaningful conclusions from data.

5️⃣ 𝐎𝐧-𝐬𝐢𝐭𝐞 𝐈𝐧𝐭𝐞𝐫𝐯𝐢𝐞𝐰𝐬 (𝐨𝐫 𝐕𝐢𝐫𝐭𝐮𝐚𝐥 𝐈𝐧𝐭𝐞𝐫𝐯𝐢𝐞𝐰𝐬 𝐢𝐧 𝐬𝐨𝐦𝐞 𝐜𝐚𝐬𝐞𝐬):2-4 𝘸𝘦𝘦𝘬𝘴 𝘢𝘧𝘵𝘦𝘳 𝘵𝘢𝘬𝘦-𝘩𝘰𝘮𝘦 𝘢𝘴𝘴𝘪𝘨𝘯𝘮𝘦𝘯𝘵
A series of interviews with team members, including data scientists, managers, and potential cross-functional collaborators.
Technical rounds include coding, statistical questions, machine learning concepts, and case studies.
Behavioral interviews focus on soft skills, teamwork, communication, and cultural fit.

6️⃣ 𝐏𝐫𝐞𝐬𝐞𝐧𝐭𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧 𝐨𝐫 𝐂𝐚𝐬𝐞 𝐒𝐭𝐮𝐝𝐲: 
Some companies may require a presentation of the take-home assignment or a separate case study.
Evaluation of communication skills, ability to explain technical concepts, and approach to problem-solving.

7️⃣ 𝐅𝐢𝐧𝐚𝐥 𝐈𝐧𝐭𝐞𝐫𝐯𝐢𝐞𝐰: 1 𝘸𝘦𝘦𝘬 𝘢𝘧𝘵𝘦𝘳 𝘰𝘯-𝘴𝘪𝘵𝘦 𝘪𝘯𝘵𝘦𝘳𝘷𝘪𝘦𝘸𝘴
With senior management or key stakeholders.
Focus on overall fit within the company, career aspirations, and alignment with company values.

8️⃣ 𝐑𝐞𝐟𝐞𝐫𝐞𝐧𝐜𝐞 𝐂𝐡𝐞𝐜𝐤: 1 𝘸𝘦𝘦𝘬
Conducted by HR or the hiring manager.
Verification of work history, skills, and character from previous employers or academic advisors.

9️⃣ 𝐉𝐨𝐛 𝐎𝐟𝐟𝐞𝐫 𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐍𝐞𝐠𝐨𝐭𝐢𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧:1-2 𝘸𝘦𝘦𝘬𝘴 
Presentation of the job offer, including salary, benefits, and other terms.
Potential negotiation on terms of the offer.

🔟 𝐎𝐧𝐛𝐨𝐚𝐫𝐝𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐏𝐫𝐨𝐜𝐞𝐬𝐬:
Introduction to the team, training, and integration into the company.


In total, the process can take anywhere from 6 weeks to 3 months or more. Some processes move faster, especially in smaller companies or startups.

--

Was your experience similar? 


#datascience #interview #softwaredevelopment #jobhunt

name: Meri Nova

content:
Most people won't tell you this. 
But stop underestimating the amount of work it takes to transition to a career in Data.

Yesterday, I had a chat with one of our upcoming guest speakers for Break Into Data.

She just landed her first data science job a year ago at a major corporation in California, and her journey was eye-opening for me. 

She previously was a data analyst but always dreamed of becoming a data scientist. 

So she went to get her Master's Degree. 

During her second semester of grad school, all of her classmates were getting job offers—everyone 𝐞𝐱𝐜𝐞𝐩𝐭 𝐡𝐞𝐫.

That’s when she realized SOMETHING needs to be done. 

So she decided to hire a consultancy firm that offered unlimited mock interviews...

And that’s when the real work began. 

She then quickly realized she couldn't pass  Statistics and Product Sense questions at all.

So, what did she do? 

She finally started to work with people and completed:

- 🤯 30 mock interviews. 
- 📋 25 resume reviews from different professionals. 
- 🗣️ 100s of mentorship calls  with other Data Scientists

The moral of her story?

❗️Lower your expectations❗️

And talk to 10x more people than you currently are.


----


If you can't find a good network, join  Break Into Data. 
Follow this invite to join - https://lnkd.in/gQmzFdyk



If you want to get more insights from our speakers, sign up for the newsletter -
merinova.substack.com
name: Meri Nova

content:
"You are not a beggar when you interview for a job. 
You are a hot chick at the bar." 
This is one of the many advice I received yesterday at Break Into Data.

When we experience continous rejections we unconsciously try to get the first opportunity without realizing how much value we bring. 

Here are some questions you can ask from potential employers: 

- Why did the previous employee leave? 
- How would you describe the company culture? 
- How many meetings does the role require you to have? 

Remember, it is not a test. 

It is a date. 

Thank you, Kelly Adams, Zach Wilson, Madhav Bhatia, Mishahal Palakuniyil, and Mert Bozkir for yesterday's private panel discussion! 

---

What questions do you ask during the interviews?

name: Meri Nova

content:
ADHD is not a superpower. 

Especially if you are trying to build a career. 


☔ It is difficult to stay organized and manage time on a daily basis. 
There are only 2 perceptions of time for ADHD people: '𝐧𝐨𝐰' or '𝐧𝐨𝐭 𝐧𝐨𝐰'.
Time management and prioritzation is almost an impossible task. 

☔ It is easy to get swayed. I am never able to complete any course, because
 there are always more innovative technologies to learn. This would lead me to start multiple roadmaps but not finish any. 

☔ There are more frequent burnouts due to overwhelm and ADHD paralysis. This happens when you have too much on your plate and you do not know where to start. 


However, if you understand how your brain works, you can manage it well and play to your strengths instead. 

Here are some advantages of a neurodivergent brain:

🌈 𝐈𝐧𝐧𝐨𝐯𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐯𝐞 𝐓𝐡𝐢𝐧𝐤𝐢𝐧𝐠: People with ADHD often think outside the box, leading to creative problem-solving. I always find diverse solutions to any problem. 😎

🌈 𝐇𝐢𝐠𝐡 𝐄𝐧𝐞𝐫𝐠𝐲 𝐋𝐞𝐯𝐞𝐥𝐬: The hyperactivity component of ADHD can translate into high energy and enthusiasm. That is why I can run 5k every day and enjoy working at fast-paced work environments. 

🌈 𝐀𝐛𝐢𝐥𝐢𝐭𝐲 𝐭𝐨 𝐇𝐲𝐩𝐞𝐫𝐟𝐨𝐜𝐮𝐬 𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐀𝐝𝐚𝐩𝐭: Under the right conditions, some people with ADHD can hyperfocus on tasks of interest. This is why I enjoy diving deep into technical and complex problems within the Break Into Data community. 

🌈 𝐑𝐢𝐬𝐤 𝐓𝐨𝐥𝐞𝐫𝐚𝐧𝐜𝐞: I changed industries and professions countless times in my career. I can leverage my diverse experience in any field. If you know how to manage your risk in the long-run, you can be unstoppable too. 


How do you overcome obstacles of neurodivergence? 

Comment below 👇 


#adhd #breakintodata #bid #neurodivergent

name: Meri Nova

content:
Stop mindlessly consuming educational content. 
If you don’t apply it immediately, you will forget it. 

How? 
Here are some ideas to get you started. 

Getting into model evaluation metrics?
- Calculate the precision and recall of your success rate in asking out potential matches on dating apps. Spoiler: Recall may be high, but precision could use some work.

Studying hypothesis testing?
- Perform A/B testing on your LinkedIn posts. Hypothesis: Adding a cat meme increases engagement. Result: Statistically significant and adorably funny.

Learning about natural language processing?
- Build a chatbot to respond to your relatives’ holiday messages. It’s a win-win: you practice NLP, and they think you’re just super engaged this year.

You get the idea. 

Remember, things not applied will be forgotten. 

Now go and get your hands dirty. 

--- 

For more interesting Data Science and ML insights subscribe to our newsletter - merinova.substack.com
name: Meri Nova

content:
I thought I knew real-world engineering - until I started working in the field...

Early in my career, I had a completely wrong idea of what an engineering work environment is. 

Turns out there is a lot more to it than just coding. 

For instance, nobody prepared me for:

- Sprints, and Tickets: There is a thing called agile development (scrum), where everyone gets assigned tickets (tasks) for each sprint (a timeframe for deliverables).

- Daily Standup Meetings: Every morning, you need to update everyone on your progress.

- Deadlines and Deliverables: Unlike personal projects, you will have strict deadlines. To meet them, you need to plan well, coordinate with others, and sometimes make tough decisions between scope and quality. 

...

You could only learn this on the job. 

That is why we decided to tackle this problem by...

Building a first-ever AI manager for our Break Into Data's workshops. 

We made it so she would act as any other human engineer would. 

Don't worry she is a good kind of manager...

She will "only": 

- Assign you tickets with detailed tasks.  👉 Just like with Scrum boards.   
- Message you daily to receive updates. 👉 Just like with Daily Standups.
- Provide you with technical support.  👉 Just like a tech lead would. 

And sometimes even give you compliments and praise. ☺️

This unique learning approach will not only teach you how to build cool projects but also prepare you for the corporate environment. 


And oh, be nice to her! We keep track of your messages too 😈 


P.S. Our upcoming workshop is sold out, but if you want to get early access to the next one, fill out this short form - https://lnkd.in/gETgQWiM

name: Meri Nova

content:
Feature engineering is a critical aspect of building robust ML systems. There isn't one metric that directly measures its quality. However, if you master these 6 techniques you can ensure model's accuracy 80% of the time: 


1. Handling Missing Values:

- Imputation: Replace missing values with the mean, median, or mode, or use predictive imputation. For instance, filling missing ages in a customer dataset with the median age.

- Deletion: Remove rows or columns with too many missing values, but this risks losing important information, like removing a variable that’s highly predictive but has 30% missing data.

2. Scaling and Normalization:

- Scaling: Normalize features to a standard range, such as [0, 1], to ensure equal contribution to the model. 

- Log Transformation: Apply to skewed data like income to stabilize variance and make patterns more discernible, e.g., log-transforming annual income to reduce skewness.

3. Encoding Categorical Features:

- One-Hot Encoding: Transform categorical variables into binary columns. Example: converting "red," "blue," "green" into three binary columns.

- Hashing Trick: Efficiently handle high-cardinality categorical variables, useful in streaming applications where new categories frequently appear, like user IDs in web analytics.

4. Feature Crossing:

- Combining Features: Create new features by combining existing ones to capture interactions, such as combining 'age' and 'income' to create an 'age-income bracket' feature.

5. Dealing with Temporal Data:

- Temporal Features: Extract features like 'day of the week' or 'season' to capture temporal patterns. Example: 'day of the week' can significantly impact sales data analysis.

6. Detecting and Avoiding Data Leakage:

- Data Leakage: Prevent future data from influencing the training process, which can lead to overly optimistic performance metrics. For instance, using data from future events in training can mislead model accuracy.

...

Mastering these feature engineering techniques is one of the things that separates good data scientists from great ones.


#datascience #featureengineering

name: Meri Nova

content:
SQL and NoSQL Databases are fundamentally different. 

Here is how 👇

SQL:

- Requires predefined schemas and relationships
- Supports complex queries and transactions
- Enables precise data retrieval and manipulation 
- Scales vertically
- Ensures data integrity through ACID (Atomicity, Consistency, Isolation, Durability) 
- Usually used in monitoring sales, financial transactions, and inventory


NoSQL: 

- Designed for flexibility and scalability
- Do not require a fixed schema
- Suitable for storing semi-structured or unstructured data
- Optimized for speed and volume over complexity
- Scales horizontally
- Best for reading and displaying diverse data on apps and websites



#sql #dataanalytics #datascience
name: Meri Nova

content:
You are not bad at job search. 
You just lack clarity. 
Let’s build your strategy in 4 steps. 

1. Pick the industry 

Hiring managers want to see domain expertise.
Pick 1-3 industries from the list (Government, Healthcare, Saas, Gaming, Finance, Academia etc) 
Leverage your past experience and domain knowledge to land interviews.
If you don’t have experience, pick one industry and start building your network and portfolio. 

2. Pick the size of the company 

Operating within an early stage startup with 15 people is entirely different from slow bureaucratic walls of the corporate world. 
If you want more growth and more stress pick a startup. 
If you want stability work in the corporate. 

3. Pick your tech stack 

From the choice of your industry and it’s size stems the choice of your tech stack. 

JS, Heroku, Flask, MongoDB - Early stage startups 
Python, Scala, AWS, GCP, Kubernetes - Series B startups 
Excel, Azure, AWS, Databricks - Corporate 
R, MATLAB, Jupyter Notebook - Academia 

4. Choose the problem/department 

What problems do you want to work on? 

Increasing sales - Customer Segmentation, Revenue forecasting, etc. 
Improving the product - A/B testing, CI/CD
Cutting costs - Supply Chain Optimization, Operarions Optimization Analytics 

There are many more problems to address, but it’s good to pick the department from Marketing, Product, Operations, HR, Management. 



🦾Finally pick 1-3 combinations from 4 areas and NAIL THEM DOWN!

♻️ Share with your network. 

—

How do you approach your career strategy?

content:
10 years ago, I wanted to become a Peace Corps volunteer.

7 years ago, I studied Business Administration. 

5 years ago, I started a volunteer travel agency. 

4 years ago, I closed the agency and started running a construction business.

3 years ago, I went bankrupt and taught myself Python instead. 

2.5 years ago, I got my first tech research job to work with robotic arms and computer vision.  

1.5 years ago, I started learning more about NLP and ML in production. 

6 months ago, I launched Break Into Data and started creating content on Linkedin.

And the rest is history. 


Moral of the story? 

Don't be afraid to try new things outside your comfort zone. 

Keep trying and failing, until you find what works for you.

It’s a journey.

Don't forget to enjoy it. 

---

Stay tuned for a podcast episode that's coming out tomorrow with Lindsay Murphy where I share more on my journey.

80% of founders do not know how to conduct layoffs HUMANELY. 
But my last manager did an excellent job firing me. 
This is not a joke.  

It doesn’t mean I didn’t want to cry during THE conversation.

But the entire process was conducted thoughtfully and sensibly. 
Because of this, we sustained a strong friendship to this day. 

At that time, the startup was running low on funds and needed faster results. Since I didn't have a STEM degree or formal engineering experience, I couldn't deliver as fast as needed.

So the founder invited me to his office one day and did the following: 

- Explained startup challenges and timeline consequences for them.
- Provided constructive feedback.
- Recommended I continue higher education or take non-engineering roles at his startup (which I declined).
- Offered help to find the next employment opportunity for me

It has been more than a year since then. 

We still exchange friendly catchup emails and plan to meet again soon. 

—

content:
How to survive Beginner's Hell when learning to code?

Here are 5 things that can help you get un-stuck...

In the digital age, the problem is no longer a lack of resources. 
As a beginner it is easy to get lost, stressed, and overwhelmed with sea of courses, roadmaps, and YouTube channels. 

I have been there too many times and developed my own go-to reminder list below. 
Follow these 5 tips to fuel your learning journey and get un-stuck.


1. 🚀 𝐄𝐦𝐛𝐫𝐚𝐜𝐞 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐉𝐨𝐮𝐫𝐧𝐞𝐲: Understand that feeling lost is a natural part of starting something new. Every expert you admire once stood where you are now. Learn to accept challenges and frictions as part of the learning experience. 

2. 💡 𝐅𝐨𝐜𝐮𝐬 𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐒𝐢𝐦𝐩𝐥𝐢𝐟𝐲: Instead of trying to learn everything at once, pick one area to focus on. Recognize that learning is a marathon, not a sprint. Understand your limits and avoid the urge to rush through materials or jump in-between subjects. Get back to clarity and simplicity each time you get overwhelmed. 

3. 🎯 𝐒𝐞𝐭 𝐑𝐞𝐚𝐥𝐢𝐬𝐭𝐢𝐜 𝐄𝐱𝐩𝐞𝐜𝐭𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧𝐬 𝐟𝐨𝐫 𝐘𝐨𝐮𝐫𝐬𝐞𝐥𝐟: Progress, no matter how small, is still progress. Know your limits. Set achievable daily, weekly, monthly targets and celebrate each milestone! This keeps motivation consistent and the journey more enjoyable.

4. 🤝 𝐒𝐞𝐞𝐤 𝐒𝐮𝐩𝐩𝐨𝐫𝐭: You're not alone. Reach out to mentors, join online communities, or partner with fellow learners. Shared experiences and guidance are invaluable. 

5. 🤗 𝐁𝐮𝐢𝐥𝐝 𝐂𝐨𝐧𝐟𝐢𝐝𝐞𝐧𝐜𝐞: Each evening, write down 5 things you are proud of achieving that day. Try to shoot for small wins. E.g., Solve 1 leetcode problem, push 1 git commit, write one Linkedin post, understand one concept,  etc. 
*This practice helps in recognizing your progress which is crucial in building self-confidence.

Remember, the path from beginner to proficient is not just about acquiring skills; it's about personal growth and resilience. 
Embrace the journey with patience and persistence, and watch as you transform challenges into stepping stones.


--


Do you get stuck or overwhelmed often?

So many beginners make these 6 mistakes when building their first data project. 
They spend months and get nowhere.  

It doesn't have to be that way. 

There is a simple, often overlooked approach to building a data portfolio project that can 10x your chances of landing a job. 

But first, stop making the following mistakes: 

#1 𝐋𝐚𝐜𝐤 𝐨𝐟 𝐬𝐭𝐫𝐚𝐭𝐞𝐠𝐲
Following your curiosity is great, but does it 𝘢𝘭𝘪𝘨𝘯 𝘸𝘪𝘵𝘩 𝘺𝘰𝘶𝘳 𝘫𝘰𝘣 𝘴𝘦𝘢𝘳𝘤𝘩 𝘴𝘵𝘳𝘢𝘵𝘦𝘨𝘺?

#2 𝐋𝐚𝐜𝐤 𝐨𝐟 𝐞𝐱𝐜𝐢𝐭𝐞𝐦𝐞𝐧𝐭 
Are you doing this because you have to or because 𝘺𝘰𝘶 𝘨𝘦𝘵 𝘵𝘰? There is a big difference that will be noticed during your interview. 

#3 𝐆𝐞𝐧𝐞𝐫𝐢𝐜 𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐜𝐥𝐞𝐚𝐧 𝐝𝐚𝐭𝐚𝐬𝐞𝐭𝐬
No more Titanic, Iris, Housing datasets. Use APIs, scrape 𝘺𝘰𝘶𝘳 𝘰𝘸𝘯 𝘥𝘢𝘵𝘢 and learn to clean and preprocess it. 

#4 𝐔𝐧𝐟𝐢𝐧𝐢𝐬𝐡𝐞𝐝 𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐮𝐧𝐝𝐞𝐩𝐥𝐨𝐲𝐞𝐝 𝐩𝐫𝐨𝐣𝐞𝐜𝐭𝐬
Do you also have 10+ Github repos with missing readme pages and only one file? Make it 𝘥𝘪𝘨𝘦𝘴𝘵𝘪𝘣𝘭𝘦 and 𝘥𝘦𝘱𝘭𝘰𝘺 your projects!

#5 𝐋𝐚𝐜𝐤 𝐨𝐟 𝐯𝐢𝐬𝐢𝐛𝐢𝐥𝐢𝐭𝐲

Here are 10 key lessons I learned from hiring managers and leaders in Data. 👇

1. Stop using generic datasets for your projects. 
2. Stand out with your unique interest-driven projects instead.
3. Don't focus too much on the tools and programming languages, focus on the problems and impact of your solutions.

6. Always develop your quantitative skills.

10. If you can, have both, a therapist and a career coach.

Currently, I have a weird approach to learning how to code...

But so far it works very well.

I have two friends who are senior engineers with more than 8 years of experience in full stack development. 

They both contribute to my open source project regularly. 

They have never met and never spoke to each other. 

But sometimes they have conflicting opinions. 

My goal as an owner of the project is to make final decisions... 

This means I have to understand both proposals thoroughly with limited relevant experience. 

I love this because I have to learn fast and make decisions fast. 

All while making sense of their code and its repercussions on the long-term vision of the project. 

Finding yourself in 'a learning sandwich' with more experienced developers is a great way to accelerate learning and make progress on your projects.

name: Meri Nova

content:
Nobody is talking about the importance of Permutations and Combinations in Data Science. 
It is surprisingly simple once you understand this: 

Permutations are just a fancy word for 𝘢𝘳𝘳𝘢𝘯𝘨𝘦𝘮𝘦𝘯𝘵𝘴 that require specific order. 
Combinations are 𝘨𝘳𝘰𝘶𝘱𝘴 of values that do not require order.  

Understanding the difference will help you solve problems related to feature selection for models, predicting the optimal order of operations, A/B testing, hypothesis testing, and many more. 

*At the end of this post you will find a 𝐩𝐫𝐨𝐛𝐥𝐞𝐦 to test your knowledge.

But for now, let's take a simple scenario. 

Imagine a data analyst, Lucy, at a small online retail company. 

She is tasked with analyzing the effectiveness of 3 different marketing emails to see which should be sent first (order matters) and which combination of emails generates the most customer engagement (order doesn't matter).

Lucy wants to test the order of sending these emails to see if it affects customer responses. The 3  emails are an educational email (Email A), a promotional offer (Email B), and a new product announcement (Email C). 

How many different orders can Lucy test sending these emails?

Solution using 𝐏𝐞𝐫𝐦𝐮𝐭𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧𝐬:
There are 3 items (Email A, Email B, Email C), so the number of permutations is 3 factorial (3!), which is 3 × 2 × 1 = 6. The permutations are:

Email A → Email B → Email C
Email A → Email C → Email B
Email B → Email A → Email C
Email B → Email C → Email A
Email C → Email A → Email B
Email C → Email B → Email A

Each order provides a unique sequence for sending the emails, which could lead to different levels of customer engagement.

𝐍𝐨𝐰 𝐢𝐭'𝐬 𝐲𝐨𝐮𝐫 𝐭𝐮𝐫𝐧. 

Solve this problem with 𝒄𝒐𝒎𝒃𝒊𝒏𝒂𝒕𝒊𝒐𝒏𝒔. 

Besides testing the sequence, Lucy also wants to choose combinations of emails to send in a split-test campaign where not all subscribers receive all three emails. 

She decides to test engagement when sending combinations of two emails out of these 3. 

𝐐: How many combinations of two emails can Lucy choose from?


#probability
name: Meri Nova

content:
Don't know what role to choose in Data Science? 
Pick them based on the headaches and the opportunities. 
Here is how 😜 👇 


📊  Data Analyst - Introverts who love dashboards.

𝐇𝐞𝐚𝐝𝐚𝐜𝐡𝐞𝐬: Working with missing data, bad queries, and all for executives to ask for an Excel dashboard at the end. 
𝐎𝐩𝐩𝐨𝐫𝐭𝐮𝐧𝐢𝐭𝐢𝐞𝐬:  It’s a good entry point for transitioning into data science from other fields.


👷‍♂️  Data Engineer - Loves the dirty often underappreciated work.

𝐇𝐞𝐚𝐝𝐚𝐜𝐡𝐞𝐬: Needs to do a lot of data "plumbing" and troubleshooting work only for analysts and managers to complain about the inefficiencies of their pipelines.

👩‍🏫  Analytics Engineer - The middle child.

𝐇𝐞𝐚𝐝𝐚𝐜𝐡𝐞𝐬: Needs to communicate to tech and the business people simultaneously, convincing each on what business metrics matter the most.
𝐎𝐩𝐩𝐨𝐫𝐭𝐮𝐧𝐢𝐭𝐢𝐞𝐬: Can transition to senior roles in Data more naturally. 


💃  Machine Learning Engineer - Hot chick at the bar.

𝐇𝐞𝐚𝐝𝐚𝐜𝐡𝐞𝐬: Everyone wants to be them after Chatgpt got released. Always needs to find the best model all while struggling to find data for it. 
𝐎𝐩𝐩𝐨𝐫𝐭𝐮𝐧𝐢𝐭𝐢𝐞𝐬: Has the highest salary and can easily find a job at another company.

This is Murray.

In 2023, he hosted 118 AI events  in the SF Bay Area alone. 

He built an audience of million people and it all started with a simple blog.  

We met yesterday at one of his events in Palo Alto.

And I couldn’t help but share his journey with you.

His tech career began in London, where he was just starting a blog about emerging technologies.

Dreaming of Silicon Valley, he applied for a U.S. visa, and surprisingly, a member of the American Consulate in the UK was a reader of his blog!

His writing contributions not only helped him secure the visa but also brought his work to the attention of larger publications like Huffington Post and Forbes.

Murray's online presence grew exponentially, garnering over a million followers across Twitter, Linkedin and Instagram.

His love for innovation and entrepreneurial drive led him to build a vibrant AI community in Silicon Valley in less than 2 years.

His story is inspiring, demonstrating how passion and persistence can create massive opportunities.

Be like Murray.

Network like its your last day on the planet.

And open your doors for others to join.

name: Meri Nova

content:
If you're feeling inadequate at your new job or project. 
Remember that this feeling is temporary. 
As the saying goes, “Every master was once a disaster.” 

The common mistake I see a lot is letting self-doubt stop our progress. 

It's a big no no. 

Most people get overwhelmed by the steepness of beginner’s learning curve. 
And get paralyzed. Unable to make a step forward. 

Don't let it happen. 

Think about this—would you be where you are today without any challenges?

Those are essential parts of your growth journey. 

You might not notice it on day-to-day basis, but each time you say - ' I’ll try again tomorrow,' you get a bit closer to your goals.

And in all due time:

🔓 You WILL learn Python, Spark, Scala and SQL syntax. 
🔓 You WILL understand when and how to use Data Science and Engineering Techniques. 
🔓 You WILL be able to build gorgeous and insightful Data charts with any tool you wish to use. 

And much more...

Most importantly, however, you will find yourself having more answers than questions. 

And that will make you unstoppable. 

Keep showing up every day and keep building your knowledge bank. 

Until one day it becomes a second nature to you.

name: Meri Nova

content:
Want to build something cool with LLMs, but don't know where to start? Follow this simple 3-step guideline with resources. 

1. Plan

- First, define your problem and ask yourself: How do you want the result to look like?

- Then, choose an LLM: 
▪️ By size: It can range between 7 to 175 billion parameters. 
▪️ By License: If you are planning to sell your app, you need to use licensed models for commercial use.▪️

Here is the largest GitHub repo for ALL open-source LLMs: https://lnkd.in/gC3cs6F6 


2. Build

- First, customize a pre-trained LLM. 

Here are some popular ways to do so: 
▪️ In-Context Learning (Same as Prompt Engineering)
▪️ Fine-Tuning
▪️ Reinforcement Learning from Human Feedback (RLHF)
▪️ Transfer Learning

- Then, Build an app infrastructure, which requires roughly three components: 

1. 𝐔𝐬𝐞𝐫 𝐢𝐧𝐩𝐮𝐭 𝐰 𝐔𝐈 𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐡𝐨𝐬𝐭𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐩𝐥𝐚𝐭𝐟𝐨𝐫𝐦. (Ex, Streamlit on Heroku)
2. 𝐔𝐬𝐞 𝐏𝐫𝐨𝐦𝐩𝐭 𝐜𝐨𝐧𝐬𝐭𝐫𝐮𝐜𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧 𝐭𝐨𝐨𝐥𝐬. This includes your data source, embedding model, a vector database, prompt construction and optimization tools, and a data filter.
3 𝐎𝐮𝐭𝐩𝐮𝐭 𝐦𝐚𝐧𝐚𝐠𝐞𝐦𝐞𝐧𝐭 𝐭𝐨𝐨𝐥𝐬. Use LLM caching and content filtering for the final output for the user. 


3. Run

After launching your app, you must establish evaluation metrics and continuously track them. 
Include metrics on user engagement and user retention. 
This will help you understand how the user interacts with your app. 

Check out Jeffrey Ip Github repo(2k stars) to evaluate LLMS - https://lnkd.in/gwwdZVhB 
  


And remember, start simple, you can always make your life harder later on. 


If you want to practice...

Register for the End-to-End Live Session with Break Into Data’s CTO tomorrow at 10 AM Pacific time. 

Sign up here - https://lnkd.in/gynhA7qy 


—-



And if you haven't already subscribe to the newsletter here - merinova.substack.com
name: Meri Nova

content:
Kubernetes this, Kubernetes that. 
I am tired of hearing this word everywhere and not knowing what it means.  
Let's break it down now. 🥁 

What is it? 
- Kubernetes is an open-source container orchestration tool launched by Google in 2014.
- It manages applications that are made up of 100s of 1000s containers across different environments (physical machines, VMs, cloud environments)

Why is it important to know? 
- It is used by 3000+ companies including Google, Slack, Udemy etc.
- Skilled Kubernetes developers and operators are in high demand. 🔔
- It has become the standard for deploying and managing containerized applications at scale in the cloud. 

Features: 
- Allows high availability or no downtime
- Highly flexible to increasing or decreasing load with autoscaling
- Allows backup and restoration 


On a personal note,  I will eventually move our AI applications from Heroku to Kubernetes once we begin scaling. 


If you are technical, sign up for our "Break Into Data" newsletter 👇   
merinova.substack.com


What is your go-to orchestration tool?

name: Meri Nova

content:
Why do most ML projects fail? 
Here are 3 common mistakes that could be avoided...

1. Lack of clear objectives. 

Many teams jump straight into ML without a clear understanding of the business problem and whether ML is even the right approach to begin with. To avoid this, gather clear product and software requirements specs from the beginning to avoid costly misunderstandings between you and the client down the line. 

2. Lack of traceability and reproducibility. 

At our last event with Break Into Data, our speaker, Maria Vechtomova, an MLops Manager, explained the importance of reproducibility and observability in MLOps. Without these components, it becomes extremely difficult to scrutinize ML workflow, iterate on top of previous work, scale models to production, or ensure regulatory compliance. Make sure to set up that infrastructure early on. 

3. Poor assumptions on product usage.

Yesterday on our walk with Raja Ramana Kova, a Decision Scientist at Adobe, we discussed the importance of understanding user behavior. Instead of developing ML-driven features, focus first on analyzing data on users' activity. After serving your model, you may realize that the way users interact with your product is different from your initial assumptions, so you have to redo the entire project. To avoid this, make sure you have user behavior analytics data in place beforehand. 


---



What are other mistakes you see?

name: Meri Nova

content:
If you have ADHD you probably switched careers too many times. You relied on the novelty factor and excitement and forgot to think about the bigger picture. 

The problem is you might end up scattered not only in your brain but also in your career trajectory. 

If you do not have a storyline that supports your past decisions it would be difficult to pass interviews and climb the corporate ladder. 

It is time to reassemble your past experiences towards a more clear vision that aligns with your goals. 

Do the following: 

• Go over your past jobs and find common tasks you were surprisingly good at.
• List all of those transferrable skills in one document and name it "Strengths and accomplishments"
• Regularly update that list and look at it whenever you get nervous before interviews. 

Remember, if you did not focus on one career path for 5-10 years it doesn't mean you are worse than the next candidate. 

It means you were brave enough to explore different professional avenues and now have accumulated a unique set of skills. 

It simply makes you more original.

Here is a helpful challenge for you. 

List all of your skills under this post to remind yourself how unique you are. 


I will start. Mine are: 

- Public speaking
- Writing 
- Video editing
- Storytelling 
- Project management
- Data Analytics 
- Machine Learning 
- Computer Vision 
- Backend engineering
- Robotics
- Raspberry pi and IOT devices
- Entrepreneurship


Your turn 🎤

name: Meri Nova

content:
If you are not documenting your work, you are wasting time. 

Many people don’t understand this crucial concept…

Failures are expected.

Especially in the field of Data Science.

In my previous role, we did a lot of robotics, iot and computer vision work. 

There were times, when I would focus too much on solving a certain problem then documenting my attempts. 

It led to a lot of frustration and sometimes I would have to start from scratch.

On the outside it may have looked like I have achieved nothing. 

But in reality, I learned a lot about incompatibilities between software and hardware packages. 

If I hadn't written them down, the next person would have to start from scratch. 

And that is the biggest mistake. 

Remember…

Results are not the only way to provide value. 

Documentation is what truly makes your work standout in the long run. 


—-

How do you keep track of your failures ?

content:
Putting all of your code in server.py is not how you organize a web app. 

Follow this guide to learn fundamentals.

Here is an example of a simple web app structure with Flask , PostgreSQL and Heroku server. 

𝐊𝐞𝐲 𝐂𝐨𝐦𝐩𝐨𝐧𝐞𝐧𝐭𝐬:

𝐀𝐩𝐩 𝐅𝐨𝐥𝐝𝐞𝐫: Contains all your Flask app's main files.
__𝐢𝐧𝐢𝐭__.𝐩𝐲: Initializes your Flask application.
𝐫𝐨𝐮𝐭𝐞𝐬.𝐩𝐲: Defines the routes of your web application.
𝐦𝐨𝐝𝐞𝐥𝐬.𝐩𝐲: Contains your database models (for PostgreSQL).
𝐭𝐞𝐦𝐩𝐥𝐚𝐭𝐞𝐬/: Stores HTML templates.
𝐬𝐭𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐜/: Holds static files like CSS, JS, and images.

𝐓𝐞𝐬𝐭𝐬 𝐅𝐨𝐥𝐝𝐞𝐫: For your unit tests. Always test your code!
𝐕𝐢𝐫𝐭𝐮𝐚𝐥 𝐄𝐧𝐯𝐢𝐫𝐨𝐧𝐦𝐞𝐧𝐭 (𝐯𝐞𝐧𝐯/): Keeps your dependencies isolated. Remember to include venv/ in your .gitignore file!
𝐑𝐞𝐪𝐮𝐢𝐫𝐞𝐦𝐞𝐧𝐭𝐬.𝐭𝐱𝐭: Lists all Python dependencies. Crucial for Heroku to install all necessary packages.
𝐑𝐮𝐧𝐭𝐢𝐦𝐞.𝐭𝐱𝐭: Specifies the Python version for Heroku.
𝐏𝐫𝐨𝐜𝐟𝐢𝐥𝐞: A must-have for Heroku deployment, it tells Heroku how to run your app.
.𝐠𝐢𝐭𝐢𝐠𝐧𝐨𝐫𝐞: Specifies files/folders that Git should ignore. (e.g., venv/, *.pyc, .env)
𝐑𝐄𝐀𝐃𝐌𝐄.𝐦𝐝: Your repo's introduction. Explain what your app does, how to set it up, and any other relevant info.


𝐁𝐞𝐬𝐭 𝐏𝐫𝐚𝐜𝐭𝐢𝐜𝐞𝐬:

Consistent Naming: Stick to a naming convention (like snake_case for Python files).
Keep It Clean: Regularly refactor and remove unused files.
Document Everything: Comments in code and a detailed README can save lives!
Commit Often: Small, frequent commits with clear messages are better than one large, vague commit.


Organizing your GitHub repo might seem like a small task, but it's a cornerstone of good project management. It not only makes your life easier but also encourages others to view and contribute to your project. So, let's keep those repos clean and shining! ✨


What else would you add?

name: Meri Nova

content:
I knew nothing about 𝐚𝐬𝐲𝐧𝐜𝐡𝐫𝐨𝐧𝐨𝐮𝐬 𝐨𝐩𝐞𝐫𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧𝐬, even though almost all of our Open Source Code relies on them. Read this post so you can build more efficient and scalable applications.

Here is a cooking analogy to explain  'async' and 'await' functions.

Imagine you're preparing a grand feast. 🥘 

Each dish represents a task in your program. In traditional synchronous cooking (or programming), you'd prepare one dish at a time, which can be time-consuming and inefficient.

Let's say you discovered asynchronous cooking and decided to try it out. 

🔹 Async Cooking: You start cooking a dish and move on to prep the next while the first one is still simmering. In programming, this is akin to starting a task and then awaiting its completion while you get on with something else. This is particularly handy when a task involves waiting (like fetching data or waiting for a user's input).

👩‍🍳 Check out  a simple Python code snippet to illustrate this concept. 

Each dish is a task. 
Using 𝐚𝐬𝐲𝐧𝐜 𝐝𝐞𝐟, we define an asynchronous function, cook_dish, which simulates cooking.
𝐚𝐰𝐚𝐢𝐭 𝐚𝐬𝐲𝐧𝐜𝐢𝐨.𝐬𝐥𝐞𝐞𝐩(𝐜𝐨𝐨𝐤𝐢𝐧𝐠_𝐭𝐢𝐦𝐞) mimics the dish cooking. Meanwhile, your program can do other tasks.
𝐚𝐬𝐲𝐧𝐜𝐢𝐨.𝐠𝐚𝐭𝐡𝐞𝐫 is your multitasking hero, handling multiple dishes at once.

🧑‍💻 Asynchronous programming can be a game-changer, especially for I/O bound tasks. It's like having a smart kitchen where dishes almost cook themselves while you manage other tasks, making your programming kitchen a lot more productive.

                                                                 ➿  ➿ ➿

content:
How To Remember (Almost) Everything? 
Here are 5 techniques that help me study Data Science efficiently. 

Learning is a skill. 
But it is often overlooked. 

We are bombarded with an endless stream of information when trying to upskill, but have you stopped to ask: 

"Am I doing this the right way?" 

Let's go over the 5 techniques to optimize our learning. 

🧠 𝐒𝐩𝐚𝐜𝐞𝐝 𝐫𝐞𝐩𝐞𝐭𝐢𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧. 
You may be able to remember everything you learned from last night, but if you do not practice active recall in a day, 3 days, and a week. You won't be able to remember it during your interviews. 

🧠 𝐀𝐩𝐩𝐥𝐲 𝐭𝐡𝐞 80/20 𝐫𝐮𝐥𝐞. 
Identify the 20% of key concepts that get asked 80% of the time in a desired field of work. And nail them. Focus on key algorithms, statistical concepts, and most popular packages. 

🧠 𝐓𝐞𝐚𝐜𝐡. 
Teaching forces you to break down complex ideas into simpler components. By repeatedly explaining concepts and answering questions, you reinforce neural pathways associated with the material, making it easier to recall in the future. Extra tip. Prepare a list of questions and try going for a Youtube Live!

🧠 𝐕𝐢𝐬𝐮𝐚𝐥𝐢𝐳𝐞. 
Use visual aids such as diagrams, mind maps, or charts to represent concepts and relationships between ideas. Visualizing information can aid in understanding, retention, and recall.

🧠 𝐀𝐩𝐩𝐥𝐲 𝐰𝐡𝐚𝐭 𝐲𝐨𝐮 𝐥𝐞𝐚𝐫𝐧𝐞𝐝: Ignite your curiosity and think of ways you can apply attained knowledge to build something useful. It is better to pause before learning new concepts to understand the opportunities and limitations of each framework. 


What do you do that helps you learn better? 


If you are a social learner, join Break Into Data and find a study partner! 👍

content:
Build and deploy your first ML model in 30 days. 
𝐃𝐚𝐲 2 - 𝐇𝐨𝐰 𝐭𝐨 𝐩𝐢𝐜𝐤 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐫𝐢𝐠𝐡𝐭 𝐩𝐫𝐨𝐣𝐞𝐜𝐭 𝐢𝐝𝐞𝐚? 
Read this 10-step guideline to get started 👇 

1️⃣		𝐈𝐝𝐞𝐧𝐭𝐢𝐟𝐲 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐍𝐚𝐭𝐮𝐫𝐞 𝐨𝐟 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐓𝐚𝐬𝐤:
What is the task's domain? (e.g., LLM, Computer Vision, recommendation systems) as it influences your choice of data source and algorithms.
Pro tip: Start with simpler models like classification and regressions. 

2️⃣ 		𝐒𝐞𝐥𝐞𝐜𝐭 𝐘𝐨𝐮𝐫 𝐃𝐚𝐭𝐚 𝐒𝐨𝐮𝐫𝐜𝐞 𝐂𝐚𝐫𝐞𝐟𝐮𝐥𝐥𝐲:
Collect your own data or use existing datasets (text, image, audio). 
Understand that the nature of your task dictates the type of data and its processing needs. 

3️⃣ 		𝐂𝐡𝐨𝐨𝐬𝐞 𝐓𝐞𝐜𝐡𝐧𝐨𝐥𝐨𝐠𝐲:
Pick tech stack relevant to your desired job - PyTorch, TensorFlow, Apache Spark, BERT, OpenCV etc.  
Use platforms like Workera to evaluate skills or follow trends to select valuable technologies to learn.

4️⃣ 		𝐀𝐥𝐢𝐠𝐧 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐏𝐫𝐨𝐣𝐞𝐜𝐭'𝐬 𝐃𝐢𝐟𝐟𝐢𝐜𝐮𝐥𝐭𝐲 𝐰𝐢𝐭𝐡 𝐘𝐨𝐮𝐫 𝐈𝐧𝐭𝐞𝐫𝐞𝐬𝐭:
Choose projects you are genuinely interested in to maintain motivation. 
You should be invested in solving the problem at hand.  

5️⃣ 		𝐃𝐚𝐭𝐚 𝐏𝐫𝐞𝐩𝐚𝐫𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧 𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐀𝐯𝐚𝐢𝐥𝐚𝐛𝐢𝐥𝐢𝐭𝐲:
Investigate the availability and preparation for your chosen data source.
You can get stuck here for more time than necessary. 

6️⃣ 		𝐌𝐨𝐝𝐞𝐥 𝐑𝐞𝐚𝐝𝐢𝐧𝐞𝐬𝐬 𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐀𝐝𝐚𝐩𝐭𝐚𝐛𝐢𝐥𝐢𝐭𝐲:
Evaluate whether to use pre-built models or develop one from scratch.
If you are a beginner, build a model from scratch, it ensures a deeper understanding of its components.

7️⃣ 		𝐏𝐫𝐨𝐣𝐞𝐜𝐭 𝐒𝐭𝐫𝐮𝐜𝐭𝐮𝐫𝐞:
Break down the project into manageable parts: 

CORE MACHINE LEARNING WORK - You can use Jupiter Notebook here.
LOCAL DEMO - Use Streamlit or Flask to allow interaction with your model. 
CLOUD DEPLOYMENT - AWS, Google Cloud, or Azure can host your model, so anyone can access it with API calls. *I will focus on GCP for this month. 

8️⃣ 		𝐈𝐭𝐞𝐫𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐯𝐞 𝐃𝐞𝐯𝐞𝐥𝐨𝐩𝐦𝐞𝐧𝐭 𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐋𝐞𝐚𝐫𝐧𝐢𝐧𝐠:
Approach your project in stages, starting with a simple, manageable task. Expand complexity as your skills and understanding grow.

9️⃣ 		𝐑𝐞𝐚𝐥-𝐖𝐨𝐫𝐥𝐝 𝐀𝐩𝐩𝐥𝐢𝐜𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧 𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐉𝐨𝐛 𝐑𝐞𝐥𝐞𝐯𝐚𝐧𝐜𝐞:
Design your project with real job tasks in mind, such as data pipelining, feature engineering, and model deployment.
Mimic real-world applications and challenges faced in machine learning roles.

🔟 		𝐅𝐞𝐞𝐝𝐛𝐚𝐜𝐤 𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐈𝐭𝐞𝐫𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧:
Be open to revising your project based on feedback or as you gain new insights. We will host weekly presentations in our community. Stay tuned for details. 


Subscribe to our newsletter for more educational materials for this 30-Day ML challenge.

content:
Do not let layoffs scare you. 
It is easier said than done. 
But it will change your life. 

The key is to remember that such events often reflect larger circumstances that are outside of your control, such as:  

🌪 Market fluctuations
🌪 Technological advancement
🌪 Company-wide restructuring
🌪 Geopolitical uncertainties.

It is your responsibility however to prepare yourself for all possible scenarios in the future.

Focus on what you can control: 
 
🔱 Regulating your own emotions and nervous system
🔱 Professional and Interview Skills
🔱 Your network
🔱 Resilience and adaptability
🔱 Support system 
🔱 Daily Attitude


Whatever doesn't kill you, makes you stronger.

content:
How to reframe Career Gaps in your resume? 
Here are 4 ways for each circumstance 👇 


📉Temporary Layoff: 
"I worked at X company during their restructuring phase from [start date] to [end date]. Since then, I remained updated on industry trends, participated in workshops in my field, and researched future opportunities."

😷 Health reason: 
"I faced a health issue that required my full attention from [start date] to [end date]. I am grateful to be fully recovered and now excited to resume my career path."

🚀 Personal Growth: "During [start date] and [end date] I focused on [include personal development goals like health, finances, wellness] which allowed me to return to the workforce with renewed energy, clarity, and enthusiasm."

📚 Skill Development: 
"During the gap in my career from [start date] and [end date] I focused on upskilling in specific areas that can further benefit my career. [For example, mention courses, certifications, projects and freelancing/volunteering experiences that allowed you to grow from Data Analytics to Data Science]. I believe, these activities have prepared me well for this position." 


#careergap #jobsearch #datascience #mentalhealth
name: Meri Nova

content:
Data Analytics Project with personal data 📊  (Results are surprising!) 

I finally got to explore my health metrics and see how I can improve them, especially the HRV (Heart rate variability).

It is one of the best metrics to focus on as it describes your overall well-being. 
This time I am focusing on two factors that impact HRV. 
Time of falling asleep and duration of sleep. 
To be honest with you, I was not expecting these results. 

Goal 🎯 : Understand how sleep impacts my HRV.
Resources 🚰 : Accumulated 6 months of personal health data by WHOOP wearable.
Question: What impacts my HRV the most when it comes to sleep? Duration or time of falling asleep?
Methods: EDA, Data Visualization, Correlation Coefficient, P value. 

Results: Shocking! Apparently there is not much correlation between amount of sleep and HRV. However, it is clear there is a relationships between the time of falling asleep and HRV. I want to continue figuring this out, I am not fully convinced yet.


Let me know what else I could look into!


P.S. Remember these findings and suggestions are not universal. It is based off of my personal data. What works for me, may not work for you. 


#dataanalysis #dataanalytics #healthdata #wearabletech #HRV #sleep #mentalhealth #eda #datavisualization #bioinformatics #personalhealth
name: Meri Nova

content:
How To Create Your First Product Development Roadmap in 6 Easy Steps?
This guide will help you save your team countless hours and unnecessary meetings. 

Recently, we welcomed 5 new developers and analysts to our Open Source Project, Break Into Data. 😍 

It became apparent that our only points of reference were the GitHub repository and our Discord channel, showing a clear need for a more centralized roadmap as our team of contributors is growing rapidly. 🎯 

So we decided to consolidate everything into our Product Roadmap.  📜 

Here is how we approached it: 

1. 𝐕𝐢𝐬𝐢𝐨𝐧 𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐒𝐜𝐨𝐩𝐞: Begin with a clear vision. What problem does your software solve? Who is it for? Define the scope to focus your efforts.

2. 𝐒𝐞𝐭 𝐎𝐛𝐣𝐞𝐜𝐭𝐢𝐯𝐞𝐬: Break your vision into achievable objectives. What are the critical milestones for your project? E.g., Establishing higher level system design, Deciding where to host your core infrastructure, etc. 

3. 𝐏𝐫𝐢𝐨𝐫𝐢𝐭𝐢𝐳𝐞 𝐅𝐞𝐚𝐭𝐮𝐫𝐞𝐬: Identify and prioritize the features that are crucial for your MVP (Minimum Viable Product). Focus on what delivers the most value to your users. We identified 3 core features: Onboarding, LLM-driven submissions, and Personal & Global Analytics. 

4. 𝐓𝐢𝐦𝐞𝐥𝐢𝐧𝐞 𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐏𝐡𝐚𝐬𝐞𝐬: Draft a realistic timeline. Outline the phases of development, from initial design to testing, and set deadlines for each phase. I like to refer to the Software Release Life Cycle. (SRLC)

5. 𝐀𝐬𝐬𝐢𝐠𝐧 𝐑𝐨𝐥𝐞𝐬: Clearly define team roles and responsibilities. Everyone needs to have a sense of ownership and accountability for the quality of their deliverables. 

6. 𝐈𝐭𝐞𝐫𝐚𝐭𝐞 𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐀𝐝𝐚𝐩𝐭: Embrace agility. Regularly review your roadmap and be ready to adapt based on feedback and new insights. Have weekly meetings to go through the results of the past week and goals for the next. 



How do you approach your product development life cycle? 



P.S. Attached picture is for example reference. It is not our roadmap. 

If you want to learn more about our progress, look out for our next article - https://lnkd.in/gEMeG9GV 🤗

How to combine several AI models to produce 10x better video content on autopilot?

Last week,  Kostya Cholak, and I, realized we need more educational video content on Youtube for our community Break Into Data. 

But we do not have time and existing AI video generators are just not good enough. 
We decided to build our own Video Generator instead. 

Here is how.👇

We used: 

1.  𝐎𝐩𝐞𝐧𝐀𝐈 to generate code and its description based on the topic we provided. 
2. 𝐏𝐢𝐥𝐥𝐨𝐰 Python library to generate frames consisting of code.
3. 𝐄𝐥𝐞𝐯𝐞𝐧𝐥𝐚𝐛𝐬 to generate audio from text.
4. 𝐟𝐟𝐦𝐩𝐞𝐠 to process and combine audio with frames to generate the final version.

The results were surprisingly good. 

Check out the video attached. 

This is exciting because now we will have another "worker" who will help us create high-quality content on Youtube!
